DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1986-87[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 1) 1986-87APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 2) 1986-87]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 November, on motion by Senator Walsh:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1986-87 cognately with the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1986-87 and the Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1986-87, which arise from the 1986-87 Budget. As was correctly pointed out by Senator Messner, who led for the Opposition in this debate, these Bills need to be considered in the light of the growing global economic difficulties. In this way we can identify the enormity of the problems facing this small country with its small economy in a world context. Senator Messner's overwhelming problem, when he tried to deal with this issue, was that he could offer no solutions, partly because the monetarist theories his Party has so slavishly followed are now increasingly seen as the cause of the world's economic problems rather than the solution, and partly because his Party has no credible stance on issues such as taxation and the economy. While Senator Messner correctly tried to put things in a global perspective, he was unable to provide anything other than superficial and glib assertions. Senator Messner's argument on tax has been admirably dealt with by my colleagues Senator Maguire and Senator Cooney, who yesterday very effectively answered the economic issues raised.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to bring to this debate a realistic perspective of the world economic situation. Senator Messner spoke about his concern over rising world debt, including ours. That is the point he emphasised, but he failed to identify the major reasons behind the buildup of this debt. It is important to do that because it is now internationally recognised that the financial system propping up the world at present is in real difficulty. One of the major reasons for the deterioration is the massive Third World debt. That debt is a result of the global downturn in the production of commodities and raw materials. Current world debt is in the order of $US900 billion, amounting to more than one-third of the Third World's gross domestic product. For many countries the ratio of debt repayment to national export earnings is now insufferable. Indeed, this very day a conference is taking place in Lima, Peru, of the 30 most underprivileged countries. The 30 countries that head the list of indebtedness are meeting in a three-day conference to consider what they might do. They will be considering proposals to repay debts with goods, to stretch repayment periods and to convert loans to grants. So for the first time the underprivileged and poor countries of Africa, Asia and South America are together considering their desperate position-and it is a desperate position.

In contrast to the early 1970s, when repayments typically averaged only one-fifth of export earnings, they now amount to one-half, two-thirds and in some cases more than the total visible exports of some countries. This reduces not only the feasibility of paying back debt capital but also the ability to import from the industrialised world. This debt crisis also endangers financial institutions in the industrialised world. Debt due from the four largest Latin American countries alone is equal to double, or more, the reserves of the top 10 private United States banks and two of the top four British banks taken together. That shows the enormity of the debt problem that major Third World countries face. Global debt is too important a matter to entrust to the private banks of the world alone.

There are also key relationships between interest rates and debt servicing capacity. High interest rates not only mean high interest payments but also weaken the debtor's capacity to pay. High interest rates kept the United States dollar strong by attracting foreign capital to the United States, but they thereby made capital less available for other countries, driving up the cost of imports in developing countries and leaving less foreign exchange available for debt servicing, without necessarily increasing the exports of those countries because the lower import costs in the United States give rise to protectionism in that country. Although we saw last year the Group of Five countries trying to lower the value of the United States dollar, to some extent successfully, I am concerned because the US still has a massive deficit. It has that massive deficit because President Reagan continues to base it on a tremendous armaments budget that is on the never-never plan. It is not being paid for out of the current United States Budget. It has accumulated to massive proportions. The deficit, by its nature, acts as a threat to world trade.

The international community has been forced to drop some of the most hard line and damaging manifestations of monetarism. In particular, the concept of free trade and financial deregulation has had to be rethought. Australia has to give consideration to this matter because it is under pressure to follow the United States. In Europe, countries other than the United Kingdom have attempted to negotiate and to consult with each other in order to make sure that there are not massive movements in their currencies and that the right level of currency occurs so that there is no disruption to their trade and the development of their industries. We also have to consider the limits of the concept of free trade because it is used so blithely and so easily to mean so many different things. Although there must be a major emphasis on the development of free trade so that the economies of the world can prosper and so that we will not slip into a recession or even a depression, we must make sure that we are not gullible and that we do not just adopt slogans. Often in the past we have been urged by other countries to reduce our tariffs. While we must attempt to reduce our tariffs it has got to be done in a most orderly way. We in Australia tend to forget-when we are often lectured by the financial Press-that we should take down the protection we give our industry. We have to remember that there are 20,000 non-tariff barriers in other countries throughout the world which are often much more subtle than the methods we use.

This Government has in a planned way-I suggest that this is absolutely necessary in the steel and heavy engineering industries-made sure that as we reduce our tariffs we protect our industries. It has made sure that we do not have the disruption and the complete chaos that can occur if we holus-bolus reduce the barriers that are necessary to protect our own industries. It is a more difficult world. With the election of the Democrats in both the Senate and the Congress in America it appears that there are more difficult times ahead for our farm goods sector. But this is just a small part of our problem as a small economy still reliant on the sales of commodities. We have to accept that the supply side of the global economy has been transformed since World War II.

Some 200 companies now account for one-third of the world's total production. For more than a decade transnational production in different countries has been greater than total world trade. The transnational companies' use of devices such as transfer pricing make notions of free trade futile. So, too, does the growth of what has wrongly been termed free trade zones. These zones are industrial development areas in remote or underdeveloped parts of a country which are often guarded by special security forces.

The companies operating within these zones are multinationals which have been encouraged by governments which want to industrialise at a faster rate. These zones are notorious for poor wages and conditions and they operate under such favourable circumstances for their multinational owners that even to consider competing against them on the grounds of free trade would be ludicrous. It is in this context that the Government is currently considering the textile, clothing and footwear recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission. I certainly hope that the Government rejects the most extreme recommendations of the IAC and seeks to make sure that we maintain a healthy textile, clothing and footwear industry. It is an industry that is essential to the regional development of this country. It is particularly important to the women it employs and to the high number of ethnic people who work in it.

There is another reason why we must firmly reject any attempt to return to the monetarist theories which dominated the world during the 1970s and early 1980s. Monetarism imposed impossible conditions on the governments of the Third World debtors which, as I have said, along with the massive worldwide build-up in armaments has taken valuable resources away from the Third World. As Global Challenge, the publication of the Socialist International, puts it:

Friedmanite and monetarist influences, combined with the market philosophies of the New Right, have seriously damaged the prospects of global development and imposed the cost of crisis on the world's poor.

For example, the monetarist International Monetary Fund has imposed draconian policies on the Third World poor by insisting on massive expenditure cuts in housing, health and education in those Third World countries. In my view there is a great deal of merit in the arguments contained in the book Global Challenge which reflects the consensus of views of Socialist International, the International Organisation of Labour, Social Democratic and socialist organisations throughout the world. It provides a new model for world development-the recovery of growth through redistribution rather than redistribution through growth, which has not worked.

For 10 per cent of what the world now spends on arms each year we could begin a process of global recovery and achieve a decade of new development for the north and the south of the globe. I am not suggesting that we should take that one-tenth of the armament figures from the armament budgets as that is probably unreal in the world in which we live today. What is being put forward by Socialist International is that a figure of 10 per cent could be taken each year and used for the development of the countries of the south. When we consider that meeting of 100 delegates in Lima today we realise that we have to do something for those countries that face bankruptcy, otherwise the whole world financial structure could be brought to its knees with the bankruptcy of any of those countries. We must argue for the redistribution of resources which will lead to economic growth-it is as simple as that. If we do not, and if we reply on the discredited monetarist principles of trickle down effects these poor countries will become poorer and finally will become bankrupt. So we have a fundamental alternative to the monetarist and New Right philosophies.

Socialist International makes many recommendations in restructuring the global trade and financial structures in order to provide for a more stable and more equal world. This gives us the element of a world strategy based on recover, redistribution, development, disarmament and democracy. Monetarist governments have imposed a high interest rate, low public spending regime which, in turn, has exacerbated the position of the poor in their own countries. We have no better example than the Fraser-Howard regime in the 1970s. In the decade before 1982 the number of people in poverty increased by 55 per cent-from 9 per cent of the population to 14 per cent-and the number of unemployed rose more than fourfold.

This leads me to discuss an even greater error that I believe the Fraser Government committed in the belief of promoting Australia as a quarry of the world. It said `We will have no more economic problems', and it talked up the resources boom. It is ironic that Senator Messner, who was leading for the Opposition, was troubled by what was in effect his own Government's actions and his actions as a Minister in that Government. This Labor Government is now having to deal with the consequences of the legacy of the Fraser Government. In fact, the Australian people are having to pay the price for the ill-timed and foolish gamble of the Fraser Government where so much public borrowing was made to deal with the proposed resources boom that did not occur.

Relatively, however, now we find that public borrowing levels are no longer a problem. I am concerned about the private borrowing levels. In my view, they will need to be watched very carefully. Private sector debt, fuelled strongly by speculation and take over mania, has become a most pressing issue. The drive for short term profits has caused alarm among many economic commentators. A couple of very respected commentators-Max Walsh and Ken Davidson of the Age-have drawn attention to these problems. I notice that even the Business Review Weekly has to concede that there are some danger signals. In its annual glorification of Australia's richest 200 people it pointed out:
There are parallels-
with the 1920s-
The new entrepreneurs, like those of 60 years ago, are exploiting the miracle of leverage to build big equity holdings.
It continued:
Banks are lending against the security of shares at a time when share markets are very high.

I am concerned-I believe we need to monitor it closely-that the institutions which wheel and deal in takeovers and corporate raiding do so at the expense of ordinary taxpayers, and we will have further problems. When we consider these appropriations and the stringent limitations this Government has placed on government spending, it is of concern to see an accelerating trend which is reported in an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 29 October. A survey of 150 companies showed that the corporate tax rate, which is officially 46c in the dollar, was effectively 26c in the dollar. This is worse than the heyday of the bottom of the harbour schemes in 1980, when the corporate tax rate was effectively 37.12c in the dollar.

We are talking about the top 150 companies; we are not talking about small business, which in general is paying the rate of 46c in the dollar. What is most galling is that the taxpayer continues to fund the companies involved in the takeover area, such as Bell Group Ltd, Industrial Equity Ltd and Bond Corporation. While 46c in the dollar is the rate, Bell, for example, pays 28.02c in the dollar; IEL pays 4.66c in the dollar; Elders pays 10.35c in the dollar; and Bond Corporation pays 13.95c in the dollar. So the top 150 companies in Australia-the representatives of the big end of town, as I would put it-are not paying their fair share of corporate tax. Although the Government has plans in place with its imputation proposals, it is of great concern and something we must examine very carefully.

In relation to the tax paid by Elders-honourable senators will recall that I said that Elders paid 10.35c instead of 46c in the dollar-I note with interest that Elders is controlled by the Treasurer of the Liberal Party of Australia, John Elliott. As far as I am concerned, he is living off the backs of wage and salary earners through the tremendous taxation concessions he has had as a result of his takeover bids, but he does not want to invest in Australia. I think most Australians are appalled that this businessman and Treasurer of the Liberal Party should say that he will not invest in Australia. It is outrageous and, if I could also use the expression of Senator Messner, very sinister. It is sinister because what John Elliott would really like to see is a government cowering in submission to the most ruthless elements in the corporate sector. Seeing, as we do, at this moment these people in the New Right-or the old extremist of the corporate area, whatever one wants to call them-demanding that the Liberal Party of Australia follow their extremist views, which in many cases are pre-fascist in their approach to economic matters, is certainly something which I believe is reprehensible.

As far as I am concerned, it is reprehensible because we have already seen that the wage and salary earners of this country have made massive sacrifices. The wages share of gross domestic product was 64 per cent in 1982-83. In 1985-86 it fell to 59.3 per cent-the lowest level since the early 1970s. In contrast, the share of GDP which went to profit in 1985-86 was 40.7 per cent-the highest share since the early 1970s. This compares with a share of 36 per cent in the last year of the Fraser Government. I am not contesting the importance of creating profit. I am not suggesting that it is not proper that we encourage corporations to make profits. But this must be on the basis that they are loyal to Australia and that those profits are ploughed back into industry, into development and into Australian jobs. I oppose the concept that some of the extremists in the Opposition maintain, that we should be guided by what Mr Everingham, the member for the Northern Territory, succinctly described as the greed or avarice for profits, without concern for the national interest and for creating employment in Australia.

So when I consider what Senator Messner said on behalf of the Opposition-he had the audacity to say that the Australian Council of Trade Unions was sinister in its desire to see up to 20 per cent of superannuation funds reinvested in Australia, and therefore in long term rewards in terms of increased employment in industry-I am flabbergasted that the Opposition should be so disloyal to the need to increase the development of Australian industry. I say to Senator Messner and the Opposition that when this matter is further developed by the ACTU and the Government they will find that all the reputable insurance, assurance and superannuation funds will be only too happy to have long term investment and to invest a percentage of the money available in Australian industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Provided they are all treated equally.

—I think it is important, of course, that they be treated equally. But also I am not very happy with some of the fly by night people in this field who are only concerned with the maximum amount of profit in the short term and who will go overseas regardless of the long term interests of the Australian people.
—Would you agree, Senator, that this would require a government law along those lines?

—Certainly I agree with the honourable senator's approach on this. I have been very consistent in believing that we must develop Australian industry and, indeed, I am proud to say that I am Chairman of a Senate committee that is trying to encourage the revitalisation of Australian industry. I think it is most sinister that people should not see their primary concern as the development of Australian industry and making sure that capital goes into Australian industry and that capital does not become just a matter of speculation.
—Mr Fitzgibbon pointed out that one could get more money on deposit. Charlie Fitzgibbon pointed out his own concerns about that. Do you deny he is a patriot?

—Mr Charlie Fitzgibbon is a patriot and he has argued for a properly planned approach to the economy of Australia. I do not have any difficulty with believing that we must plan the resources of Australia in such a way as to develop Australian industry. That means examining many things in this country. I believe that this Government has shown with the industry plans that it has already developed that it will do just that. In the next decade under Labor governments industry after industry in Australia, I believe, will find that they have effective plans that will increase their productivity and develop new industries. We must certainly make sure that this is Australia's priority, facing, as I have described, the tremendous problems that any realistic assessment of the world in which we now live will show.

SPEECH.PARA: If I react to all the interjections, I shall take up someone else's time, so I conclude by referring the Senate to a remark of someone whose views are worthy of consideration-Galbraith. He said that he could never understand why it was that the rich needed tax cuts and, therefore, rises in income in order to restore their incentive, whereas the poor needed to have their incomes cut in order to restore their incentive. That applies to the world at present, and it certainly applies in Australia. We must ensure that we are identifying with the people who are today struggling in Lima, Peru and with the problem of bankruptcy for the 30 poorest countries of the world. We must also be concerned in our own country that we follow economic policies that will create growth here. In these appropriations this Government is laying the foundation so that we shall be able to develop our industries and this country's economy for the next decade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is intriguing to hear Senator Childs talk critically of a previous government for talking up what he described as a resources boom when he has clear evidence that there was a resources boom in respect of investment which, unfortunately, did not carry forward into a resources boom in respect of earnings from that investment, largely because there was a downturn in world economics. It is intriguing in that context to hear a member of the Australian Labor Party talking about talking up a situation when we have this nation's Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) engaged right now in one of the most disreputable efforts to talk up an economy. On 11 November the Prime Minister deceptively said that members of the other place would recall that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) had made it clear `that there was an expectation that economic conditions would improve in this country in the first half of 1987'. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: I am very pleased to say that the most recent economic indicators are consistent with the expectation then expressed.
He pointed to the following factors:

. . . the greater confidence in the Australian dollar, to the indicated improvement in consumer confidence and also to the increasing evidence that domestic manufacturers are recognising the opportunities offered to them by the significant depreciation that has occurred in this country.

If honourable senators have ever heard pie in the sky stuff, this is it-deliberate deception and a deliberate misconstruction of the reality of what is happening in this nation right now. In just three-quarters of an hour's time we shall see the latest evidence of governmental deception of the people when the balance of payments figures come out. It will be another disaster. Let us remember what this Government said about the balance of payments last year: How it would get a little bit worse before it got an awful lot better. Leave out the rest-just retain the word `awful' and the Government is right. As we remember, in the Budget last year the Government told us how things would get so much better and how the balance of payments deficit on current account would be less than the $14.7 billion forecast. Of course, we can see now that last year it was far worse than was forecast, and that this year it will blow out enormously. We shall already have a deficit of about $6 billion in four months by the time the figures come out today, and we are still getting the nonsense that we have been getting continually from this Government. It is a deliberate campaign of deception. What is the reason? It is to talk up the Australian dollar, to tide things over so that the Government can-hopefully, perhaps-run for an early election next February, before the house of cards crumbles, a house of cards that is being deceptively and dishonourably created by this Government to try to fool the Australian people about the real nature of our economic standing. One has only to look at the ANZ Bank `Business Indicators' spring 1986 issue, which says:
However, for there to be any significant reduction in imports and increase in exports new investment will be needed.

What is happening to new investment in Australia? Can the Labor Party tell us about a great new surge of investment? Of course it cannot. Not even Bob Hawke, in his misleading statements in the House of Representatives, can pretend that there is anything like an investment resurgence going on. Yet even the economists in the Labor Party-those who can add up, and those who are not such lateral thinkers that they think one and one make 11-cannot pretend that there is any investment going on in this nation. There is in fact a fall in the level of investment, yet everyone recognises that to solve the basic problems involved in the balance of payments current account, there must be an increase in investment. The ANZ spring 1986 bulletin said:
In the absence of an investment led recovery, the outlook for the economy is grim.

That is not what the Prime Minister said. I wonder who is right? Do we believe the Prime Minister, who talked up the economy all of last year and was shown to be totally incorrect, who kept on talking about what interest rates would do, and was proved to be totally incorrect; or do we believe people who do not have the vested interest that the Prime Minister has in deceiving the people about what is going on in our economy? Do we believe the people who know what is happening in the real world?

Let us look at the real world, and at what is happening in the balance of payments area on which our future depends-our ability to export and our requirements to import. Let us look at the situation in which the Prime Minister pretends that there is a great and buoyant economy where everything will be all right again, as he consistently and mistakenly has been saying for so long. Let us look at what is happening and the impact on our balance of payments. Right now we are facing the prospect of a cut of about $6.25 a tonne in prices for Australian coal sales to Japan, along with reduced volume. Let us remind ourselves that coal is our major single export. We have expectations of a reduced Japanese demand for Australian iron ore as Japanese steel output is forecast to fall from 104 million tonnes this year to as low as 80 million tonnes after 1990.

We have uncertainty over prospects for Australian oil exports and imports following the turmoil in the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries after the sacking of Sheikh Yamani. We have a cave-in by Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. to an upsurge in industrial unrest at its steelworks over superannuation. We have had the submission by Borg-Warner to demands for an immoral and improper payment to settle a strike, which ended 3,000 stand downs caused by bully-boy union tactics. We have had a sharp rise in housing interest rates which underlines the continuing impact on the economy of the Government's policy of high interest rates, designed to hold up the Australian dollar. Let us recognise that the high level of interest rates in Australia, which fluctuate every now and again-for example, last week they were down a bit-are deliberate government policy. They are not by accident; they have not magically happened. They are a deliberate exercise of government policy to protect the Australian dollar. Let there be no suggestion to the contrary.

We have also the lowest motor vehicle registration figures for nine years following the further 9.6 per cent seasonally adjusted drop in September. We have the prospect of patchy local demand for steel, with BHP forecasting an 8 per cent fall in 1986-87 in the internal demand for steel due to sluggish private fixed investment, weak commodity prices and uncertain economic prospects. On top of all that, we have the failure of the Government's review of its fringe benefits tax to do more than trim about 10 per cent off the edges in unintended consequences, leaving the tax about 90 per cent unchanged. Honourable senators should remember that this is a tax on business, a tax on the people who are supposed to be making the investments that are needed to get Australia out of the mire. They should recognise that behind all this, secretly, in a speech to a Washington audience the Treasurer's senior economic adviser has admitted that there will be no internal economic growth this year. We have not heard that from the Treasurer yet. We have not heard it from the Prime Minister, who says that everything is wonderful and that everything will turn up next year. He urges us all to trust him. Why would anyone trust this man? We have not even been told in this Parliament that there will be no internal economic growth this year, yet the Treasurer's office is prepared to tell American investors. Apparently they are much more important than the people of Australia. The people of Australia can be kept in the dark about the fact that the Budget forecast of minimal economic growth is now wiped out to no economic growth.

There is something even more disturbing to me in the Prime Minister's approach. He has been reported-I understand that this is correct-as having told the Caucus that everything was very good indeed. According to the Sydney Morning Herald, he painted an optimistic picture of the future of the economy. He told Caucus that with a more stable dollar and unemployment figures which were not discouraging, there was reason for optimism and that the Government had been through the worst period. Why do we have a more stable dollar? If ever I have seen any self-delusion-I presume it is deliberate because Government members could not be so foolish as this-it is by this Government. Why on earth does the Government think the dollar is relatively strong at the moment? Is it because we have a great, outstanding, unbelievable future? Not according to the experts, including the experts overseas, who have just been visited by Mr Keating and members of his office.

The reality is that the only reason Australia is an attractive haven for foreign short term money at the moment is that the Government has put a floor under the Australian dollar. It has instructed the Reserve Bank to do so. The Reserve Bank buys dollars under US60c and has put the floor there. Everyone knows that it is there, so there is a guaranteed level below which the dollar cannot fall. Yet at the same time the Government is maintaining massive interest rates. Let me tell the Government this: There is no better haven for hot short term money in the world at the moment than Australia, not because Australia looks wonderful or the Australian economy is great. It is exactly the contrary; it is because this Government has placed a floor under the dollar and by massive interest rate policy it is providing an enormous guaranteed return to foreign investors in this country. There is no better game in the world for foreign investors to get into on a short term basis than Australia at the moment because there are no risks as long as the Government maintains the floor under the dollar. Also there are very high returns as long as the Government maintains its high interest rate policy.

This is where the fascinating bit comes in. In other words, the only risk a foreign investor has is if the Government changes its mind and its policy. What would encourage the Government to change its mind? Quaintly, if our foreign exchange and balance of payments figures started to improve-in other words, if we started to do well and there was good news about our balance of payments-the Government would not need to maintain the record high interest rates or the floor under the dollar. Therefore, good news for Australia would be bad news for the foreign investors because there would then be no need for the Government to maintain its record interest rate policy, which is slamming Australian homeowners, destroying the prospect of investment in Australia, and which is disastrous for our economic recovery, but which gets the Government out of a hole on foreign exchange. So clearly, every time there is bad news, which forces the Government to keep up interest rates, foreign investors are delighted. That is why we have had this positive response.

Every time a dreadful balance of payments figure comes out, why on earth do Government members think it is so wonderful? They seem to believe that it shows that the foreigners still have confidence in Australia and that the Government is still on the right track. Government members are deluding themselves and that is the most dangerous and damaging aspect because apparently they genuinely do not know. If they were deliberately wicked-there are suggestions that that could be so, but I doubt it; I think they really do not know-it would be a different matter. I think that Government members really do not know the motivations behind the people from overseas in putting their money in Australia. They do not realise that it is only because of the Government's policies, which are costing the Australian people so much, that foreign investors are putting their short term money in Australia. Government members do not know that good news, a good result, would be the last thing that those short term foreign investors want because in those circumstances the Government might be able to reduce its interest rates, thereby reducing the benefits that foreign investors would receive.
Let us hear what Salomon Brothers, the leading American broker in this area, has said about the Aussie dollar. It says that the Australian dollar's rise:
. . . appears to be related to the willingness of the Australian authorities to maintain a high interest rate policy for a longer period than financial markets had anticipated.
This is despite the fact that recent economic indicators suggest that the Australian economy may be slipping into a recession.

There we have the brokers in America saying that they recognise that our economy is slipping into a recession, that this Government does not know what it is doing, and that its policies are all wrong in terms of the future of the Australian people, but that those policies are not bad for anyone who has some money and wants to slip into Australia because it is the best game in town. That is because this Government is providing a guaranteed base for the dollar and record interest rates to attract foreign investment. If it is self-delusion which is encouraging the Government to take this kind of approach, where it seems to think that everything is all right and that everything will be wonderful next year, I must say that I am appalled at the incompetence of this Government, but not surprised. If, however, this is deliberate deception to prepare the ground for an early election in February or March, it is disgraceful, but nonetheless typical of the sort of economic management for political purposes that we have had from this Government. It is economic management based on political objectives which take no account of the long term future or benefit of this nation.

We have already seen this in the way in which the Government massively increased its spending in its first Budget here, adding $2.5 billion of its own new spending programs at a time when the rest of Australia recognised that this was a disastrous course to set out on. The fact that the Government started on that course immediately it came to office set the scene for disaster. It was told that by the Opposition at the time, but it pressed on regardless. Was that self-delusion at the time or was it deliberate deception again? The Prime Minister said that we had to create 300,000 jobs during his first term in office, no matter what the cost in the long term to the Australian economy, no matter how many of those jobs would ultimately be destroyed as the economy slumped into recession, facing enormous difficulties. We have seen for political purposes this Government increase its spending even in the current year. The current appropriations relate to spending that is increasing by 6.9 per cent in money terms and slightly increasing in real terms after taking account of inflation. The so-called enormous spending cuts which got such publicity, which have been touted throughout the nation as if somehow the Government has been respectable, are not cuts on what was actually spent last year at all. They are simply cuts from what the Government wanted to spend. They are simply cuts on what a continuation of the enormously increased programs that have taken place over the last three years would have meant in terms of spending. So the Government has not cut spending by one cent this year. It has gone on with its policies of record spending, record taxation, and of course, in this context, record deception of the people of Australia.

I want to deal very briefly with the issue of tax because, when there is record spending and the disasters in the balance of payments, which have been exacerbated by our extraordinarily and unnecessarily high levels of government spending, the other side of that equation is record taxes. Of course, one of the problems in the tax area relates to relations with trade unions. We must remember that the tax cut that is supposed to take place on 1 December is simply a trade-off, and no more than that, for the 2 per cent cut in indexation which took place earlier this year. It is simply a trade-off. It is a way to soften or wipe out the blow which was dressed up by this Government as a responsible and real reduction in benefits to employees as a result of the unfortunate decline in our fortunes internationally. In other words, because we were not earning enough overseas and had to devalue, the cost impact of that should be denied on wage earners. To offset the discounting, the wage earners would get a tax cut.

Of course, the consequence of that is that someone has to pay for that tax cut. Who is it? Of course, it is the business community in Australia, which is facing the fringe benefits tax and all those other taxes required to offset the revenue losses, as well as inflation; that is the other element to offset the revenue losses. So what do we get to pay for these tax cuts? We get a fringe benefits tax and a package of other taxes worth something like $800m. This belts the business community, the very people whose investment future is absolutely vital. A healthy investment future for those people is absolutely vital if we are to get out of our present trading mess. Yet, according to this Government, they are the people who are dispensable and who have to pay for the deal done with the union movement in order to keep the accord mark 2.

How realistic is that accord mark 2 anyway? We are seeing it change now through discussions about accord mark 3. The Government seems to have no other basic policy than to maintain these so-called accords which it claims have been absolutely essential to its success. If what this Government has had is success, for heaven's sake, can we really afford to have accords that bring this kind of success? The reality of the prospect of breakdown is very serious indeed. We can look at the industrial unrest around at the moment, at the nurses' problems. Throughout Australia there is a resurgence of industrial unrest. The figures brought out last month about industrial unrest in Australia are the worst for three years because at last there is a real testing of the strength and the reality of these so-called accords. We should take note of the fact that Moody's Investor Services Inc., which recently downgraded Australia from AAA to AA1--

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't that the first time it has ever happened?
—As Senator Messner says, that is the first time that we have ever been downgraded. One of the points that Moody's made was that any breakdown in the accord between the Government and the unions:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . would be a clear harbinger not only of higher inflation and lower industrial productivity, but of diminished international competitiveness and ultimately the need for greater borrowing to offset wider fiscal and current account gaps.

There is no doubt, as Moody's has indicated, that every optimistic comment you can get about Australia, apart from those from the Prime Minister which are clearly deceptive or incompetent, is conditional upon the unions being responsible, or the unions not pursuing the level of industrial unrest being pursued at present. Let us recognise that among the most disruptive of the unions at the moment is the Federated Storemen and Packers Union of Australia, Mr Crean's old union. He is the man who is apparently and allegedly in charge not only of the labour movement in Australia but also of this Government. Yet his union is the one causing so much industrial disruption.

I will revert to the issue of taxation. We have had an enormous increase in tax. After the tax cuts that take place next month, Australian taxpayers will still be paying far more than they did last year. They will certainly be paying far more than when this Government came to office, once the figures are adjusted for inflation. The people of Australia will remain far worse off, even after these tax arrangements, than they were when this Government came into power. Of course, the key point is that so is the business community worse off.

This brings to my attention the role of the Australian Taxation Office. We have seen the Commissioner of Taxation take a political role on two occasions in the last couple of months. As Mr Howard has said, this is totally improper. Clearly, what the Commissioner is doing is responding to some very effective attacks on the administration of the Tax Office, which has resulted in very large amounts of money not being collected in Australia. Of course, the response at the moment is to the report from the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure which revealed that in the last three years about $39m was unspent on computer equipment that should have gone into that Office to increase its ability to act effectively. In today's newspapers we have seen a report of a survey conducted by the research professor of tax law at the University of Melbourne, Mr Bernard Marks.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very good man too.

—As Senator Messner says, he is a good man. He notes that the Australian Taxation Office has effectively been making tax laws that are either inconsistent with legislation, against political intent or do not have the sanction of law. One article states:

SPEECH.PARA: It said tax laws were often drafted by parliamentary draftsmen acting upon the advice of the Taxation Office that differed from the announcement heralding the particular change.
The article continued:
In some cases tax reform legislation-
I must say that I am offended by the use of the word `reform'; often it is change, not necessarily reform-
which had been backdated contained measures which were not announced or even expected at the time of the reform announcement.
The article further states:
He said that in many cases ``it would appear that the real (tax) policy is made by the bureaucracy''.

That is the important point. There appears to have been a hidden agenda within the Tax Office, I suspect in order to cover up inadequacies in its operations. Let us look where this hidden agenda exists. Let us look, for example, at the prescribed payments tax. That was a proposal announced by the previous Government, and a sensible proposal it was. But, when this Government introduced that legislation, it did a lot more than introduce a prescribed payments tax. One of the items on the hidden agenda in that legislation was the capacity to force subcontractors to become employees. Not one line in the explanatory memorandum of the prescribed payments legislation, not one word in the second reading speech of the Treasurer, said anything about giving the Tax Office the capacity by statement to convert people from subcontractors to employees, with all of the implications that flow from that, including implications relating to the sort of compulsory unionism that is brought about by standover tactics within the building industry.

This sort of hidden agenda is intolerable and I suggest that the Tax Office stands condemned for sneaking in behind people's backs, with no reference having been made to it in a second reading speech or in an explanatory memorandum, the kind of thing which overturned the 1955 tilers High Court of Australia decision relating to who is a subcontractor and who is not. If this Government or this Tax Office wants to change the law fundamentally in an industry, it should come forward honestly and straightforwardly and do so. It is inevitable that whenever we have a government overspending, making excessive demands on people, we will get a Tax Office being put under this kind of pressure. The Tax Office is simply responding to the pressures put on it by a government whose appetite for money is insatiable because it insists on maintaining policies that are destructive of the Australian economy, which take far too big a proportion of its resources and which it has been established have damaged, I hope not irreparably, Australia's prospect of recovery. They have certainly damaged private investment in Australia, which now of course is shuddering to a halt. Yet we have the Prime Minister continuing to try to delude us.
Debate (on motion by Senator Grimes) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: NURSING HOMES AND HOSTELS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 12 November.

Senator Peter Baume-This might be a convenient time to seek some advice from you, Mr Chairman. It seems to me that we have before the Committee three sets of amendments. We have one set of Opposition amendments and two sets of Government amendments, many of them relating to the same matters and the same clauses. I notice that in at least one case alternatives have been offered by both the Government and the Opposition in relation to proposed amendments. I think that occurs particularly with Government amendment No. 2 on one sheet which seeks to amend clause 4. I am keen to have some orderly management of the amendments. I understand there is a fair amount of agreement between both sides of the Parliament on some of the amendments and certainly some agreement as to the purposes of the amendments. I would like your advice on how we should proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition appreciates that the process undertaken by the Government will be in two broad stages. The Government is proposing first to identify certain classes of people, or classes within classes of people, perhaps migrants of a particular ethnic background in a particular locality; and secondly, having done that, we understand that the Minister would then make a specific determination in relation to an application to grant 100 per cent funding for people within that class. The Opposition mentioned yesterday, during the second reading debate, that it was its belief that, in order to maintain the greatest possible amount of public confidence in the process being undertaken, the process should be at least theoretically disallowable by the Parliament at each stage. We indicated that this was particularly desirable because the question of 100 per cent capital funding was involved and this is a new concept explained by the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) during his second reading speech.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not argue as to the principle and as to the purposes which are being sought to be achieved, but we want to make sure that certain sections of the public do not get the impression that this power could or would be misused by any Minister of the day. I do not believe for one moment that Senator Grimes would misuse that power, but there will be Ministers following Senator Grimes so, as we suggested yesterday, we would like both steps of that process to be disallowable. The Minister indicated in his second reading speech that a number of decisions were to be moved to gazettal and were to be made disallowable as gazettal decisions. We have drawn up this amendment to try to bring the clause into line with the gazettal procedure the Government has laid down. We propose that it would be necessary for the Minister to lay before each House of the Parliament within five sitting days each certificate which would be issued under paragraph 9 (1) (b) and each determination under sub-section 3, they being the two steps of the process. Having been laid before the Parliament, the Parliament would then have the capacity to disallow them-we have suggested in the amendment within 20 sitting days, although I must say that that is entirely a matter on which I would hear argument-and, once that period had elapsed, if there was no disallowance the instrument should then come into effect.

With the Committee's indulgence, I indicate that I have read the Government's amendment which is being circulated as an alternative approach. This amendment does several things: First, it provides disallowance capacity only for part of that process, only for one of the two steps; secondly, it does it in a different way. What we have suggested is putting it in the form of a gazettal which would not have effect until the period for disallowance had finished. The Government has proposed that it be done by way of an instrument having effect like a regulation which would, in fact, start to have effect immediately and would continue to have effect unless and until it was subsequently disallowed. The theoretical disadvantage of that is that, if the Parliament were disposed to exercise its power to disallow under this clause, it might have the effect of finding an organisation which then said: `But we believed that we had received approval. You have now disallowed it and we have incurred a certain amount of activity and maybe some expense, and we think that is improper'.

On the other hand, as we said to the Minister yesterday in the chamber, and I say it again now, I find it very unlikely that people will be seeking to use this power. It would be there, as it were, as a reserve capacity if people felt particularly aggrieved by any decision. Because of that, it may be quite appropriate to use a regulation making power, as the Minister has suggested. Under those circumstances I will now formally move the amendment which we have circulated, but I do it on the basis that if the Minister makes certain assurances to me and indicates the advantages of his amendment, I may subsequently seek the permission of the Committee to withdraw my amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a certain amount of horse trading, in a proper sense, on this matter. Senator Peter Baume raises matters which have been raised many times in this place before and they are important. The capacity of the Parliament to ensure that Ministers do not act irresponsibly is an important right. It is also important to the level of anxiety amongst people involved in the nursing home area that we ensure that they believe that the system is impartial and that the decisions that are made concerning funding are non-political decisions in the party political sense. At the same time, this has to be balanced with sensible administrative processes. As Senator Peter Baume said, the capacity of the Government to provide 100 per cent funding for special groups is a new one. As he said, to introduce an amendment of the type that the Opposition introduced would bring the process to a halt until the 20 days that he suggested in his amendment were up, which would mean a period of uncertainty for the organisations involved.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government believes that, if it is going to proceed in this way, it should in fact have an instrument of regulation, such as a regulation whereby the time is 15 days, as it is with every other disallowance, which would preserve the capacity of the organisation at least to plan ahead in that time. I think that is important. As Senator Baume said, if we were to proceed down this path-it is a unique path; I will come to that in a minute-it is extremely unlikely that the Parliament would disallow such a proposal. I think it is extremely unlikely, even in the unlikely possibility of the Opposition coming to government, that any Minister would act in the irresponsible way that obviously some people out there think they might.

What I put to Senator Baume and the Opposition is that it is one thing to provide for parliamentary scrutiny of the foundations of decision making; For example, in this case deciding what classes of people-be they Aboriginals or people in an ethnic group or in another disadvantaged group-should be defined as financially disadvantaged and then become eligible for 100 per cent funding. That classification may even be a group in one area. For instance, I suppose one could say a particular ethnic group in a particular district could be classed as financially disadvantaged and therefore eligible for 100 per cent funding. Subsequently the Minister or the Department would make an administrative decision that organisation X in that area should be funded at 100 per cent to provide the service for that particular disadvantaged group. If we are going to introduce a situation whereby the capacity of the Parliament is to disallow that administrative decision, we are taking a step into a new area-we are not quite taking a step into the void, but we are taking a step into a new area.

Senator Baume puts the case, and I can understand that case, that what we are doing here in providing 100 per cent funding is a new step in this area; that there are other organisations which provide the same sort of service-namely, accommodation for the aged; that they may have some anxieties that in our capacity to fund special organisations at 100 per cent we are giving the Minister and the Government the power to give those organisations a considerable advantage over ordinary groups. As an example, we may have a religious group seeking funding for a nursing home. Under the normal circumstances-under the circumstances in this legislation-the decision to fund nursing homes is not disallowable by this Parliament, in fact by this House because it would be the Senate that would do so. Another religious group, another political group-I suppose that is the biggest worry-or another activist group of some kind may seek to run a nursing home for a particular disadvantaged group. They could get 100 per cent funding and that could be disallowed. We are setting up two classes of people. Senator Peter Baume's argument would undoubtedly be-who am I to argue with it?-that in providing 100 per cent funding for one group and 80 per cent funding for another we are setting up two classes of people.

If we accepted the amendments moved by Senator Baume we would add long delays to the action we would like to take to respond to the needs of financially disadvantaged and underserviced groups. Both the determination that that group is disadvantaged and the subsequent certification that a proposed facility be provided for that group would be disallowable at any time until 20 sitting days had passed. The amendment would mean that the certification was void. The problem is that the disadvantage to that group by preventing action being taken to respond to real needs until after that full disallowance period is reached can mean a considerable period. For instance, if I and the Government decided to fund a group in a couple of days time, 20 days time may take us well into the next session of Parliament-I suppose even into April. Therefore, if we are going to proceed down this track we would prefer to have the normal disallowance provisions so that valid planning decisions-not decisions to spend vast sums of money-can be made in that time. If parliamentary scrutiny is to be provided, we cannot see any reason for not having the traditional 15 days and having revocation taking effect only from the date of the disallowance.

I would prefer the disallowance to apply only to the determination of particular groups. I have had discussions with Senator Baume and I believe that this is both important legislation and an important principle. It will have the effect of lowering the level of anxiety of those organisations in the community which are a little disturbed by our capacity to fund organisations at 100 per cent and which may be disturbed that, at some future date, this capacity would be abused. I am circulating amendments which will have the effect of making both the certification and the determination disallowable under the normal 15 days. This would allow normal planning to go ahead, as is the situation with a regulation. Although this will be of some administrative nuisance to the public servants who have to administer the legislation, we believe the numbers of cases will not be many and that once the first formulation of how to do it is decided the others will follow fairly naturally, bearing in mind that I do not believe that, certainly in my time or in the time of anyone I know in this place, such a disallowance provision would be utilised.

I must say, though, that if we find that the sort of proposal I am putting forward, which is a modification of Senator Baume's proposal, creates administrative difficulties, I, or a future Minister in this area, will undoubtedly bring it back to Parliament. I point out that what we are doing is different from what is done in normal circumstances, but that does not mean that we should not do it, of course, and I have never let that stop me from doing anything in this place. I do not think the argument about administrative difficulties is strong enough to prevent us from doing this and accepting it. To ease the anxieties of those in the community who are concerned, I propose, and I think Senator Baume would agree, the amendment I am now circulating in substitution of his amendment, which is a more acceptable and more practical one, with the proviso that, if we do have difficulties, those difficulties will have to be corrected at a later date.

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Page 5, clause 8, proposed new sub-section 39aa (5), at the end of the sub-section, add:
``, unless the Minister considers that it is necessary to do so in order to meet the need for nursing home beds in a region''.

This amendment seeks to add certain words to the end of proposed new sub-section 39aa (5). The matter I raised in the second reading debate relates to our concern that, with altering conditions-they can be quite rapid in many regions in Australia-the need may emerge for extra nursing home beds and the Minister may be left with only a limited capacity to act in respect of those needs.

It was put to us by industry sources that we should seek to establish an independent tribunal and that the Minister should have the capacity to vary the numbers in respect of the findings of such an independent body. We are not attracted to the idea of an independent body. We think, in the end, it is an executive decision for the Minister, say Senator Grimes, to make. But we think that, where there has been an influx, say, of elderly people into an area where previously there were no elderly people, where no allocation has been made for the provision of nursing home beds, or where the demography has changed quite rapidly, there should be a capacity for the Minister to make such a decision.

I mentioned yesterday areas of my city of Sydney where certain ethnic groups have moved into particular suburbs and locations, often very rapidly. The demography is changing because aged people are congregating, and I draw attention to the retirement areas on the central and north coast of New South Wales. Where those kinds of circumstances exist we believe that the Minister should have a residual discretion to vary the determination to meet particular needs in a town or a region. The words we propose to add to clause 8 would leave with the Minister such a residual capacity. I believe that Senator Grimes would exercise that power, for example, only if he were convinced that an area had legitimately been overlooked or that its needs had changed and he wanted to give it an extra allocation of nursing home beds. We are simply seeking to give the Minister that extra capacity and extra discretion. I commend the amendment to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would prefer not to accept this amendment to the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill 1986-I think for very good and valid reasons. As Senator Peter Baume said, this matter caused some anxiety in some sections of the nursing home industry which apparently wanted an independent tribunal. I pointed out to them that I do, and future Ministers will, get independent advice from the advisory councils, and I think it is important. I also think it is important that the functions of government, as much as possible, remain with government and are not handed over to independent tribunals of this type, which are certainly not omniscient. I would have thought the experiences of Ministers on both sides of the chamber in recent years would suggest that this is not a sensible proposal. Therefore, I am glad that the Opposition has not agreed with that.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment would mean that the bed numbers specified in a Commonwealth of Australia Gazette notice-I remind honourable senators that we have to gazette the numbers from time to time-were not firm. I think this would create some difficulties. I can understand Senator Peter Baume's expressed concern that the new arrangements would not permit the Minister to allocate beds to areas of atypical need or where the need changes from time to time, but that is simply not the case. It is just not true. The basis of the amendment that has been moved by the Opposition is that the Minister and the Government should have the capacity under the legislation to respond flexibly to the real needs which may be identified in relation to all those things of which Senator Peter Baume spoke, such as movements of ethnic groups. I remind the honourable senator that the number of beds for ethnic people is determined on a State-wide basis, and another determination specifies where they should be located.

The Bill provides the Minister with this flexibility. While the ceiling on bed numbers within States and regions and for special groups is fixed by the Gazette notices that are in force from time to time, new gazettals can and will be made as needed. Under the legislation the Minister would have the capacity to respond to urgent needs, which may not have been apparent when bed distributions were being planned at the start of the financial year, by issuing a revised gazettal notice. In other words, I will be able to gazette new figures.

I think this course is preferable to the amendment moved by the Opposition in that the act of gazettal makes public the Government's actions and the Minister's actions in a particular area. I will gazette it; it will be made public; people can see what is happening and can argue about it if they like. Under the Opposition's amendment the Minister can depart from the gazetted planning figures without even notifying the Parliament, without notifying anybody. I do not think that is desirable. I think it is important that what we are doing in an area is made public so that people can see what is going on. There is an analogy with the previous concerns of the Opposition spokesman.

What we have done in this legislation in this area is preferable to the Opposition's proposal. We have allowed the Minister the capacity to respond to atypical need but in a public and an accountable way, which would not occur if the Minister could do it all at will and, if the amendment were carried, without anyone knowing that he had done it. SPEECH.PARA: (6) Page 9, clause 13, proposed new sub-section 40AD (1ad), leave out `or otherwise'.
(7) Page 10, clause 13, proposed new sub-section 40ad (1ad), leave out `or otherwise'.

In my speech in the second reading debate, I drew attention to the use of the words `or otherwise' in two places in the Bill. I remind the Committee of the problem. The clause provides that the Minister may, at any time, take certain action on application in writing by the proprietor of a nursing home `or otherwise'. That means he can just take the action. We might as well leave out the words `on application . . . by the owner of a nursing home'. It means that the Minister can take the action at any time at all.

It seems to the Opposition that certainly in the case of private participating nursing homes we are talking about something that might be the private property of a person or group or corporation, which may represent the investment of people's life savings, the only capital they have. If it were decided that the Minister should take certain action, which in this case might be to reclassify or redesignate certain beds within a nursing home in accordance with the provisions that we have been discussing in relation to this Bill, the Minister should do it only if it were something to which at least the owner of the nursing home was party. We are attracted to the words `may, at any time, on application in writing by the proprietor of a nursing home' take certain action because, in that case, the Minister would be responding to a request from the owner of the facility. The words `or otherwise' really make a mockery of that. It means that it is not a question of the person applying in writing; it could be done in any sense.

I understand that it was not intended that the words should have that kind of effect and that the Minister faces some administrative complications. The words appear in proposed new sub-sections 1ab and 1ad. Certainly the Opposition has some sympathy with the Minister and officers in relation to the administrative problems that they face, but our duty really is to look at the legislation as it is presented, read the words, work out what they mean or might mean and propose amendments on that basis. We believe the words `or otherwise' should be deleted. We invite the Minister to try to convince us why they should not be deleted and whether any other course of action might be taken to overcome the problem which I have raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Peter Baume for his invitation. This is about the third time I have taken it up. This matter causes nightmares for Ministers and shadow Ministers. I am very grateful that I am not a Minister in the Senate with former Senator James Cavanagh sitting opposite me in these circumstances-not that I am putting down the capacity of Senator Peter Baume. The clauses that he refers to relate to the Minister's ability to vary or revoke a determination that a specified number of beds in a nursing home are approved in relation to special needs groups, groups to which we have referred in other debate in this place. Such a determination can be made at three stages of the approval process: When the approval in principle is given; when the final approval is given as a home comes on stream; and when a home is varied, such as when an extension is completed. The need for the words `or otherwise' arises from the counting provisions that are in clause 8, particularly proposed new sub-sections 39aa (7), (9), (10), (11) and (12).

SPEECH.PARA: These provisions define the number of beds to be counted as special needs beds. In order to avoid double counting under these provisions it is necessary, administratively, to be able, for instance, to revoke a determination made at the approval in principle stage and to make a new corresponding one under the appropriate section of the Act when the home receives that final approval. The effect of double counting would be to inflate the numbers of beds attributed to a State and, in fact, to frustrate the Government's capacity rationally to plan new provisions. In the absence of the capacity provided by the words `or otherwise' there would be a considerable additional administrative imposition on proprietors seeking to wend their way through what is in fact-although it is a bit better-an already complex approval procedure. There is a risk that a proprietor, I suppose, could even seek to frustrate the administration under the legislation by declining to submit an application that would ensure double counting was avoided. So we are in fact concerned not only about the administrative capacity of the Department to act sensibly but also not to put an excessive burden on proprietors of nursing homes.

I can understand very well the Opposition's and Senator Peter Baume's concern that the words `or otherwise' may inadvertently provide the Minister with the capacity to force a proprietor to provide a certain number of special needs beds against his will. My first comment on that is that it would be an extraordinarily silly Minister who did attempt to inflict on a nursing home proprietor a group such as a migrant group-or any group-that he or she was unwilling to care for. That would not be in the interests of the proprietor or the group concerned. Secondly, it would be quite unjust, as Senator Baume has said.

There are certain safeguards in the legislation, however, to curb misuse of this power, apart from those common sense ones. Clause 13 (b) of the Bill, which appears on page 10, demonstrates the intention that the Minister shall not make a determination in the latter stages of the approval process which is inconsistent with an undertaking given at the approval in principle stage. Proposed new sub-section 39aa (5) in clause 8 prevents the variation or revocation of special needs determinations where this would be inconsistent with the gazetted allocations. There are avenues of review of decisions by the Federal Court of Australia under the Administrative Decisions Judicial Review Act. In addition, in the event of a Minister varying a condition and thus causing a proprietor to be in breach of his conditions, any action to revoke his approval on that ground would be subject to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The words `or otherwise' allow the Minister under proposed new sub-section 40ad (1ab) to make nursing homes subject to the condition that the operations of the home are to be carried out in a manner consistent with the special purposes of the home. In this case the power is necessary for two reasons: To allow consistent administrative steps to be taken following any action under the previously discussed provisions; and to enable a special purpose to be specified in relation to existing nursing homes where there are special needs beds, such as Montefiore homes in Melbourne, to regularise an existing situation.

Having said all that, and bearing in mind that there are all those curbs and that it would be a very silly Minister indeed who acted in the way that undoubtedly some nursing home proprietors may consider he or she would act, I accept that it would be better if the legislation were written in another way to achieve the same effect and to get rid of the words `or otherwise'. But neither my departmental advisers nor the Parliamentary Counsel, or anyone else that we have been able to talk to, including Senator Baume, has found a way yet. I believe that to take out those words would in fact create administrative difficulties beyond the benefit that the leaving of those words in at the moment would provide. I am certainly willing to guarantee-and certainly will-that between now and the autumn session, when we will have statute law amendments coming up, and probably there will also be further legislation in this area, we will seek and find an alternative way of wording this legislation. I can assure Senator Baume that in the meantime I will not be abusing those words `or otherwise'. I think that frequently in this place we have to balance administrative good sense with absolute guarantees that nothing nasty will happen in the woodshed. In these circumstances I urge the Opposition to accept that guarantee and not disturb the legislation in this way, because the unintended consequences of such disturbance of the legislation would be worse than the unintended consequences possible as the legislation is now.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1986-87[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 1) 1986-87APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 2) 1986-87]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1986-87 and related Appropriation Bills give effect to the Hawke Government's August Budget, brought down by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). In debating these Bills, it behoves me to make some remarks about that Budget. That Budget succeeded wildly beyond the dreams of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), the former failed Treasurer of the Fraser Administration, who predicted that the Budget deficit would be about $4 billion; of course, the deficit came in at $3.5 billion, and Mr Howard was wrong again.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the key features of the Budget is that it is a Budget in which there is zero growth in outlays. In fact, Commonwealth expenditure, in real terms, has not increased. It is a Budget designed in those terms because there is a recognition by the Government that the economic policies that we had been pursuing had led to expansionary growth in the economy to the extent that it was beginning to overheat and that we were sucking in imports at a great rate, and since the devaluation had had an effect, the price of those imports was pushing up the rate of inflation, and there was a need to ease back a little. The Budget has that effect, and we are now looking forward to a Budget for recovery and one which, once we adjust to the massive alteration in the terms of trade that was suffered earlier this year by Australia, should be a budget for growth as well.

In recognising that the Budget is appropriate economically, it should also be mentioned that it contains some elements of which some of us on the Government benches did not approve. One of which I did not approve was the sale of Australian uranium to France. However, as part of an overall economic package, it cannot be said that the Government has failed the test of confronting the difficulties of what are harsh economic times. It has cut government expenditure back to zero growth. In pursuance of the Government's other two major economic objectives-the final conclusion of its tax reform initiative, and the final landing of an agreement with the Australian Council of Trade Unions for an accord mark 3 on wages-we should be expecting that, over the early months of next year and into next year proper, there will be increasing growth in the economy, and we shall be replacing our imports with Australian manufactured goods and competing more effectively on the world market with our exports.

I want to comment on a couple of aspects of the tax package reforms because, although this is a subject that is spoken about much and a subject on which much heat is generated, very little light seems to have been brought to the debate. The tax package as a whole will raise, according to an estimate by the Treasurer, $1.5 billion, but the Government, in providing tax cuts to the vast majority of Australians, will be outlaying $4.5 billion in cuts to marginal tax rates, which will benefit ordinary wage and salary earners, in December of this year and in July of next year. Indeed, when the cycle of tax cuts, coming, as they will, seven months apart, is complete, the top marginal rate paid by higher wage earners will be reduced from 60c in the dollar to 49c, and that is a remarkable tax reform. No reform of commensurate character or size has been undertaken by any previous conservative government, and although we are yet to see the details of the Howard tax package-and we probably will not see them until the last minute, so that the electorate will have an inappropriate time span on which to judge the real meaning of what promises to be an opportunistic tax hand-out by the Opposition-the real record of this Government will have been to achieve significant reform in taxes paid by ordinary men and women in the street. They will have had the benefit of that.

The Treasurer, two weeks ago, announced further revisions to the fringe benefits tax, as the Parliament is aware. Those revisions have reduced by $75m the revenue yield to the Commonwealth from the fringe benefits tax. That $75m has been forgone in order to simplify the tax, but its main principles have been kept intact so that salary earners and business entrepreneurs who were escaping taxation by replacing wages or salaries with benefits in kind will be taxed, and the total value of taxes raised by the fringe benefits tax is now estimated to be, in a full year, about $700m.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you are still catching remote area people, aren't you?

—I am glad that the honourable senator has raised that question because that is the next subject to which I was about to turn. Consistent with my earlier comment that, on the subject of remote area benefits, more heat was being generated than light, let me talk about the effect of the changes on people living in remote areas-because it is quite significant. Before going into some detail about the area with which I am most familiar, the iron ore province of the Pilbara in my State of Western Australia, let me say that recently I had the benefit of discussing with senior executives of Mount Isa Mines, from Queensland, their objections to the fringe benefits tax in remote localities. They produced for me a chart showing what the total tax outgoings for Mount Isa Mines was in Queensland. From memory, that chart showed that Mount Isa Mines paid, all up, $114m in taxes. Five per cent of what it paid in taxes it paid to the Commonwealth; the balance, apart from about one per cent, it paid to the State of Queensland. Of the balance, $87m that it paid to the State of Queensland was paid, by that company's estimation, in excessive freight rates to the Queensland Government. In fact, the Queensland Government, which boasted in the recent election campaign that it did not apply a number of State taxes, squeezes mining developments in that State, and in the case of Mount Isa Mines-a significant mining developer in coal and other minerals-it does so to the tune of $87m in excess of the real cost of shipping its ore to the loading ports. That $87m is to be compared to a total tax bill of $114m. If the Opposition in this place wants to argue that the cost of properly paying taxes on fringe benefits is impeding the development of the minerals industry, if it is to have any credit it should explain before doing so why its partner in coalition, the National Party in Queensland, imposes an $87m cost-out of $114m-on the development of mining operations in that State.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the Pilbara. I have a close understanding of the tax arrangements for remote localities in that region. Indeed, the review brought about a further change in the fringe benefits tax to be paid by operators in remote areas of Australia, and the total sum to be gathered is reduced by $20m. Let me take the iron ore industry.
