When the Government first announced what the tax changes were to be but before the legislation was tabled, the mining companies in Western Australia combined to produce a report under the auspices of the respected accountancy and auditing company Coopers and Lybrand which, again from memory, showed that the total cost of fringe benefits tax on remote locality operations would be of the order of about $28m. After that impact was considered and after the Government announced its legislation, we believe that the total cost would have been reduced to $17m. Coopers and Lybrand conducted another study which showed that the cost would have been $28.3m on an aggregation of the expenses of all the four individual companies. Although since the announcement there has not been a release of the latest study by that same auditor of the likely effect, it is estimated by reliable sources that the reduction has been another $10m, so the real cost is about $18m. When one considers the value of the fall in the exchange rate of 40 per cent in the mining industry in terms of a windfall gain to that industry, and a number of other measures conducted by this Government, then in my view in the circumstances that is not an unreasonable cost. So despite the generation of argument, I think that in recognising the need for the Commonwealth to close off that loophole in fringe benefits tax, a proper and most reasonable outcome has been achieved.

I turn to the next major and most important economic event in Australia. I refer to the reaching of an agreement with wage and salary earners, and hopefully approval by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, for a significantly new discounting of wages and its achievement in the context of an agreement entitled by media commentators `Accord Mark III', with the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The first thing to be said is that Australian wage and salary earners have been among the most eminent of all Australians who have sacrificed their wages position in real terms for the benefit of this nation and the good of the economy. I have before me a chart which I am indebted to Dr Don Stammer of Bain and Company for producing. The chart appears in a speech he delivered to the Confederation of Australian Industry in August entitled `The Outlook for the Australian Economy'. The chart he reproduces is sourced as being the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development main economic indicators and is headed `Real Wages'.

The chart shows that in the period 1983-85 real wages in key economies of the world such as Japan rose by 6.1 per cent. In Germany real wages for the same period rose by 4.1 per cent. In France they went up by 3.7 per cent. In the United Kingdom for the same period, under the Thatcher Government, they leapt by 12.7 per cent, and in Holland by 0.4 per cent. There are only three economies in which they fell. The most dramatic fall was in New Zealand; in Canada they fell by 1.4 per cent and in the United States they fell by 0.6 per cent. In Australia real wages went down by 6.5 per cent. That happened because unions had practised wage restraint through the terms of the accord with this Government and forwent wage increases, realising that tax cuts would be forthcoming and that they would be rewarded through the social wage for that restraint. The net reduction in real terms on employers in this period has been 6.5 per cent. This has been a period in which record profits have been generated across a wide spectrum of the Australian private sector. At a time in which there are still many calls for restraint, it is vitally important that it be understood that the restraint that has been borne in the community has been borne by wage and salary earners, and mostly by low and middle order wage and salary earners. It is to them that this nation owes a huge debt of gratitude as they organise themselves to come to grips with the economic crisis that confronts Australia.

In the context of that position the Australian Council of Trade Unions last week adopted at a national conference of unions an in-principle agreement to apply to the Arbitration Commission next year for a two-tiered wage system. It is interesting to see that almost hot on the heels of the agreement by the union movement again to practise responsible wage adjustment in recognition of the economic circumstances, it has been heavily criticised. The Australian Federation of Employers, led by the doyen of the New Right Mr Andrew Hay, is reported in this morning's Australian Financial Review as saying that his organisation will apply to the Commission further to deregulate wages. This is in the context of record profits in the private sector, but he believes that wages should be further deregulated. The Confederation of Australian Industry and the Business Council should at least be praised by the Government for giving some broad approval to the two-tiered system for which the ACTU has announced support, thus giving life to the possibility of a tripartite accord, in which all the social partners work for the Australian Government to confront the economic problems of the nation.

I note that Mr Andrew Hay is not the only doyen of the New Right, or the only New Right activist, who wants wages to be cut to nothing and living standards to fall further without Mr Hay or the others practising any restraint at all. This morning's newspapers also carried reports of an address by Mr John Spalvins last night saying that the new two-tiered wages proposal should be thrown out because it would lead to a wages break-out. One wonders what Mr Spalvins would think if the full wages policy of the Liberal Party were to be adopted and market forces were to apply. Mr Spalvins would recognise at least that under the two-tiered system there is considerable containment of what wage increases might be and what the outcomes will achieve. But under a totally deregulated market, although there would be massive and graphic exploitation, particularly of young workers, female workers or workers in areas of the economy in which there is no bargaining power at all, those at key points of the economic process and of the industrial economy would be able to explode their wages to a much higher level than is comfortable. However, as I have said, it is to the ACTU that this nation owes a debt of gratitude in that it has been able to accommodate to the changes in the macroeconomic circumstances. I trust that the Commission will adopt the proposal and that at the end of 1987 we will see a wages outcome that is compatible with the economic strategy of this Government, but also compatible with the living and employment conditions of ordinary wage and salary earners, too, as tax cuts and social wage considerations help to compensate for real wage reductions.

I now turn to the question of the iron ore industry in Western Australia as a leading export industry-an industry that offers up to Australians the possibility of contrasting the two styles of the political, economic and industrial relations approach. I refer to the consensual style, as it has been labelled by the Hawke Government, the approach of getting together around a table all the major players in an industry and sorting our a way in which that industry can be more competitive, or the New Right confrontationist approach as practised at Robe River by Charles Copeman through Peko-Wallsend Ltd, the majority shareholder in Robe River Iron Ore Associates in Western Australia.

It is interesting to note that the lockout which Peko imposed on the Robe River employees, which also had a detrimental effect on the local community and small business people in that area as earnings were cut, cost on responsible estimates at least $9m to Robe River. When one considers the Western Australian Industrial Commission's judgment as to fault and the awarding of compensation in excess of $1m to the workers who were locked out, one realises that Peko shareholders have taken a profits plunge at least of the order of $10m. That was done for no extra advantage in terms of trading with our major clients overseas. Indeed, the reported antics of Mr Copeman in slamming down a telephone when speaking to a senior Japanese steel industry executive are not only offensive to the Japanese, but are also typical of the arrogance that the New Right has displayed in Australian politics. When a responsible company such as the Nissan Motor Co. says of the Besco Batteries dispute that the Peko company is behaving unethically, one has to question whether our major trading partner regards this manifestation of ultra-rightism in the Australian political, economic and industrial landscape as something to be encouraged at all.

On the other hand if one looks at the other three major iron ore miners in the Pilbara region of Western Australia and the way in which they have worked with both the Western Australian and Federal governments through the West Australian Iron Ore Industry Consultative Council, one sees a vastly different picture emerge by contrast. Let me go back to 1983 before the Consultative Council was established. In that calendar year 102,000 man days were lost in industrial disputes in the Pilbara region. In the first calendar year of the operation of the Consultative Council, that level of industrial disputation had fallen to 55,000 man days. Last calendar year it dropped even further to 26,000 man days and this year, before the madness of Robe River broke out, the results were on track to a similar outcome. That has been achieved simply because a degree of understanding has descended upon the area about the market problems that are faced by workers and companies in that region and there has been a realisation through the consensual or `social partners' approach of the Hawke Government, that by pulling together and achieving a better market share and better competitive performance in that industry, there are more spoils to go around for all involved.

Certainly for workers in a commodity based industry that is looking at a world market flooded with iron ore there is the consideration that not only can they maintain their own living standards if their industry becomes more competitive-and consistent with that they can improve them as well-but, fundamentally, they will obtain job security by being better competitors. For the shareholders in the mining companies there is the recognition that if there is to be a dividend payable on their shares, there must be a better competitive performance. For governments, which extract royalties from the performance of those industries, there is a self-interest advantage as well. When all those factors are put together, there is no reason why the authoritarian arrogance and dictatorial and confrontationist approach so typical of the Fraser years that we have come to see at Robe River should be continued. The results under a more co-operative approach, as I have indicated in the figures of man days lost, speak for themselves.

If it were a tale that related only to industrial disputes, it would be impressive, but it does not stop there. If one looks at productivity per labour unit employed, one sees that in the 1983-84 financial year, 7,200 tonnes were shipped per labour unit employed in the Pilbara region. In the 1984-85 financial year, under the co-operative approach of the Western Australian Iron Ore Industry Consultative Council, that level had skyrocketed to 11,200 tonnes per unit of labour employed. That is a graphic comparison to the $10m lost to the Peko operation and it has been achieved by using the central philosophy of this Government and not the confrontationist philosophy of the previous Government which is now espoused by the New Right.

To say all that is not to say that there is not a highly competitive world market in iron ore. Indeed, in today's Australian Financial Review it is reported that Japanese steel makers have posted a deficit of 180 billion yen. That says a bit about the processes used in Japanese steel making these days. While our share of the Japanese iron ore market has declined, on the latest figures it is pleasing to see that the total tonnage exported by the West Australian iron ore industry as a whole increased in 1985 over 1984 and stood at a higher figure than in 1983, 1982 or 1981. That increase was both in tonnes and in the Australian dollar value. That industry has been successful in diversifying its markets away from being involved almost exclusively in the Japanese market to the emergent markets of the People's Republic of China, the Republic of South Korea, Taiwan and to markets in Europe as well. We can compete with the world's leading suppliers, such as Brazil, and still sell iron ore to European markets where the Brazilians enjoy about a $5 per tonne cost advantage over Australia.

Bearing in mind that these Bills are related to the Budget, let me conclude my speech by dealing with what I think is the most fundamental comparison that this Government can make between its performance and those of its predecessors and its would-be replacement. We on the Labor side of the House are concerned not only with growth, personal liberties and freedoms, but also with the production of an equitable outcome for ordinary Australians in our society. Let us look at education expenditures under the Labor Government. From 1975-76 to 1982-83-the Fraser years-education expenditure rose by 1.6 per cent in real terms. From 1982-83 to 1985-86-under us-education expenditure went up by 8.4 per cent. In the Fraser period government outlays on health fell by 22.4 per cent in real terms. Under us, they went up by 50.7 per cent. Between 1975-76 and 1982-83 social security and welfare payments rose by 11.8 per cent in real terms. In many fewer years-that is, from 1982-83 to 1985-86-such payments rose by 10.3 per cent. In housing, which is a key right of ordinary Australians, from 1975-76 to 1982-83 expenditure fell by 35.8 per cent in real terms, while under us in a shorter period it rose by 63.5 per cent. If one looks at the distribution of income in Australia one sees that those at the lower end of the income scale have benefited more under a Labor government. Those living in poverty and those unable to make ends meet have been better attended to and their needs have been more adequately addressed under a Labor government than they were under a Liberal government. The other central achievement in the three-year period-and this Budget signifies that latest major economic statement by this Government-600,000 new jobs have been created as well. On the basis of those achievements, on the basis of the achievements in industrial relationships and on the basis of the settings for the macroeconomy that this Budget has put down, I think it is entirely right for the commentators and pundits to speculate that the Australian economy will come right towards the end of next year if nobody panics and everyone works together under the Government's guidelines. Then we will be able to share the abundancy that that will produce more equitably among ordinary Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the debate on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1986-87 and cognate Bills, I want to speak mainly on matters relating to the Department of Resources and Energy. With every day that goes by we can foresee with a good deal of accuracy a steady drop in our self-sufficiency in oil production. That point was made by a member of the Opposition in the other place quite recently. We have plenty of coal, and more economical and cleaner ways of using coal are being researched. Nevertheless, coal is a finite and non-renewable resource. Every generation of human beings in the future is likely to put a high value on the hydrocarbons because of the enormous range of useful manufactured products they can provide. I stress that that is what their proper function ought now to be seen as, rather than as a fuel to be burned. If we simply go on burning them up, for the most part without any regard even to efficient burning, we can expect our descendants to look back on us with horror as the generation of barbarians who massively destroyed irreplaceable human assets without much regard for the needs of the future.

SPEECH.PARA: However, it is reassuring to see that the Federal Government is now making some gestures in the direction of alternative and permanently renewable energy resources. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation has programs to increase the efficiency of photovoltaic conversion of light into electricity and into the storage of solar energy. These two programs are quite large, with spending of over $2m. Grants under the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council programs include several in the solar energy field, including solar ponds, and one to Murdoch University to assist wind power potential. We need to go much further with these things but at least now there seems to be some recognition within the Government of the need to plan for the future, and some understanding that the time may well come when we do not have oil of our own and when we do not have access to cheap oil. Even today's oil price may seem cheap compared with what it might be in 10 or 15 years time.

I note a recent Press release from the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) stating the Government's view of the changed nature of the Atomic Energy Commission to become the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation, which the Australian Democrats applaud. We just want to see that Bill come forward. Let us get it through the Senate and get this good new era started. In the Committee stage of this debate I will more properly raise matters of detail in that area.

I want to mention briefly the case for nuclear power as it now stands, for a variety of reasons. The first is that it is still being freely canvassed as the only reliable energy source for a future world, although I feel that increasingly smaller numbers of people are taking that position. The second is the regrettable fact that the Australian Labor Government persists in touting for the nuclear industry, encouraging the sale of our uranium even to such countries as France while France continues with impunity its nuclear tests in the Pacific.

Nuclear power is dangerous and uneconomic and is a continuing cause of deep divisions in virtually every community. The moment of truth for the nuclear industry was the Chernobyl reactor tragedy on 26 April this year. At this stage it is good to look at responsible views of the consequences of the Chernobyl accident. I will quote one of them which I think is sufficiently appalling to demand attention, and certainly to warrant repetition. It states:

. . . the available data suggests that the number of excess cancer deaths arising from radiation from the accident might be some 10,000 or so. Of these, a few hundred may occur in the immediate evacuation zone, about 5000 elsewhere in the USSR, some 3000-5000 in Eastern Bloc countries other than the USSR, and about 1000 elsewhere in Europe.

The number of excess cancer deaths arising from ingestion of radionuclides (notably caesium-137) through the food chain cannot be determined accurately from the data at this stage, but indications are that the number of these deaths would be comparable to those arising from external radiation effects.

That suggests another 10,000 deaths. These figures do not come from an anti-nuclear group. The quote is taken verbatim from the report of 19 September of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission. I take it that it can be regarded as conservative rather than otherwise. We are talking about 20,000 agonising and protracted slow deaths from a single accident. As nuclear plants age, even under the most stable social conditions imaginable, such accidents must happen again. No technology is perfect. Human beings err. These are constant, known facts in human society. Unfortunately, from them more Chernobyls, more massive tragedies, can be predicted with utter inevitability. Such accidents will take a very heavy toll on life and cause enormous quantities of illness-long term illnesses such as cancer-because so many of the world's nuclear reactors are located in areas of high population density.

It is interesting in this context to get the contribution of nuclear power into a reliable perspective. According to an excellent energy brief published by the Economist on 24 May this year, nuclear power delivers only 2 to 3 per cent of total world energy to the end user. For instance, hydroelectricity, according to the same source, still provides 70 per cent more power than does nuclear energy. So it is a fact that the world could turn its back completely on nuclear energy without much difficulty. Efficient conservation measures alone could fill that gap. That is beyond doubt.

The whole nuclear power situation is distorted by the fact that a few countries are very heavily committed to nuclear generation. One such country is France, with more than 60 per cent of its electricity coming from nuclear energy, and Belgium, with more than 50 per cent. The case of Belgium is rather interesting. While in that country earlier this year, I was intrigued to see-I believe it is the only country in the world in this category-that it is able to street light all of its major highways throughout the night from border to border. Indeed, people who fly over Belgium recognise it by the long strings of lights blazing right through the night. This massive road lighting is scarcely necessary. It is certainly not an economic use of electric power. It is made possible only because of the huge amount of nuclear electricity generated in Belgium which has to be used up one way or another. That is so typical of the nuclear industry. It creates vast quantities of power, irrespective of whether the consumption requirement is there. Of course, this applies very much to smaller countries and to the Third World. After France and Belgium, the nuclear contribution falls off quite rapidly. For instance, Japan generates 20 per cent of its electricity that way and Britain and the United States of America around 15 per cent.

One of the unfortunate things about the world-history should teach us this if nothing else-is that there is no guarantee against war. There has always been war in human society, although perhaps all of us in this place regret that deeply. Somehow or other wars continue to break out. This is especially the case in the world at present where the causes of and reasons for war are becoming exacerbated as time goes on. It ought to be axiomatic that the nations who rely heavily on nuclear power have placed themselves in a very dangerous position. An atomic power plant is obviously an attractive target for anyone wanting to knock out an enemy completely because such an attack would create major areas of radioactivity. Indeed, reliance on nuclear power, to the extent that, say, France or Belgium have become reliant, must make it almost impossible for nations to do other than lose any war in which they might become involved in the future. Again, it is axiomatic that a mere threat of attack on the reactors of France or Belgium from any enemy would virtually guarantee the surrender of those countries immediately, purely on that positive threat. Their only alternative to surrender would be total destruction of their society and the death of virtually all of their people.

Faced with that problem, I suggest that countries that use nuclear power extensively have made themselves hostages to fortune. I am sure that strategists in other countries that do not have nuclear power, and the people who may want to attack those countries, have noted this and that it is a very big factor in the future. It is naive to think that this would not happen. The bombing of Hiroshima, the blitz on London and Coventry and the fire bombing of Dresden make it plain enough that any measure is considered justified to gain a victory. That in itself is a compelling reason why the world must abandon nuclear power as fast as possible and turn to alternatives. It is also a compelling reason to believe that all of those who contribute to nuclear power, to its continuation in the world, or who assist it in any way, are culpable to the extent that they ought to recognise those facts.

The second reason, other than that strategic one, is economic. A major world problem is the appalling poverty of so much of the Third World. This is due substantially to the fact that it does not have an industrial output anywhere near adequate to finance the development that it needs. This imbalance is not being corrected. As time goes on it becomes worse. As that rate of disproportion increases, it must bring war and terrorism to the world. It is not possible to expect people to starve to death quietly. They will not starve to death quietly; they will eventually organise themselves to the stage where they will fight wars against the more fortunate part of the world to get what that more fortunate part of the world has. Not to recognise this is to display an intolerable degree of naivete. It is in the world's interests, then, to redress this balance effectively and promptly. That ought to be a proper course of action for the world, including this country, because it is obviously the more fortunate countries of the world that must take the lead in that regard.

The Third World has to an interesting degree a major potential asset which could be used and which would be of benefit to the whole world-relatively large regions of desert with high temperatures and high sunshine rates. The Third World, then, is ideally suited for solar energy development and generation. This has long been recognised but the point is that the demand for power is in the cooler industrial regions. Solar energy, it is said, cannot be transported. Many people, who I suggest have not been doing enough reading recently, say that this is the end of the argument, but of course it is not. That assessment is not true. In fact technology does exist which would allow solar energy to be stored and transported, and intensive research work is going on into those processes in many parts of the world.

I had the opportunity earlier this year to visit Israel's Weizmann Institute of Science, one of the world's major research establishments and in my opinion one of the most remarkable centres of learning on the planet. I was interested to learn that one of the main uses to which a $10m solar furnace, now under construction and due to be completed by next year, will be put is the separation of substances into their constituent gases through the use of solar heat. This process, thermochemical dissociation, is regarded as very promising for the very reasons I have stated, and indeed the scientists I discussed it with said it was very interesting that I was the first politician they knew of who had been to see the process and who realised what they were working towards. They said the process would allow solar energy to be stored and transported. Gases can be moved over long distances very readily through small-bore pipelines, as we know well enough in this country. Of course water can be dissociated into oxygen and hydrogen but much lower temperatures will dissociate ammonia into nitrogen and hydrogen. It is worth noting that in both cases the base product is hydrogen. To dissociate water, temperatures of some 2,000 degrees centigrade are needed, which requires very expensive materials in the actual plant. Also, the rate of dissociation is low. However, dissociating ammonia requires temperatures of only 700 degrees centigrade.

As some honourable senators may recall, a group at the Australian National University here in Canberra holds patents on the most efficient system of dissociating ammonia known. This research has been led by Professor Stephen Kaneff of the Department of Engineering Physics at the ANU. I was advised by him recently that about $1m supplied to fund this research over the next five years would complete the system. That funding has not been forthcoming for a variety of reasons. I do not know what they are. It seems to me that it would be an excellent investment and it is worth noting in this context that the United States Department of Energy last year allocated $5m to the same area-that is, the chemical dissociation of substances using solar energy. To my mind the future advantages to Australia of this research ought to be obvious. We have the huge areas of sunlit desert which would provide cheap heat on a completely renewable basis into the future to fuel the process. That can be done, beyond doubt. I am assured by the scientists that that is the case. We also have pipeline systems now carrying natural gas which at some future time, when that fuel has been depleted or exhausted, could carry hydrogen.

There is another matter I would like to get into proportion. Solar energy has been criticised because it is said it would take up so much land. It would indeed take a lot, but not much in terms of the size of the planet, or even Australia for that matter. Professor Kaneff has estimated that it would require, at a 20 per cent conversion efficiency-which is quite reasonable these days-an area 600 kilometres square in central Australia to provide the present energy needs not just of Australia but of the whole world. Of course, such areas for solar collectors are more than available. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Walsh) agreed to:
That, unless otherwise ordered, till 2 p.m. this day, matters of public interest may be discussed by senators, provided that no senator shall speak for more than 15 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I rise to address an issue, I think, of growing importance, certainly to the environmental movement in Australia, but increasingly to the wider community. It concerns the increasing health problems posed by toxic wastes and associated problems with environmental control in Australia. I think the community's awareness of the problem of chemical and metallurgical wastes has risen markedly in recent years, probably spurred on by the news of so many disasters, such as the Seveso disaster in Italy, which scattered dioxin over an extremely large area. The very well known disaster of the Love Canal in the United States came to light in 1979 and much more recently, of course, the Bhopal disaster happened in India. In the last week, the tremendously damaging killing off of large parts of the Rhine occurred through chemical wastes being spilt into the Rhine by Swiss chemical companies.

SPEECH.PARA: Closer to home the potential for widespread harm is illustrated by the threat by an apprentice electrician, which was published in the newspapers, to pollute the metropolitan water supplies with PCBs which are, of course, readily available, and to decommission the generators and capacitors in electricity authorities. In general terms, however, the relatively low industrial concentration and sheer geographical size of Australia have tended to blunt the public's awareness of the magnitude of the problem. There can be little doubt, however, that the absence of major disasters in Australia has been largely due to good luck rather than good management.

The report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation on this matter states quite clearly that there is no accurate information on a national basis on the generation, storage and disposal of toxic wastes. The industry has been essentially self-regulating, while disposal is the preserve of local government, which not surprisingly often lacks both knowledge and the resources necessary for effective regulation, planning and control. In the United States, where much more attention has been paid to this matter, the general definition now of toxic wastes is:
The waste that may cause or significantly contribute to serious illness or death, or that poses a substantial threat to human health or the environment when improperly managed.

Maunsell and Partners surveyed the generation and management of toxic wastes in Australia. It carried out its survey according to the following criteria: First of all, the persistent organics, including PCBs, dioxin and other chlorinated hydrocarbons; second, the acutely toxic teratogenic, carcinogenic and mutagenic organisms; third, inflammable wastes; fourth, explosive, reactive and oxygising wastes; fifth, toxic metals and organo metallics; sixth, toxic inorganics, for example, cyanide; seventh, strongly acidic and toxic wastes; eighth, gas generating wastes; and ninth, gas and liquid container cylinders.

When one looks at that list one is struck by the vast potential for problems that exists in a society such as ours. The enduring and characteristic problem presented by toxic wastes is, of course, their latency period. The physiological harm which can be caused by continuing low level exposure to environmental carcinogenics may not manifest itself for anything up to 40 years. Similarly, mutagenic effects may not be suspect for quite an extended period and, because of the difficulties often found in identification of source and causation, the establishment of that final causal link, which is often necessary seemingly in our society to get anything done, is often difficult, if not impossible, to substantiate.

Of course, if indiscriminate dumping has occurred, the potential for synogestic interactions is enhanced; in other words, the mixing of various chemicals which we have seen in Australia-for example, in my own city of Brisbane-which are only mildly to moderately carcinogenic individually but when put together have their potential for harm magnified extraordinarily. The durability of many of these toxins within our system is also well documented. Heavy metal pollution is virtually permanent and these substances are not biodegradable and, of course, are biocumulative.

Groundwater pollution is something which interestingly enough is being taken up by almost every major international conference on water reticulation currently being conducted around the world-a recent one, of course, being conducted last week in Rome. The problem of groundwater pollution is extremely insidious and potentially one of the most destructive of the problems that are currently facing our country. Having acknowledged the dangers associated with toxic wastes, it is a little worrying that so little attention has been devoted to the monitoring, identification and disposal of these wastes. In fact, almost no action has taken place since the bringing down of the House of Representatives report which pointed quite graphically to the major problems that are looming around Australia and documented those problems in our major metropolitan areas.

We have had legal and illegal dumping in sewers; we have the landfill sites both in Hobart and Melbourne; we have had drums filled with reactive wastes exploding on tips; we have had the problem in Brisbane, for example, at Willawong, with a privately run operation involving the leakage of toxins and toxic wastes; we have had a substitution in Brisbane of another dump which brought about massive deaths of birds. We have even had one death of a person living next to that waste. Again, seemingly very little attention has been paid to this, as though it is something we have come to expect in our type of society.

We have had problems throughout Australia and indeed some of the ones, for example, Willawong, might even be put at the top of the list, but at least they are a planned disposal of wastes in some way. In other States such as Tasmania there are, in fact, no disposal facilities. One further dimension of this problem is the substantial quantity, as I have already mentioned, of PCBs stored by electricity authorities. Neither the locations nor the precise quantities are known; however, the amounts are sure to grow as generators and capacitors are moved into storage. We have clearly an enormous problem that is getting away from us. Undoubtedly part of the solution lies with the re-examination of our laws and regulations with a view to getting some uniformity between the States, Territories and the Commonwealth Government.

The Federal Government has been urged to establish an environmental contaminants authority to seek this type of co-operation between Federal and State governments. Without this, the producers of toxic wastes, fairly obviously, will simply migrate to the State with the least stringent laws and continue their operations. Looking at the pattern around the world, one must be highly sceptical of the ethical regard that most of these companies seem to have for the way that they deal with their products. Uniformity could be obtained by State reference of the requisite powers of a Federal government and this might be another way in which it might be handled.

It seems to me that any political difficulties that may be in the way really ought to be overcome and must be overcome given the urgency of the problem. We are unlikely either now or in the future to arrive at the type of problem faced in the United States with the Love Canal. However, given the fact that there is some increasing pressure within our metropolitan areas over land usage, I would expect that at some stage in the future some similar types of problems-though not identical-could emerge. Hence it seems to me that priority really ought to be given to planning and development of the safe destruction and containment sites on a regional basis for these by-products of our civilisation. Perhaps the use of section 96 grants to States under the Constitution could be an avenue for the encouragement of State development of such facilities. These potential problems will very rapidly find community acceptance.

Unless we move rapidly, I think the community itself will put aside its out of sight, out of mind attitude which exists at the moment and could quickly become highly critical of those governments that have failed to address this issue at a time when the issue can be addressed. The problem could blow out to a point requiring extraordinarily large expenditures, such as were incurred by the United States Government in terms of the complete rehabilitation and removal of a town and rebuilding of a new town with houses and all that that entails. That type of extraordinary expenditure could in fact land on some future governments whether they be local, State or Federal. Now is the time to act while seemingly some type of containment is possible.

Fundamental to a truly comprehensive scheme is the availability of Commonwealth powers and I would hope that the Commonwealth Government would see that this in fact is an obligation that it has and would seek co-operation with State and local authorities to undertake some urgent action so that we are not faced in the very near future with some massive destructive disaster. Then the people of Australia will ask us: `Why have you not done something?'. The information has been presented to this Parliament. It has been presented to the Government and it is well known. What is needed now is some attention to and some action on this very serious and, I think, growing problem within our community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to say something on the Queensland gerrymander, particularly in relation to the recent State election held on 1 November. I think it is important that some of the facts be placed on the record of the Senate in relation to that recent election held in Queensland. It is worth while noting at this stage that the National Party won 55 per cent of the seats, 49 out of the 89, with only 39 per cent of the vote. The National Party increased its outright control of the Parliament when in fact, compared with 1983 it went backwards in terms of votes. We have a situation in which 61 per cent of Queenslanders voted very deliberately against a party which governs with a majority of nine seats in its own right. Not only is it the least popular government in modern Australian history, but probably it has less support than any Opposition in this nation.

SPEECH.PARA: The increase in seats in the latest Queensland gerrymander from 82 to 89 was designed solely and wholly to maximise the National Party's representation on the minimum number of votes required. It is conceivable that under this outrageous electoral rort, the National Party vote could fall to 35 per cent or less and it would still retain outright government. Differences between enrolments vary by as much as 160 per cent-the difference in numbers of enrolments between electorates. In the Queensland election, the issue was clear-cut. Parties other than the National Party campaigned on corruption, cronyism, electoral justice and accountability.

The results are just as clear. Sixty-one per cent of Queensland voted for clean and decent government, against the dishonesty and discrimination of the National Party. Sixty-one per cent of Queenslanders voted for a fair and equal election. They voted against the disgusting distortions and inequalities of the National Party. Sixty-one per cent of Queenslanders voted for accountability of government through an all-party accounts committee and other means of reporting to the Parliament. They voted against the secrecy and the lack of public accountability that were the trademark of the National Party.

The situation is that overwhelmingly 61 per cent of Queenslanders voted against the re-election of a government on three key issues in the 1 November election campaign. Queensland for the next three years will be governed by a party against which 61 per cent of the electorate voted. In actual fact, 61 per cent of the electorate passed a vote of no-confidence in the Government. Where else could we have a government in its own right which 61 per cent of its subjects believe is corrupt, dishonest, dishonestly elected and dangerously unaccountable?

Even worse is the fact that the National Party majority relied on the preferences of the Liberal Party which campaigned directly against it. One could say quite easily that between 10 and 16 seats were given to the National Party by the preferences allocated by the Liberal Party in the State election on 1 November. Where else would one find a political organisation that directs its preferences to a party that has already kicked it out of coalition and now treats it with cynical contempt? Where else would one find a political organisation giving its preferences to a party whose president says it is corrupt and whose treasurer says it is riddled with cronyism? Where else would you find that sort of thing happening other than Queensland?

This unaccountable National Party Government, protected as it is by the gerrymander, is the political darling of the tax avoiders, fly-by-night opportunists and in some cases convicted criminals. We saw the Bond payout of $400,000 for political protection and there is no doubt that a major portion of the $3m to $4m spent by the National Party in the recent campaign came from some of those undesirable sources. The Senate should be concerned not only at the way that the Queensland Government is elected but also at the type of government the electoral system delivers and preserves.

When the majority of voters in any State are unable to express effectively their desire for clean, honest government, it is time for Australians, nationally, to display this outrage. I suppose an example of the electoral system is very clearly shown in the figures that are available to us now; the results of the election are very clear. In the west-far north and the country zones where the National Party won 21 of the 25 seats, 300,909 voters elected the 25 members. In the provincial zones and cities, where the Australian Labor Party won eight of the 13 seats, 240,320 elected 13 members. So there is a difference between the country zones and the city zones; 300,909 voters elected 25 members in the country areas and in the city zones 240,320 elected 13 members. In simple terms, in these non-metropolitan areas the difference of 60,500 overall enrolments means an extra 12 seats, almost all to the advantage of the National Party.

The National Party has 21 of its 49 seats in the most blatantly gerrymandered electoral zone and all I can say is that I appeal to the people within the National Parliament that we bring down legislation to change the entrenched gerrymander in the entrenched National Party within the State of Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is becoming increasingly fashionable in this Parliament to attack key personalities and large companies associated with mining, manufacturing and primary industry activities. Of course, on top of that list stands Charles Copeman of Peko- Wallsend Ltd. But unlike some of the investment mining companies in Australia, Peko-Wallsend is a true miner in the sense that despite current depressed commodity prices it continues to keep open a number of its unprofitable mines, thereby securing employment in remote regions and maintaining the future potential of the mine.

SPEECH.PARA: An example in my State, of course, is the scheelite mine on King Island. When there is a change in management or ownership, there is often a change in attitude as to how those operations should be carried out. During the debate on the Pilbara problems, few people seemed to realise that Peko during the last financial year acquired a controlling interest in the management company of Robe River Iron Associates Joint Venture and, prior to that acquisition, the joint venture had arranged a lease from a subsidiary of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. As part of that lease arrangement it acquired the right to mine further iron ore reserves at Western Deepdale. This action effectively extended the life of the Robe River operations well into the twenty-first century. Also during that year the two largest Japanese steel mills, Nippon Steel and Sumitomo Metal, increased their direct interest in the joint venture by acquiring part of the equity which was previously held by Mitsui.

While, on the one hand, assurances of adequate reserves and participation by major customers in a joint venture are reassuring, on the other they are not sufficient to ensure a successful and profitable operation. It is necessary to have cost control and to be internationally competitive in that mine. When Peko assumed control it became fairly evident that far-reaching management decisions would have to be made to ensure that the mine achieved a level of profitability which would justify proceeding with the quite major capital expenditure necessary to service the increased sales opportunities arising from the extended life of the project.

Unfortunately, over the years many restrictive work practices had been imposed on that operation. In fact, the chairman in his annual report stated that despite persistent negotiations for their removal the situation deteriorated rapidly and resulted in losses being recorded in the last month of the financial year. On 31 July last, far-reaching changes to both management and operation practices were effected. After an unsettling period the operation was closed for 17 working days, which received national publicity. At the annual general meeting, I think in October, the chairman reported that it was pleasing that the operation had returned to a normal level and that most of the restrictive work practices had been removed, with considerable cost savings.

These changes, of course, attracted widespread attention and reflected, no doubt, the level of public concern about the need to improve competitiveness by Australian industry. The Australian Government was initially very critical of the Peko operations, but it soon sensed a national feeling that something had to be done and joined the band-wagon. Unfortunately the Labor Government rhetoric has not been followed by subsequent action. Fortunately, we do have around Australia individuals like the John Leards and the entrepreneurs of Dollar Sweets as well as the Jay Pendarvises of Mudginberri, to name a few. They are standing up for jobs, unlike other bodies such as the Industries Assistance Commission which is continuing to destroy them or transport them outside Australia.

I think it is about time that we saluted some of the people who are trying to maintain or create new jobs, rather than hero worship those who are trying to destroy them. The last casualty of the Hawke Government's inaction is a very competitive company, ANI Corporation Ltd, which sought government help against union thuggery. While Mr Hawke visited Kakadu and made futile attempts to cause job losses because he was uninformed about the Jackeys Marsh area's involvement in woodchipping operations-and he was blatantly wrong-500 jobs in Victoria were in the balance. What has happened? A $70m export contract with Hong Kong, which was initially hailed by the Australian Labor Party as something of a victory, has been lost because of industrial action by the Electrical Trades Union and the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation.

If such action continues further jobs will be destroyed, further export markets will be lost and the dollar will continue to be unstable and to be propped up by the Reserve Bank. The Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) outlined plans, I think just a few days ago, to remove impediments that limit trade potential. What a farce. In theory it is good, but not in practice. It is of little consolation to industries right throughout this country which have been held to ransom by union thuggery. Whether the Minister for Trade's moves will be effective I believe is quite questionable. In July of this year union strikes over superannuation brought eastern Australian shipping to a standstill. In fact, the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations has been quoted as advising that 60,000 man-days have been lost nationally over superannuation claims in the past few months.

These strikes have hit at major companies such as ACI International Ltd and Dunlop, and the list continues. Earlier this year the coal industry had a desperate battle to try to maintain market share and at a time when the industry was at its lowest ebb, a major disputation by the unions resulted in stoppages going over many weeks. Distant fields often appear greener, certainly to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) because he is now stating that 1987 will be much better than 1986. I suppose this might well be the case, if in the last few months of 1986 we continue to go down the drain as quickly as we are going now. There is no hope for Australia if there is not some improvement. But how much lower are we to go?

With the fringe benefits tax, one of the unintended consequences that the Prime Minister has not done anything about, of course, is that this tax is going to lift the average weekly wage beyond the Budget forecast. That is an unintended consequence he did not take into account in his recent adjustments.

The Government has taken great pride in its record on the reduced number of industrial disputes but they are on the rise again. Working days lost through industrial disputes in 1985-86 rose to 1.45 million, the highest level since 1982-83; in fact, they were 10.7 per cent above those in 1984-85. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has stated that Australia can no longer afford strikes if it is to become a successful manufacturing exporter. I ask: What is the Minister doing in relation to his own State, in relation to the loss of jobs as a result of the loss of the export order through ANI to Hong Kong? He went on to say that it is a luxury that this country cannot afford if it is to be a successful manufacturing operator. It is a luxury that he cannot afford, just to sit there and do nothing about the thuggery in relation to ANI.

The rhetoric continues. In July this year the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) said that industrial action and inefficient practices on Australian docks were costing the country $1.2 billion a year. The report confirms that costs and delays associated with shore-based operations are damaging competitiveness of Australian exporters in international markets. We are complaining about our problem of balance of payments but what is the Government doing in the very areas which are causing problems?

The report also points out that the companies which are trying to enter the export market for the first time are being particularly hard hit. The extra costs imposed on importers and exporters by delays could have a greater cost than the effect of a strike. We also have problems of bulk cargo movements; there is unreliability of railway rolling stock; the Government is being lethargic in relation to the setting up of a royal commission into grain handling; and there is a lack of consultation and commercial approach by rail and port authorities. These issues have to be examined if Australia is to get back on its feet again. It is about time that this Labor Party Government started governing in the best interests of Australia and started taking control of thuggery in the union movement.
Sitting suspended from 1.15 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the record current account deficit for October of $1,753m. I ask the Minister: When does he expect this disastrous trend in our current account to be reversed? Does the Minister agree that general adjustment of wages upwards, as presently supported by the Government, and increased wage costs in the form of extra superannuation are absurd in our present circumstances and that the Government must revise its policies in these areas? Finally, what changes does the Government propose to address this ongoing crisis?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The current account deficit for the month, published today, was well within the range of the Government's anticipations.

—Some people in the business and financial community say that the Opposition in this place does not even understand the issues, let alone have the capacity to debate them. That is what they say about members of the Opposition-that they do not even understand the issues. I remind the Senate that I said here three or four months ago that we were anticipating bad figures in respect of the current account deficit later in the year, in October and November.
—That's no excuse.

—Of course it is no excuse. The excuses are to be found in the period when the former Government was in office. There were seven years of malign neglect in which all these issues were swept under the table. Members of the former Government restrained inflation on the admission of their own Prime Minister by keeping the dollar overvalued. That is what members of the former Government did, on the admission of their now trouserless Prime Minister. That is what they did in that period and that is where the seeds of these problems were laid.

ANSWER.PARA: I will return to Senator Chaney's question instead of the rather absurd supplementaries that I have been given of an almost infantile level. In terms of the second part of the question, the Government has implemented a policy on wages since it came to office which has produced results tremendously better than the disastrous years of the Fraser Government. There have been no wage increases in this country under this Government of the order of 14 per cent and 16 per cent per annum. In fact, there has been a decline in real unit labour costs, a performance matched, I think, in no other country. That is recognised by people who have a better understanding of the issues than the lot opposite.

In terms of the last part of the question, let me say first of all that the superannuation issue has been referred back to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission with the support of the Government. That matter is now in the hands of the Arbitration Commission, the Government and industry putting similar submissions to the Arbitration Commission on that issue. Secondly, in terms of a general adjustment of wages, the Government has indicated the parameters for wages for this Budget year and they will be maintained.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I note with great regret the fact that the $1,753m deficit is within the Government's anticipation, but I ask the Minister to answer the question: When does he expect this disastrous trend to be reversed? Will he further tell the Senate whether the Government's record in respect of wages, of which he has been so proud, is good enough for our present circumstances? Does he still believe that the prospect of a 6 per cent wage rise this year is appropriate to Australia's present circumstances?

—The answer to the second part of the question is yes. The answer to the first part of the question is that I am not in the business of predicting, except to say that in terms of our current account problem we are in this for the medium to long haul. I have said that on a number of occasions and I do not in any way intend to depart from what I have persistently said about this issue. For those who understand something of the structural problems of this country, what I have just said should not come as a surprise. It comes as no surprise to the financial community; it should not come as a surprise even to those opposite.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. I refer to media reports that the exploration company, Geopeko, has put a drilling rig into the Kakadu National Park. Can the Minister tell us what the Government intends to do about it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been advised that the Geopeko drilling rig was operating within the Kakadu National Park stage 2 in the vicinity of the Ranger 4 lease yesterday afternoon and again this morning. The Ranger 4 area contains two pre-existing mineral leases on which the Government cannot prevent further exploration, as both the Prime Minister and I indicated in answers in the Parliament on 10 October. We will of course use all our powers, and they are substantial and ample, to prevent mining in any such area should it come to that in due course. In addition to those pre-existing mineral leases in respect of which our powers to stop exploration activity are so limited, the Ranger 4 area also contains a number of lease applications on which the Government does not recognise the right of Geopeko to explore. As we understand it, the drilling in question that has occurred in the last day or so did occur outside the pre-existing mineral lease area and in areas which, as I have just said, we do not recognise as interests under the relevant legislation.

ANSWER.PARA: We understand that Geopeko moved today to yet another lease area, Ranger 68, which is also a lease application of a kind which we do not recognise as an interest justifying or entitling it to explore, but it appears that the wet weather that has occurred up there has prevented it from actually attempting to drill. The Government is advised that the drilling rig has since left the park. However, in the light of all these events the Government has decided to lodge an application for a declaration and, if necessary, an injunction restraining Geopeko from any exploration activity outside the lease areas. Geopeko's action is highly provocative, as I think we can all appreciate, and we will simply not countenance it. The Government will fight Geopeko in the courts to prevent any exploration occurring outside the pre-existing lease area, where, as I have said, our hands are tied.

As to the mining question, at the end of the day on those pre-existing lease areas where some exploration can take effect-although it does not seem that Geopeko is very interested in exploring on its unarguable areas-in respect of those areas and indeed in Kakadu as a whole I simply repeat the earlier statements that have been made very forcefully by the Prime Minister on this issue: That is to say, the Government will not countenance any mining in the existing Kakadu National Park. That is categorical and that is final.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Education aware of comments by the Vice-Chancellor of Queensland University, Professor Brian Wilson, reported in last Saturday's Courier-Mail, that Queensland should find a way to become part of Sydney's western suburbs in order to get a fairer share of tertiary places? Does the Minister agree with Professor Wilson's claim that it is harder to find a tertiary place in Queensland than anywhere else in Australia and that a greater percentage of students are staying on to year 12 in Queensland than in any other State? What hope, if any, can the Government provide to young Queenslanders who are concerned about their futures, beyond the recent inadequate measures?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see some report of Vice-Chancellor Wilson's remarks. There is only one point on which I am in agreement with him and that is his comment that there are high participation rates in the last two years of secondary schooling in Queensland. That is true. That is something we believe has come about as a result of the Commonwealth's policies, such as the participation and equity program and greatly increased allowances for students in that age group, and we are pleased to see it. However, if Professor Wilson's other comments were accurately reported, they are quite misleading. He seemed to be implying that there was going to be some privileged treatment of the western suburbs of Sydney with regard to university places. That is quite wrong.

ANSWER.PARA: The proposal that the Commonwealth Government is currently considering is to make some university places available in the west some time during the next triennium-probably in the last year of that triennium, which would be 1990 or it may even be as far ahead as 1991. If we were able to do that we would not be doing it by taking away resources from any other institution within New South Wales or Australia.

I have made it clear to the New South Wales Government and to the proponents of developing university places in the west that we cannot provide places by taking them away from someone else and certainly Queensland will be no loser. Our current proposal is to move some places which may already be allocated to New South Wales, say, to an existing university out to the west. We may be able to make additional places available as a result of the funding secured for the next triennium but that is really a matter for next year's Budget. So there is absolutely no question of any development we might like to see in the west detracting from commitments made in Queensland, any other State or any other part of New South Wales. It is certainly the wish of the Commonwealth Government to see the development of university places in the west and I believe that we will have the co-operation of the New South Wales Government in ensuring that development.

But to get back to Queensland, I do not know how often I have to say in this place that, under the Hawke Government's higher education policies, Queensland has done better than any other State. The facts speak for themselves and if Senator Parer would like to address the schedules attached to the Commonwealth tertiary education assistance Bills he will see that the places allocated are higher per capita for Queensland than for any other place. Queensland is getting a larger share of per capita enrolments than any other State. I think, from memory, the growth in higher education places in Queensland will be in the vicinity of 9 per cent, whereas nationally it is 7 per cent. We are giving preferential treatment to Queensland because we realise that there is a backlog of neglect inherited from the Fraser Government in the Commonwealth field and inherited further back from the neglect of higher education in Queensland when it was a State responsibility. Of course, that neglect must be sheeted home to previous Queensland State governments.

The history of Queensland's particular situation with regard to higher education places has been set out many times in this place. I would have thought that by now, Senator Parer, who has had some association with higher education in Queensland, would have understood that history; indeed he probably participated in it. The Hawke Government has given preferential treatment in each year's allocation of higher education places to Queensland. Queensland is getting a larger share of the higher education cake than it could justify on a per capita basis because we wish to make up that backlog, which was not our doing but the doing of the Fraser Government and previous Queensland State governments.

So I think it is quite inappropriate for Senator Parer to raise this matter in the terms in which he has. I must say that I think it quite inappropriate for Vice-Chancellor Wilson, who certainly understands the history of higher education funding in Queensland, to suggest that developments in other parts of Australia somehow put Queensland at a disadvantage. Queensland is currently at an advantage in the funding of higher education places. It has been since the Hawke Government implemented its higher education policies, and it is our intention to continue to give preferential treatment to Queensland. I just wish that the Queensland authorities, including the leaders of higher education institutions, would admit the reality.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Minister representing the Treasurer hear the Federal Leader of the Opposition say on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's AM program this morning that the Government would pick up $8 billion in revenue from the cash economy? Can the Minister indicate whether the $8 billion figure for revenue forgone from the cash economy is accurate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did hear Mr Howard's comments on AM this morning and I and my staff spent a bit of time looking around for something which would substantiate the $8 billion. Eventually, I found it. Its origin is incestuous. In fact, it comes from a Press release dated 2 October issued by--
—Mr President, I take a point of order. The Minister seems to be responding to a question which is based on an incorrect quotation of Mr Howard.
—Misusing the Standing Orders again.

—Mr President, there is an abuse of this place by Ministers like the failed Attorney-General. I do not need to be corrected by him from his indolent seated position. The question contained a statement which purported to quote Mr Howard and I think it did so inaccurately. The reference to the $8 billion was to a quantum in the cash economy and not to an amount of taxation which could be collected. I think the question should proceed on the basis of an accurate statement if it is to be permitted at all. It is doubtful whether it is a valid question at all within the Standing Orders since it does not relate to the Minister's responsibilities. But if the question is to be allowed it should be based on an accurate quotation and not an inaccurate one.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I thought that Senator Chaney was going to object to my reference to the incestuous origin of the Leader of the Opposition's statement, because that is what its origin is. A Press statement issued on 2 October by Senator Messner stated:

ANSWER.PARA: the world of the cash transaction has been evading its tax responsibilities to the tune of $21b per annum . . . if the Government collected an average 40 per cent of the $21b lost to the underground economy annually, that would amount to increased Commonwealth revenue of $8b . . .
Both figures are assertions, unsupported by any sourced evidence or any opinions of any consequence. Senator Messner's Press statement continued:
. . . it's time the Government released the thumbscrews on the legitimate private sector--

That is, the banking sector and so on. As I have said, I heard Mr Howard speaking on the AM program this morning. I think this is a very important fact to put on the record because he was giving a list of things for which the Australia Card would be required. He said it would be required to withdraw from or deposit money into a bank. That is true; it will be. The production of the card will also be required for anybody who wants to open an account in a bank. That is very important, of course, because it means that, if one wants to open an account in a false name and continue to operate that account under that false name, as tax evaders and other law-breakers are wont to do, if or when the Australia Card is introduced it will no longer be possible to cheat the Commonwealth revenue or to indulge in other types of criminal activity. It is precisely that sort of activity on which the Opposition has set a course to protect and preserve.

Leaving aside the rubberiness of the figures, Mr Howard's claim that the Australia Card will make no difference whatever to the level of transactions or activity in the black economy is patently false. To the extent that the black economy encompasses payments in cash which are claimed by the payer as deductions from his taxable income but not reported by the employee as taxable income in his hands, the Australia Card will eliminate that section of it. In those areas of the black economy or the cash economy where the payer is not claiming the payment as a deduction from taxable income, the receiver of the payment will sooner or later run into the problem that, unless he wants to stuff the money into a mattress--

TALK.START.PARA: —Put it under the bed.
—Or put it under the bed with the red communists and whoever else inhabits that place these days--
—Order! Senator Walsh, I ask you to stick to the matter of Senator Colston's question. Answers are getting a bit too long.

—Certainly, Mr President. Sooner or later the recipient of the payment will want to dispose of that money in some way or other, such as by putting it in a bank. With an Australia Card he will not be able to use the device that people now use, which is to open a bank account in a false name. He will be required to produce his Australia Card in order to deposit the money, which will then attract the attention of the taxation authorities, which might start asking awkward questions about where all this cash came from.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. I refer to media reports to the effect that the Minister for Primary Industry is satisfied that the logging being carried out at Jackeys Marsh is not endangering National Estate values. I ask: Firstly, on what evidence was the Minister's judgment that no National Estate values were threatened based? Secondly, was the Minister aware that Dr Jamie Kirkpatrick, the botanist employed by the Australian Heritage Commission to produce a detailed report on the Jackeys Marsh area, recommended yesterday to the Commission that logging cease? Finally, if the Heritage Commission report to be presented to the Government within the next two weeks indicates that significant National Estate values are being threatened by the logging, will the Government immediately move to stop that logging?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the last part of the question, I am unaware of any head of power under which the Commonwealth Government could move into Tasmania and stop the State Government or anybody else cutting down trees. The Commonwealth, of course, could, if it chose to do so, have some effect on logging activity through the use of its export control powers. Implicit in the question-I think this is a fair interpretation of it-is that, because Dr Jamie Kirkpatrick, whoever he is, has recommended that the Government take steps to terminate the logging, the Commonwealth should automatically do that. I do not know how good a botanist he is, but it seems to me-this is only a layman's opinion-that he needs to know a bit more about the law if he makes that sort of recommendation and thinks the Commonwealth Government can just move in and stop somebody cutting down trees in Tasmania. I regard it, quite frankly, as an abdication of responsibility, that the Commonwealth should delegate that sort of power, even if it had it, to any particular individual. Those are the sorts of decisions which should be made by governments, by people who are elected rather than by people who are appointed.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised by Mr Kerin that the Government has not yet received the final reports from the botanist, the Commonwealth Government and the Australian Heritage Commission. When those reports are received the Government will consider them as part of the consultative process outlined in the memorandum of understanding. The Commonwealth's Advisory Committee on Tasmanian Forestry Operations is due to report on Jackeys Marsh within three weeks, and the Heritage Commission is expected to complete its detailed work on National Estate values within two weeks. The Government's unequivocal position is that the logging should be suspended pending the consultation processes outlined in the memorandum of understanding.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce seen the article in today's Australian Financial Review regarding the slow uptake of the heavy engineering package which was launched in July of this year? Is the Minister aware that, according to the article, only 11 heavy engineering firms have made formal application for a share of the funds and that only one company has obtained final approval of its application? The article suggests that it is the Government's insistence on unions changing work practices and on companies producing a basic business strategy which is the cause of the slow uptake. Can the Minister indicate the degree of progress in processing applications? What factors are contributing to the delay, if any is occurring?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the contents of the article in the Australian Financial Review this morning. The interest currently being shown in the heavy engineering package is as anticipated. We did not expect a rapid uptake of the scheme, for a variety of reasons.
—It is like the balance of payments deficit.
—No, it is not like the balance of payments deficit. This is probably easier for the honourable senator to understand.
—You anticipate bad results.

—It is not a bad result at all. If the honourable senator just listens to the answer instead of making smart interjections, he will appreciate that. At present some 11 engineering establishments have formally sought assistance under the package and a further 20 companies, some with more than one establishment, have indicated that they will be seeking assistance in the near future. Taken together, the number of applications pending and received account for about 20 per cent of all establishments currently designated as being eligible for assistance under the package.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is aware of concerns held by some eligible firms about the need for them to achieve significant improvements in methods of deploying labour and capital-that is, work practices in particular-before being able to avail themselves of some form of assistance. It is also aware that in some quarters the requirement for applicants to submit details of their corporate strategies or business plans with their applications is of concern. However, the Government has no intention of relaxing these provisions. Changing the work practices requirement would largely negate the main objective of the industry, and that is to improve the efficiency and competitiveness of firms within that industry.

In this context I would emphasise that firm agreements exist within the Australian Council of Trade Unions to ensure that discussions on work practice agreements are undertaken constructively and within the parameters of the wage principles. If employees at particular plants are seeking to go outside these agreements, the matter should be brought to the Government's attention through the Heavy Engineering Board. Relaxing the requirements for applicants to provide details of the firm's viability and business plans would mean that the value of the assistance to the firm could not be adequately judged. Waiving this requirement could lead to funds being wasted on firms which may not be viable in the longer term. In this regard I wish to assure the industry that the provision of such information will be treated in the strictest confidence.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the question which I asked him more than one month ago on the existence, if any, of any legal or other obstacles, including International Labour Organisation decisions, preventing the compulsion of work on those receiving unemployment benefit. I ask: What is the answer to that question? What is the reason for such a long delay in answering?
—I am not aware of the reasons for the delay, but I can see that there has been one, and I will chase up the answer as quickly as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to Australia's vital need to boost export proceeds. I understand that one of the target sectors included in the Australian investment mission to Japan last week was the computer programming and software industry. Can the Minister report on the position of the industry in Australia and indicate whether it has a potential comparative world advantage to contribute significantly to Australian export proceeds?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question comes on a very timely occasion, because today I am releasing the preliminary results of a survey of the Australian software industry which has been conducted by my Department and which confirms the Government's understanding of the industry's potential. The results of that survey show an annual average growth rate in the software industry sector of 50 per cent-a very strong growth by any standards. This growth rate within the industry was not confined just to the domestic market. Other results showed that 10 per cent of the total sales made by the industry would be in export markets. The survey will form a major component of a comprehensive study that will define the current state of the industry and its potential, and it is hoped that it will also expose any problems the industry may have in reaching that potential.

ANSWER.PARA: The results are based on the response to a postal survey of 1,000 software firms and organisations conducted in August 1986. Almost 40 per cent of those surveyed replied, which is a very satisfactory response rate. The preliminary results of the survey show that the industry currently employs about 16,500 people, that software sales for 1985-86 were of the order of $600m, and that sales by respondent companies are reported to have grown, as I said, at an annual average rate of about 50 per cent since this Government came to power. In the period commencing 1983-84 the growth started.
