Exports in 1985-86 contributed over 10 per cent of total sales and are expected to increase their contribution significantly, and over 70 per cent of the respondents indicated that they had developed in Australia software for multiple sale licence or release. In 1985-86 respondents reported that this expenditure was approximately $67m, and it is anticipated that it will rise by 28 per cent to $85.5m in 1986-87.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is Question Time.

—For the benefit of Senator Newman I would also add that the survey indicates that a number of infrastructure problems-that is probably something the honourable senator could ask a question about-are currently confronting the industry. They include the availability of external finance, the availability of skilled staff, and the limited knowledge of overseas markets. These problems affect the industry's ability to export software. Any honourable senator opposite who has a keen intellectual interest in this matter can obtain a copy of the Press release from my office.
—I ask the Minister to table the documents from which he has quoted.
—I table the documents.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Territories. The Minister will no doubt be aware of the industrial dispute currently affecting the collection of garbage in the Australian Capital Territory and the picketing of Australian Capital Territory rubbish tips. Given that the dispute has existed for some weeks, will the Minister give an assurance that the tips will be open this weekend? Will the Minister instruct police to take the necessary action to enable householders and private contractors to exercise their lawful right to dispose of rotting, stinking garbage which is accumulating?

—One of the lessons which the Opposition needs to learn is that when we have industrial disputes it is important that it be left to the parties concerned to resolve the difficulties without making it a party political matter in the Parliament. The Government has recognised the equity of the union's claims in relation to portability of entitlements between contractors and the recognition of service with previous employers. It also, of course, recognises that inconvenience is currently being caused in the Canberra community, and therefore it is doing everything within its power to resolve the dispute. It has agreed in principle to enter into arrangements which will meet the union's claims. When that situation has been resolved the garbage employees will be on the same long service leave benefits as all other private sector employees. The Government's offer is conditional on the union's agreeing to lift all industrial action as soon as is practicable. The Government has not agreed to the union's demand that long service leave arrangements be amended so that the garbage workers will be able to take two months long service leave after 10 years service, because such arrangements would put the garbage employees ahead of other Australian Capital Territory private sector employees. So the Government is endeavouring to resolve the matter in the interests of the community and in the interests of the conditions of those employed in the service.
—I ask a supplementary question. The Minister answered the question that I did not ask, and we are not disputing what he said.
—Order! Will the honourable senator ask her supplementary question?

—The question that I asked was: Will the tips be open this weekend? Will the citizens of Canberra be able to exercise their right to take their own rubbish to the rubbish tips which exist but which are presently being picketed?

—Of course, if the dispute is resolved there is no difficulty. In response to the specific question that Senator Reid asked, she, of course, will accept the fact that I am not the Minister responsible-I only represent him-but I will certainly refer that matter to him for an immediate response.

—Is the Minister representing the Attorney-General aware of concern expressed yesterday in the Victorian Parliament about videos promoting incest finding their way into Victoria from the Australian Capital Territory under laws supported by the Commonwealth Government? Is the Minister also aware that the Attorney-General, Jim Kennan, promised to investigate this? Is the Minister further aware that recently the South Australian Community Welfare Minister, John Cornwall, launched a major survey revealing the devastating impact of videos approved by the Film Censorship Board under the same Federal Government laws, and that a spokeswoman for the authors of the survey, Barbara Biggins, condemned the undue delay of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material in reporting to Parliament? Is it not a fact that this delay cannot be justifiably used as an excuse by the Federal Government to sit on its hands? Is it not a fact that the Senate Select Committee on Video Material in March last year recommended that the Federal Government take action pending the outcome of the Joint Select Committee inquiry and that such action would have overcome the fears of the Victorian Parliament and Mrs Biggins? What action does the Federal Government propose to take to implement these interim measures which, besides a moratorium of X classification videos, the Senate Committee said should have regard to the many problems brought to it in evidence concerning the extent of violence and sex depicted on videos, their transmission by post and their accessibility to children?

—The Attorney-General seems to be displaying a much healthier sense of relaxation about this issue than is Senator Harradine. We are, of course, awaiting the report of the Senate Committee before taking action and making a decision as to what action is appropriate in this area. I will draw the attention of the Attorney-General to Senator Harradine's question and see what more immediate response he might care to make.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. How much has the Government spent so far on preparing the Australia Card, even though no legislation authorising such a card has even been presented to the Senate, let alone passed into law? What has been the cost of the so-called secret project at the Government Printing Office in Canberra on which 20 people have been employed full time for much of this year, and which is involved in preparing this card that a Senate committee recommended against six months ago after hearing expert evidence? Why has the Government wasted these large amounts of money on continuing with expensive preparations for introducing a card which a Senate committee found six months ago would not result in any meaningful reductions in fraud relating to either social security or tax?

—I have no knowledge of any secret project in the Government Printing Office. All I know about this city indicates that if anything is secret it leaks out much quicker than if it is not secret. I am amazed that it has come up only now, but I will make some inquiries of the relevant Minister. I do not know how much money has been expended. I do know that the money was appropriated. It was clearly stated in the Budget, and we have had several debates on the matter. I shall refer the matter raised by Senator Michael Baume to the Minister for Health and get a detailed answer for him as soon as possible.

—The Minister for Veterans' Affairs will be aware that Mr Everingham, in the other place, has made accusations that certain officers employed by the War Memorial have been profiteering from the sales of certain publications and so on. Has the Minister sought an explanation regarding the substance of these allegations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I deplore the use of the Parliament by members to slander public servants who are not in a position to defend themselves and who subsequently find in the newspapers grave allegations made by members of parliament against which they have little redress as the matters have been dealt with under privilege. I think there is a difference in some cases, of course, and I recall Senator Chaney dealing with a matter yesterday of a person holding public office who enters the political debate. There is a difference between what is said there in respect of his political utterances and those members of the Public Service who are obliged by law and regulations not to respond to political issues. Mr Everingham's attack upon three public servants who are not in a position to respond was a scurrilous and defamatory attack and was quite slanderous to the reputation of people who, in my view, are innocent in respect of any of the problems that exist in the Australian War Memorial.

ANSWER.PARA: However, Mr Everingham made certain statements that suggested that both myself and the Department of Veterans' Affairs had failed to carry out any of the investigations we would be obliged to undertake. The very simple explanation is that those matters were never brought to the attention of the Department or the Minister. If those matters had been problems over time, they would have been, or should have been, brought to the attention of the previous Minister; but they were not. In those circumstances, when Mr Everingham made his attack, obviously I sought an explanation from the public servants concerned, three of whom work at the War Memorial. One of them is overseas on leave and obviously I cannot get any response from him at present. However, I have statutory declarations from two other senior officials, public servants who work at the War Memorial. In order to satisfy the exaggerated expectations of the Opposition in this matter, I will table their responses, which are statutory declarations denying emphatically that they have been guilty of any misdemeanour whatsoever.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In the Government's consideration of its dividend imputation proposals, can the Minister yet state whether individuals will still be able to obtain a tax deduction on the interest expense incurred in the purchase of shares, and whether they will be able to negatively gear that interest expense? If no such decisions have been made, when does the Minister expect that they will be made?

—I have a note from the Treasurer on this question. I am advised that interest deductions are available now, as I am sure Senator Short knows, under the general provisions of the tax law, where expense is incurred in deriving assessable income. Assessable income may be derived from the acquisition of shares, from dividends or from capital gains made on the disposal of the shares. The fact that tax payable on dividend income is subject to imputation credits for tax paid at the company level does not alter the fact that the income is assessable. The purpose of the credits is to remove the existing double taxation provision. The Government has made no decision to alter the tax treatment of interest expenses on borrowings used to acquire shares. A discussion of the taxation principles which underlie that treatment is contained in Treasury Economic Paper No. 12, which was released in May this year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to the question asked of him yesterday by Senator Chaney regarding the Australian Taxation Office and revenue losses. Has the Minister been able to ascertain the antecedents of Senator Chaney's question? In particular, I ask whether he can clarify the origins of Senator Chaney's quotation from the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure:

QUESTION.PARA: Taxation revenue losses through non-detection of total taxpayer incomes could conceivably amount to several billion dollars each year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —When Senator Chaney asked me that question yesterday, I said that I had not read the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure, and nor, unfortunately, had I been briefed on it. I now realise that that was a great pity, because since then I have seen page 44, the relevant page of the House of Representatives Expenditure Committee report. There is a footnote on page 44 which names as the source of the $2 billion referred to in the text `Reform of the Australian Tax System', a draft White Paper published last year-page 37. Looking at that source, one finds at page 37 a discussion on tax that is being evaded either through understatement of income or through non-reporting of income. There is a table at the top of page 37 that lists understatement of business income, which is then defined as claims for what is in fact capital expenditure being claimed as repairs or recurrent expenditure, which is a deferral of taxation, of course, by its nature, rather than an outright evasion. It then goes on to name these other items: Non-declaration of fringe benefits received in kind, $700m, estimate; over-claimed employee expenses, $150m; unreported wage and salary income, $100m; non-declaration of dividend and interest income, $300m to $500m; and non-declaration of rental income. Those last three items would be substantially affected, if not eliminated, by the Australia Card. The over-claiming of employee expenses would also be likely to be influenced by the Australia Card. The only remaining item, then, is the fringe benefits tax.

ANSWER.PARA: The really amazing thing about Senator Chaney asking that question is that the Opposition is exhorting and urging the Government to recover that $2 billion of taxation it had been estimated is not being paid now while it is opposing the very devices in legislation which are being put forward to enable us to stamp out that tax evasion. On the one hand, Opposition members say `You have got to collect this revenue which is not being collected', but on the other hand they say, `We promise to repeal the piece of legislation you put in to get $700m of it, and we are also committed to defeating the Australia Card'-which would recover most of the rest of it.

I think I know what happened, and am sure that Senator Chaney is not at all happy about this. He was given a bum steer by the Opposition Leader's office. He was asked to come here and make a fool of himself by asking a silly question based on some very sloppy research. If Senator Chaney wants to ask any more questions about taxation, he should get a more reliable source than his Leader's office.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Walsh following his invitation. I refer to the report to which he has just referred at page 44. Is it not true that in the passage to which he referred, the passage that is footnoted with a reference to the draft White Paper, after stating that there is a loss of about $2,000m in tax revenue, the report goes on to state:

QUESTION.PARA: While this loss is taxpayer initiated, part of the blame lies in the inadequacy of the ATO's system.

I again ask the Minister: Is it not a fact that the Australian Tax Office fails to use the systems which are currently available to it, for example, its right to obtain details of all interest payments which are made to Australian taxpayers? Is it not that failure of the use of the present laws which are available to the Tax Office which is the main point of this report?

TALK.START.PARA: —The report certainly says, as Senator Chaney said, that the loss is taxpayer initiated and that part of the blame lies in the inadequacy of the Australian Taxation Office's systems. That is exactly what the Government believes, and is what the Government is trying to address through the introduction of an Australia Card, and also through the enactment of the fringe benefits tax legislation. Accepting as accurate the background papers and estimates on which the Opposition's original question was based, the fringe benefits tax legislation, which in this context incorporates the substantiation requirements, will collect $700m. Most of the remaining $1,300m or thereabouts listed in that table, at the top of page 37 of the May 1985 White Paper, if not eliminated would be very substantially reduced by the improved system which the Australian Taxation Office would have if the Australia Card were to be introduced. But the Tax Office, the Government and honest taxpayers are confronted with the threat from the Opposition and from the Australian Democrats that they will continue to protect tax evaders in the future as they have done in the past.

—I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister deny what is stated by the Expenditure Committee that the loss of this money `in large measure can simply be attributed to the Australian Taxation Office's own internal inadequacies'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot find that particular passage. I do not think it is a quotation; I think that it is Senator Chaney's interpretation of what is there. What I can find there is:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . part of the blame lies in the inadequacy of ATO's systems?
The Government agrees with that, and that is precisely what the Government is trying to remedy-the inadequacies of the Tax Office system.

TALK.START.PARA: —We inherited it.
—As Senator Gietzelt reminds me, we inherited it from the former Government. We are trying to improve those systems. A critical element in that improvement is, of course, the Australia Card.
—You are a fraud.
—Order! Senator Messner will withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw, Mr President.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Health seen statements by the Liberal spokesman on legal matters, Mr Griffin, in South Australia who has called in the Adelaide Advertiser for the introduction of an identification system similar to an Australia Card? Is this another example of the Liberal Party having it both ways on the real problem of beating tax evasion and social welfare fraud?
—As I ask that question, Senator Newman is interjecting. Obviously, she supports tax fraud or she would not be interjecting on that basis.
—I raise a point of order, Mr President. The reference to Senator Newman was highly objectionable and should be withdrawn.
—Order! I ask Senator Aulich to withdraw that remark.
—Senator Newman has not objected and I understand the touchiness of the Liberal spokesman, but I withdraw.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I did see the reference to Mr Griffin's remarks in South Australia. I note that he also said that identity cards had worked well in Queensland without infringing people's rights, and that a similar system could be introduced in South Australia. Mr Griffin joins people like Mr Anthony and Mr Sinclair in the past, who have advocated the use of identity cards.
—He and others.

—As Senator Evans implies, if one goes through selectively the sorts of people who have advocated the use of identity cards, one wonders whether we should be advocating them ourselves. Mr Ray Braithwaite, who used to be the shadow Minister for Social Security, in 1982 said:

ANSWER.PARA: What we need in Australia to effectively fight all forms of abuse is a proper identification of each Australian with a number, photograph and even a fingerprint.
In 1985 he modified his attitude slightly by saying:
Some of that information may not be necessary now, but my opinion hasn't changed. Concern for civil liberties has to be balanced against the level of social security fraud and overpayment.
Mr Ralph Hunt on 5 June 1985 said:
I will be making representations to the Government strongly supporting this aspect of the White Paper proposals-

It advocated an identity card. Mrs Eda Ritchie, the mother of all the Victorian Liberals here in 1985, also advocated the use of an identity card. Mr Charles Blunt, the present shadow Minister for Social Security, said:

The use of plastic cards as a means of identification would streamline the collection of tax revenue, imposing greater accountability on that small minority who seek to evade their responsibilities . . . The introduction of an ID system should require people to quote the same identity number to both the Tax Office and the Social Security Department.

Mr Blunt also supported it in September 1985, November 1985, May 1986 and September 1986. He was joined in August 1985 by Mr Ian Spicer, the Executive Director of the Victorian Employers Federation, and by Mr Chris Cullen of the Australian Chamber of Commerce. Mr John Howard said on 15 September 1985 that the Government should give favourable consideration to an identity card. Mr Laurie Oakes said to him:
But what about on the grounds of deregulation? If you support deregulation how can you support an ID card?

I don't think there is any inconsistency. I mean the United States has had a social security card for generations and yet the United States economy is the most deregulated economy in the world. I don't think there is any conflict at all.

In June 1986 the Returned Services League, Senator Gietzelt's friends, put out a Press statement supporting it. On 28 June 1985, Mr Nick Greiner said that he supported the introduction of national identity cards. The report of his comments stated:
They are in the interests of the community. Only people who were acting dishonestly had anything to fear.

He did not believe there was a significant issue of civil liberties involved. The Australian Retailers Association is in favour. We all know about Mr Eric Risstrom, and we all know about Mr Eric Mayer from the Business Council of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. Both in presentation and length clearly the Minister is debating the question. I ask you to request him to bring his answer to a close.
—I will, Mr President. On 18 July 1985 these words were said:

ANSWER.PARA: I believe that we should, as a party, be prepared to examine objectively any proposal which is put forward and to very carefully check any proposal against the sort of problems that have been raised.
That was a quotation of Senator Fred Chaney about the introduction of identity cards. My final quotation is from the editorial in today's Australian. It states:

The decision to oppose the introduction of the Australia Card straight after having been so forthright on the fact that a Coalition government would abolish the fringe benefits tax makes the Opposition look like the tax avoiders' party.
The Opposition not only looks like it-it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health or the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. How and to what extent will a national identity card affect the detection and deportation of illegal immigrants?
—Undoubtedly I will get a detailed answer from--
—Have a go.

—I will have a go, Ronnie; you need not worry. Quite clearly one of the means by which illegal immigrants can stay in this country and support themselves is by their capacity to obtain work without any questions being asked, their capacity to easily obtain social security benefits sometimes because of the difficulty in getting the proper identification procedures working effectively and by their capacity similarly to get Medicare cards. One would hope that by making it more difficult for them to do this and by making it easier to detect illegal immigrants, the Australia Card may assist us. However that is not the prime function of the Australia Card--
—In other words, it doesn't work.

—Oh, Senator Walters! I do not know-she is incorrigible. I will miss you, Shirl, I will miss you badly. If honourable senators want some more detailed answers I will get them from the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. In passing, I wish to thank Senator Newman for sending me the free ticket and the opportunity to win a meal with Senator Walters in the near future.

—I ask a supplementary question. I noted the Minister's reponse that the existence of the ID card would make it easier to detect such people. But is it not a fact that immigration officers cannot require any suspected illegal immigrant to produce an ID card and that if they do so they may be subject to a penalty of $5,000 or to imprisonment? How will detection occur?

—I did not say that it would be easier to detect them. I said that it would be much more difficult for them to support themselves under those circumstances in this country. That is consistent with the use of the card as it applies in many other countries in the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Last week I led an investment mission to Japan. I also met with the Japanese Prime Minister, Mr Nakasone, the Minister for International Trade and Industry, Mr Tamura, and leaders of the business and financial sectors, including Mr Saito, Chairman of the Keidanren, Japan's most important business organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: The 12-member investment mission comprised key businessmen, a senior trade union official and government officers. Senior executives from 51 companies accompanied the delegation. The mission arose from an agreement reached between the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Mr Nakasone in Japan last May that there would be an exchange of investment missions between Australia and Japan. Our discussions in Japan were dominated by the structural changes taking place in both Japan and Australia. The sharp appreciation of the yen, resulting from Japan's massive trade surplus, is placing cost pressures on Japanese industry. The Japanese economy will have to adjust to these developments. While this is accepted by the Government, it will nevertheless be a painful process. The adjustment required was highlighted in the influential Maekawa report last April, which recommended, inter alia: Shifting the economy away from its current dependence on exports to growth based more on domestic demand; greater integration between the Japanese and international economies; rationalisation of traditional manufacturing industries based on raw materials and establishment of off-shore production facilities; and development of technologically based industries such as micro-electronics, new materials and biotechnology.

Following the Japanese elections last July Prime Minister Nakasone established a task force under his personal direction to implement the Maekawa recommendations. My discussions with him and Mr Tamura confirmed their determination to pursue these changes. Already some new directions have been established. A start has been made on measures to open up the domestic market to imports; measures to expand domestic demand have been foreshadowed; and Japan has emerged as the world's largest capital exporter, with a rising proportion of this investment going into manufacturing operations in industrialised countries, particularly the United States of America. At the same time as the yen has appreciated there has been a depreciation of the Australian dollar as a result of the slump in our terms of trade. Against the yen, the value of the Australian dollar has more than halved over the past 18 months. This has coincided with some basic economic reforms and adjustments to our industrial structure which have greatly improved our competitiveness. The combination of these reforms and the new yen-Australian dollar relationship lay the framework for an extension of the traditional economic relationship between Australia and Japan. Indeed, this relationship must change and broaden if we are to maintain strong economic ties with Japan. The appreciation of the yen has placed great pressure on Japanese industries which are customers for our resources-based exports. While these exports will remain very important, we need to look to new areas to expand trade between Australia and Japan.

It is clear that Japan is a dominant force in the world economy. Japanese investment in Australia can strengthen our own position in the world economy. At the same time, there are obvious benefits for Japan. From our point of view, Japanese investment in Australian manufacturing industries can contribute to the industry revitalisation objectives we are pursuing through other policy measures. Ties with Japanese companies could, through their existing marketing networks, help Australian enterprises break new ground in exports of manufactures and services, both to Japan and more broadly in the international marketplace. The acknowledged strengths of Japanese industry in product design, quality control and management techniques could also benefit Australian industry. For Japan, it provides a means of addressing its important structural adjustment challenges through access to an industrial infrastructure which contains considerable scope for profitable expansion. Australia offers an impressive skills and research base and a wealthy natural resource base.

Traditionally Japan has looked to Australia mainly for raw materials and there has been a lack of knowledge about our capacities in other areas. A major objective of the mission therefore was to demonstrate the capabilities of Australian industry, particularly in the following areas: The further processing of food, wool, metal and mineral resources; areas where Australia has world class scientific skills and technical capabilities such as computer software, biotechnology and telecommunications; and the automotive components industry where existing links with Japanese industry provide the base for competitive manufacture of components in Australia for both export and domestic use. The other major objective was to outline the structural changes that have occurred in the Australian economy recently and which provide the base for industry's improved competitiveness. These changes are well known to the Australian community but less well known abroad. Our presentations about the deregulation of the financial markets, the relaxation of the guidelines for foreign investment and the reforms made to the taxation system, especially the 150 per cent tax deduction for research and development spending, drew a very favourable response.

During the mission's visit a major focus was the improved industrial relations climate in Australia. Japanese companies were particularly receptive to the involvement and presentations of Mr Bill Mansfield, Assistant Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The mission was united in conveying to the Japanese the determination of business, trade unions and government to work in co-operation to build strength into our economy. The tripartite approach to industrial development through the Australian Manufacturing Council was highlighted.

I believe the mission made significant progress in shifting Japanese perceptions about the capabilities and competitiveness of Australian industry. Considerable interest was generated about investment prospects in Australia. An editorial in the most influential economic newspaper in Japan commented that presentations at the seminar `impressed on us strongly the image of a changing Australia' and that `it is high time for Japanese businesses to consider investment in Australia seriously'. This mission must be seen as the first step in a medium term program to attract Japanese capital and expertise to Australia. We were not aiming for immediate results but rather expect that as a result of the mission Japanese business people will examine the opportunities available for investment in Australian manufacturing industry.

A number of specific business propositions, though, did emerge from the mission and these will be followed up by Australian and Japanese companies in the coming months. The Japanese Government will send a return investment mission to Australia in February next year. It will be led by Mr Amaya, a former Vice-Minister of the Ministry for International Trade and Industry, who visited Australia in 1984 as a guest of government to discuss industry policy. Preparation for the return mission is under way and I look forward to a successful outcome from Mr Amaya's visit. Another avenue for industrial co-operation with Japan is through Auscitec, the private sector committee established earlier this year. Auscitec, working with its Japanese counterpart committee, aims to match Australian and Japanese companies seeking joint ventures, including co-operation in third markets and in technological developments.

There is a tendency sometimes for us to think that our problems are unique. Our own economic restructuring is not easy, but it is matched by the difficulties being faced by many other countries, including Japan. Discussions in Japan confirmed my view that, while restructuring is difficult and painful, the alternative of ignoring changes in the world economic environment is untenable. Both Australia and Japan are adjusting to economic change and this provides the opportunity and the need to broaden our traditional economic relationship. The investment mission succeeded in getting the Japanese to re-examine some of their past perceptions about Australia. I believe there is now a window of opportunity available to us. However, the competition for Japanese capital is fierce. To capitalise on this opportunity requires that we maintain the recent improvement in cost competitiveness and industrial relations. Our industry must also continue to upgrade its management skills, product quality and technological base. Above all, the attraction of substantial productive investment from Japan will depend on a vigorous, co-operative effort between business, trade unions and governments to ensure that we are able to build on the successful economic partnership of the last 30 years between Australia and Japan. I move:
That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has just reported on a matter which is of great importance to Australia-namely, the promotion of investment in this country and particularly investment in our industry. The fact that the statement focuses on the potential for investment from Japan and that it follows and reports upon the Minister's visit to Japan to encourage that is simply a particular aspect of the broader problem that Australia faces-namely, how we are to get the investment which will modernise our economy and solve our economic problems.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst acknowledging the importance of the mission to Japan and accepting many of the points made in the statement, it would be a mistake simply to direct my remarks to the positives in the statement. It would be a little like saying to Emperor Nero `I think you are playing a very beautiful tune' and ignoring what was going on around the violin playing. Whilst I totally support the encouragement of investment in this country and whilst it is important that there be bipartisan support for that so that we will encourage such investment, it is also important to note what I see as the deficiency in the Government's approach, and that is that it is not providing a sufficient sense of urgency about the task which lies ahead. If I were to disagree with any part of the statement put down by the Minister, I would begin with the paragraph towards the end of his statement where he refers to the competition for Japanese capital being fierce. He says:
To capitalise on this opportunity requires that we maintain the recent improvements in cost competitiveness and industrial relations.

Clearly that is not good enough. One of the real deficiencies in the policies being pursued by the Government is that the idea is developing that we need to do no more than maintain the improvements where improvements have been achieved, for example, in the steel industry and the car industry, whereas the reality is that unless we have a commitment in this country to a continuous process of improvements in our cost competitiveness and industrial relations we will not offer what the Minister's statement concedes that we must offer if we are to attract investment, namely, the expectation that this country will provide favourable conditions for profitable expansion in the future. The reality is that it makes sense to invest in this country only if the Government can be seen to be coming to grips with all of the difficulties which at present stand in the way of investment in this country.

Again in Question Time today we heard an attack on a member of the Liberal Party who had said that investing in Australia at this time was not very productive. Of course, that matter has been raised in this Parliament. I raised by way of interjection a similar comment made by Mr Charles Fitzgibbon, who pointed out that at the moment there would be more return from investing in fixed deposits than in Australian enterprises. The challenge which the Government has not faced up to is the need to pursue the changes which will make Australia a better long term investment prospect.

The balance of payments figures released today explain quite adequately why the Opposition does not believe that the touch of complacency which has emerged in this area is appropriate. I rarely find myself in agreement with Mr Laurie Carmichael but I note that Mr Carmichael, who was very deeply involved in the production of the report of the Australian Manufacturing Council issued a little earlier this week, was reported in the Age of 11 November as saying that Australia needed to act quickly on the problems of manufacturing if it wanted to sustain its standard of living. He is reported as follows:

We are looking at what's got to be done in the next six to nine months in order to get a return in five to seven years. Otherwise, your income as well as everybody else's is going to be seriously affected.
I say quite seriously and absolutely that if it is not fixed in that time frame then the standard of living the Australian people have grown up with is going to slide and slide quite dangerously.

The need for that sort of urgency, which is the same point as I stressed after receiving and reading the report of the Australian Manufacturing Council, is borne out by the abysmal balance of payments figures that we face during the current year. It is less than a year since Minister Walsh was saying that there was not really a problem, that the balance of payments situation was nowhere near as bad as that which applied in the last year of the Fraser Government. He conveniently glosses over the fact that there was an international recession at that time; but, even if he was right, the fact is that our record is getting steadily worse and the percentages that he was jeering about less than a year ago are now being exceeded in this country. In the first four months of this year our current account deficit has gone up 14 per cent over the same four months of last year. We heard the Leader of the Government in the Senate addressing that issue in Question Time today. He said that we had problems over the medium term in that regard. The point that the Opposition wishes to assert is that we face an urgent situation and the Government is taking a complacent and gradualist approach which is totally inappropriate to our present circumstances.

The terrifying rise in our debt, including the fact that a substantial additional element of this month's current account deficit is debt servicing, is a reminder that this situation has to be turned around. When the issue was raised with the Leader of the Government today he simply gave us more of the same-business as usual. He referred in Question Time to the heavy engineering regime. Of course, that represents a classic example of the far too gradual application of the processes of change to an industry that faces a very serious and difficult future. The Minister has introduced a three-year plan and procedures which will result in the establishment of committees and the drawing up of rules about what work practices are to be attacked, instead of fostering a situation in which those work practices are being attacked now, today, at the places of work where they are causing inefficiencies. I agree with Mr Laurie Carmichael. We might disagree about the precise changes that need to be made with the rapidity he is urging, but I agree that if we are to attract the sort of investment Senator Button has been seeking in Japan and if we are to offer investors from that country or Australia, or from the United States or the United Kingdom, a future in this country we have to face up to the fact that a whole series of changes is required not over the next 10 years but now. There is no shortage of advice being given to the Government.

Because time is limited in this debate I do not want to go in detail through the report of the Australian Manufacturing Council. However, that report touches on the many areas which will influence Australia's capacity to foster its manufacturing industry. Very few of the general principles which have been expressed would be disputed by anybody on this side of the chamber. Again, one has the sobering assessment in the report that the strategy and policies which are being pursued will be mostly medium to longer term. I again pose the question to Senator Button: What is he going to do now and what is the Government going to do in the very near future to avoid a further collapse of confidence in this country as our debts continue to rise? This extraordinary attitude which seems to be abroad within the Government that we can simply carry on until some medium to longer term strategy bears fruit is, it seems to me, a counsel which can have arisen only out of a desire to preserve the short term political situation rather than the real needs of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would you do, Fred? Have a wage freeze, I suppose?

—The Minister interjects: `What would you do? Would you have a wage freeze?' I asked the Minister a question today. I asked him whether he thought we could justify across the board wage rises in the present circumstances that Australia faces. The Minister reaffirmed the situation the Government adopted in the Budget in August of this year. If the Government genuinely believes that across the board wage increases are appropriate at a time when our balance of payments is in the state that has been announced today, I can only say that the Minister is not nearly as clever as he is reputed to be or that he is, as he sometimes has to, complying with the Government line with which he is not in agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that there is a whole series of areas where the Government has to make quite substantial reversals of policy, and reversals which must be made quickly. How long does the Minister think we can sustain the present level of interest rates and go around claiming that we are trying to encourage new private investment? The Minister is party to a Budget which says that new private investment in this country will decline this year. He is leading an investment mission off to Japan encouraging investment here and yet he is doing nothing about an interest rate regime which makes investment in productive enterprise a stupid thing to do. That is the assessment not just of capitalists, but of trade unionists and others who are putting their savings to work in Australia. They are not putting them to work, they are putting them on deposit to take advantage of these very high interest rates. Too much of that money is being taken by government instead of going into productive enterprise.

In the wages policy area we still have a government which, whilst it has referred the question of superannuation back to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, has yet to come out clearly and state that at the moment any wage rises which are other than productivity based and anything like an across the board add-on of 3 per cent is absolutely absurd given Australia's situation. I simply use this opportunity to draw attention to the fact that whilst the Minister is doing so many things which are in accord with what is required in this country, he is persisting and his Government is persisting with a framework which makes much of his effort totally irrelevant.

If we look at the field of taxation, the Minister is trying desperately to encourage new capital investment in this country in a year when we have imposed capital gains taxes at marginal income tax rates. I ask the Minister: What is happening in the capital gains tax area in those countries with which we are competing for capital gains investment? Are those countries raising their taxes on capital? The answer is no. The reality is that we have a new fringe benefits tax which has been conceded by the Government to be effectively a further payroll tax. Is that the direction we want to go if we wish to encourage investment in productive enterprise? Of course, the answer is no. The Minister says that we want to encourage the tripartite arrangements between government, industry and labour. Again, I direct the Government's attention to the fact that there is a fundamental defect in what it is doing in those cases where, instead of encouraging direct dealings between the employers and their work force, it is encouraging the intervention of trade unions which are not based on any particular enterprise. The Government is encouraging the involvement of trade unions which have no direct interest in the increase of productivity and the improvement of the results of the investment.

The reality is that this statement covers an approach to one segment of our problems which has the support of the Opposition. This Minister has been treated generously by the Opposition. We have supported all the constructive proposals he has put forward to advance the interests of manufacturing industry; but the Opposition believes that the Minister is fundamentally failing to come to grips with the need to provide a genuinely competitive environment. He is a party to too many decisions which are making his actions meaningless. In the case of trying to encourage Japanese investment, he will have to do much more to encourage a reduced cost structure in Australia, a more constructive approach to productivity at the work place, rather than involving external trade unions, and so on. This is a matter which I think warrants and deserves very considerable debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —See how we go.

—The Minister says: `See how we go'. I close my remarks at this stage by simply reminding him that how we are going has again been measured by a record current account deficit in the last measured month.
—Oh, come on! Don't be silly.

—The Minister says that that is silly. I say to him that it is very silly for the Government to be maintaining its Budget parameters or trying to maintain the policies it adopted at Budget time when we are so clearly going down the tube on our balance of payments and building up such massive overseas debt. The sense of urgency which is totally missing from this Government since it decided to trim its sails and sail for the next election is costing this country very dearly. It is a matter on which I hope the Senate will have a great deal more to say before we rise for the Christmas break in December. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: KAKADU NATIONAL PARK: WORLD HERITAGE LISTING

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that Mr President has received the following letter, dated 13 November, from Senator Durack:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
`That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Government to forthwith withdraw its nomination for World Heritage listing of Stage II of Kakadu National Park.'
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Government to forthwith withdraw its nomination for World Heritage listing of Stage II of Kakadu National Park.

At 8.30 a.m. on 16 September last, the Hawke Cabinet met in a state of great panic. At 10.30 a.m. that day it faced a Caucus meeting of members who were in a most rebellious mood about the Hawke Government's environmental policy. That had been precipitated by a report in a newspaper two days earlier of a letter Mr Hawke had written in support of consideration being given to multiple land use in the Kakadu National Park area. For many months prior to these events the Government had been considering the question of a new management plan for Kakadu National Park to replace the one which had expired in December last year. At the same time the Government had been considering the question of whether stage 2 of Kakadu National Park should be nominated for World Heritage listing, stage 1 having been nominated and accepted for listing by the World Heritage Commission in 1981. Both these questions-namely, the new plan of management and the provision that should be made for mineral exploration and possible mining in the stage 2 area, and the question of whether stage 2 should be nominated for World Heritage listing-had been matters of great controversy within the Government. There was also great opposition to some of the extreme environmental approaches by the mining industry generally and by the Northern Territory Government. In fact only as recently as a week ago the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) wrote a letter to a number of people who had been expressing their concern to him. I have already quoted from this letter but I will quote from it again. He said:

You can be assured that I am following these issues carefully with the long term objective of establishing a multiple land use policy in the Region which balances the interests of the mining industry with those of other land users.

On the very morning of 16 September we are now told, prior to the Cabinet meeting at 8.30 a.m., the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, Mr Barry Cohen, who must have been up early that morning dealing with his papers, wrote a letter to assure the Northern Territory Government that there would be consultation with that Government on this question before a decision was made to nominate stage 2 for World Heritage listing. I quote from Mr Cohen's letter to the Minister for Mines and Energy in the Northern Territory, Mr Coulter, dated 16 September. The last paragraph of that letter states:

In relation to the possible inclusion of Kakadu Stage 2 on the World Heritage List, procedures for nominating possible future Australian sites for World Heritage listing were agreed at the July 1984 meeting of the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers . . . and included, inter alia, a commitment by the Commonwealth to full consultation with State and Territory Governments. Should the Commonwealth decide to pursue World Heritage listing of the former Stage 2 area, your Government will be consulted in accordance with the . . . agreement prior to any approach being made to the World Heritage Secretariat in Paris.

History has unfolded very rapidly. The Hawke Cabinet, faced with a rebellious Caucus, completely went to water. Cabinet got together a new approach in its state of panic at that meeting at 8.30 a.m. and when it met Caucus later that morning it was able to tell Caucus that it had agreed to a new plan of management for Kakadu National Park which conceded everything the environmentalists wanted. It was going to exclude mining operations from the park completely and put out of consideration any question of assessing its mineral potential before it made a decision on the new plan of management. In addition to the decision on the plan of management, which we have been debating in the Senate recently, the Government decided immediately to nominate the stage 2 area for inclusion on the World Heritage List. Without any further delay and without any attempt at consultation with the Northern Territory Government, as promised by Mr Cohen only a few hours or perhaps even a few minutes before that decision was taken, on the very next day the Government forwarded its nomination of stage 2 to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation World Heritage Committee for consideration by it. That nomination has now gone forward and it is to be considered by the World Heritage Committee next week or the following week. So this is truly a matter of urgency because the die has been cast by the Government. It still need not proceed with this nomination. It could withdraw it and allow a full and proper assessment to be made of this area before further consideration is given to put it on the World Heritage List.

There is considerable doubt about the procedure the Government has followed which the World Heritage Committee seems to be adopting. Under its operational guidelines, adopted for the consideration of matters for World Heritage listing, a procedure and timetable are laid down which require that nominations of any properties for World Heritage listing should be received by the Committee on 1 January of a particular year. There must be considerable doubt as to whether this Committee, under its own rules and under the International Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural Heritage, is entitled to consider this matter in the haste which the Hawke Government is seeking to impose on it. Of course, there are good reasons for this consideration because very proper consideration has to be given by that Committee to the circumstances for acceptance of any matter for World Heritage listing.

The World Heritage listing will be greatly devalued if the Committee does not consider fully whether properties qualify for listing, whether a country's nomination observes those requirements, or whether properties have been put up for some political reason as this nomination by the Hawke Government clearly is. This is being done to assuage the ruffled environmental lobby on the Government's own back bench and elsewhere. The conduct of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in recent weeks clearly shows his grotesque attempts to curry favour with that lobby. What a pathetic sight we have seen in recent days. The Prime Minister, weeks after he has made a vital decision about Kakadu, goes up to Kakadu at vast expense to the taxpayer and has himself photographed at a key site which is familiar to all viewers of Crocodile Dundee. But what was the point of his going to Kakadu after the Government had made its decision? Surely the Prime Minister should have made those inspections before the Government made its decision?
The requirements for World Heritage listing under the Convention are very strict indeed. Article 2 of the Convention requires that areas should be:

. . . precisely delineated areas which constitute the habitat of threatened species of animals and plants of outstanding universal value . . . natural sites or precisely delineated areas of outstanding universal value from the point of view of science, conservation and natural beauty.

Those are the requirements of the Convention itself. The operational guidelines, which I have mentioned, refer to the requirements for listing properties. This is the sort of language used: Unique, rare or superlative natural phenomena, exceptional natural beauty--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is it.
—The Minister obviously has not been there either. The requirements continue: Great concentrations of animals, sweeping vistas covered by natural vegetation--
—You have never been there.

—Those are the requirements. As I said in the debate on the plan of management only a few days ago, I have recently been there. I went there before the Opposition made its decision, unlike the Prime Minister who only went there afterwards. I went there and saw the total situation. We are talking about a new area of 7,000 square kilometres. Maybe generously we could say that one-third of the that area would satisfy the requirements of the Convention which I mentioned. There are certainly areas of superlative natural beauty in the sandstone escarpments in the escarpment itself, in the rock galleries and in the wetlands. Two-thirds at least or, according to noted Australian conservationist Mr Harry Butler, three-quarters of this area certainly does not satisfy those requirements. As Mr Butler and Professor Mellanby of Britain's Monks Wood Experimental Station have said, 75 per cent of this country certainly does not satisfy those requirements. As Senator Gareth Evans so colourfully put it, it is clapped-out buffalo country. Mr Justice Fox conducted the major environmental study of this area. On 22 October this year I quoted in the Senate from his report, in which he described two thirds of it-I will not say 75 per cent of it-as lowlands that are somewhat monotonous scenically. He said it is mostly open eucalypt forest or woodland, country which is totally familiar in vast areas of Australia. It certainly does not come within a bull's roar of satisfying the requirements of the Convention which I have mentioned.

SPEECH.PARA: We have already nominated stage 1, which comprises about 6,000 square kilometres and which contains within it--

TALK.START.PARA: —Which you did not want.

—The Fraser Government nominated the area. Senator Robertson seems to have no regard at all for the facts of this matter. The 6,000 square kilometres contains examples of all the major features of the Kakadu region. Admittedly, stage 2 contains further examples-in some case maybe even slightly better examples-of some aspects of the grounds for nomination. Certainly, as I have said, not more than a third of that area contains further examples of what is already recorded on the World Heritage List.

SPEECH.PARA: In listing stage 2 in addition to stage 1 a total area of 13,000 square kilometres, by virtue of the plan of management and World Heritage listing, will be totally excluded from any further assessment of mineral potential by the mining industry. It has been assessed by the Bureau of Mineral Resources as one of the most promising areas of mineralisation in the world, not only because of the uranium that is there but also because of a range of other minerals, such as gold, platinum, copper, silver, lead and zinc. Although the importance of the area as a uranium province has been established-uranium mines could be established there if it were not, again, for the troglodytes of the Australian Labor Party who dominate this Government and prevent further uranium mining taking place in approved areas-it has not been fully explored for uranium potential and there has been next to no exploration for the other minerals.

That is the subject of this nomination and the subject of this debate today. We ask only that the Government think again and make a proper assessment of this area. The Government has made this sudden and panic-stricken decision under pressure from its left wing back bench members and others in the community, some of whom are represented in this place. No doubt some of those will be speaking on this today. That is why this nomination has been made. It is a complete sop to the environmental lobby. I would like those speakers who will take part in this debate today to tell us how this nation will ever recover from its economic problems. A current account deficit figure of record proportion was announced today. It is continuing at a level that is well above the Government's estimates, how will the Government rectify that when we prevent even the assessment of enormous potential export earnings? We have a government which has ignored this problem and which is preventing any assessment being made in the future of such a large area which the Government's departments acknowledge is of highly prospective mineralisation.

As I have said, the Government made this decision in panic. It abandoned its attempts to consider the feasibility and desirability of multiple land use for such a large and diverse area as Kakadu National Park. It was in the process of giving that proper consideration when the prospect of facing a rebellious Caucus was too much for the weak stomach of the Prime Minister and a few other Ministers, such as Senator Gareth Evans, and it just gave in without a fight. The nomination has been made without the consultation of the Northern Territory Government, which maintains its strong opposition to it. I hope the Federal Government will allow the Northern Territory Government to appear before the Committee and will do everything possible to facilitate that so that this Committee will learn some facts about the nature of the area which this Government is seeking to have included in such a highly valued and precious document as the World Heritage List. Indeed, I hope the Committee will observe its rules and insist on proper procedures taking place. This is a trumped-up political exercise by this Government-that is all this nomination is-to get it off the hook and to try to mollify the loony Left in its Party and a rapidly dwindling environmental lobby in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a most extraordinary urgency motion that Senator Durack has moved in the Senate today. He is claiming that it is a matter of urgency that the Government withdraw its nomination for the World Heritage listing of stage 2 of Kakadu National Park. The only sense in which the matter is one of urgency is that it is urgent to the Opposition that its hostility to this proposal be considered. In no other respect is there any urgency at all. Virtually all that the Liberal Opposition has chosen to do today is to come in and put, as a matter of urgency, its complaint about the fact that we are implementing Government policy and that it is a policy with which it does not agree. There is no sense in which it is a matter of urgency.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly if I can be clear about anything in this debate it is that the Hawke Government has no intention whatsoever of withdrawing the nomination. We are totally enthusiastic about it; we support it entirely; and, of course, we believe it will be successful. When the listing of Kakadu stage 2 is successful I believe it will be welcomed throughout Australia, not only by environmentalists but also by many other people who see the importance of protecting our natural heritage in this way. Of course, it will be welcomed very widely in the international community because, once an area attains World Heritage listing, there is recognition that it has universal significance and value. There is absolutely no question of the Government taking any notice at all of any pleas for withdrawal from this very important, positive and proper course of action.

It is quite surprising that Senator Durack repeated in the comments that he has just made the view that somehow the decision to proceed with the World Heritage listing of Kakadu stage 2 was sudden and unpremeditated. This is quite extraordinary, even for someone such as Senator Durack. The intention of nominating Kakadu stage 2 has been around for many years and, indeed, was first acknowledged during the period of the Fraser Government, of which Senator Durack was a member, when it made the nomination of Kakadu stage 1. It is absolutely ludicrous to suggest that until the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made his announcement a few weeks ago there was no consideration of this matter. There has been ongoing, active and public consideration of the nomination since 1981. The Northern Territory Government, the Liberal Opposition, Senator Durack and everybody else has known that this has been the intention. We have never at any stage suggested anything other than that we would be proceeding along these lines.

As for the specific timing of the decision, that was brought about by a number of matters but mainly by the fact that we wanted to demonstrate quite clearly that, as we had undertaken to do, we were going to proceed with the protection of Kakadu stage 2. In fact, one of the complaints that Senator Durack made in the course of his remarks concerned the guidelines for new nominations for the World Heritage Committee. Senator Durack may or may not be aware-but he ought to be aware-that the World Heritage Committee does not regard this as a new nomination but as an extension to an existing listing which the Committee itself nominated in 1981. Further, the United Nations Educational, Cultural and Scientific Organisation has suggested that there was no need to go through the lengthy procedures for a new nomination. So what we are really doing is completing a course of action which was commenced in 1981.

As I said, any suggestion that suddenly, out of the blue, our Government discovered Kakadu stage 2 and decided to seek nomination for it on the World Heritage List is absolutely absurd. I am really surprised that Senator Durack could make those sorts of comments in this place. He also suggested in some of his comments that there was very little knowledge of the park and its outstanding characteristics on the part of the Government on a personal basis. That is absolutely absurd also. My colleague Senator Ted Robertson, who has been a Senator for the Northern Territory for a period in excess of 10 years, has spent a great deal of time in Kakadu National Park and has been a constant source of information to the Government about it. Many members of our Government have visited the park and spent time there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Including yourself.

—Indeed, as Senator Robertson pointed out, I spent some days there myself in the middle of 1982, and was at that time persuaded of the unique, rare, and special character of the park. I was persuaded of something else, too-something which is relevant to some of the concluding remarks of Senator Durack. Senator Durack suggested that by proceeding with this course of action-and, as I said, we have every intention of doing so-we are somehow harming the economic prospects for Australia generally and the Northern Territory specifically. I think it is his view that, rather than protecting this unique and wonderful piece of natural heritage, we should go and dig it up and see whether there is any more uranium there. I would like to point out to Senator Durack that it is my view-and I am sure it is a view that would be widely supported-that the tourism earning potential of national park areas of such exquisite and rare interest as that of Kakadu far outweighs any possible earnings that may or may not come about through the production of more uranium. We certainly do not have uranium in short supply. World uranium prices are not particularly good.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a very narrow and short term argument to say that whereas the digging up of the park might lead to the discovery of more uranium mines the protection of it would harm the economy. I have spoken to many Northern Territorians in the 10 years or so that I have been visiting the Territory and many of them are most conscious of the tourism potential of their Territory. It seems to me that that is indeed the greatest economic potential that the Territory has. If national parks are properly cared for, if they are given international prominence-and this certainly happens as a result of World Heritage listing-economic benefits will flow to Territorians in a much more assured way than they would as a result of any speculation on the possibility of more uranium.

I would like to return to the theme harped on by Senator Durack, namely, that this decision to nominate Kakadu stage 2 was sudden and brought about for political rather than policy reasons and so forth. I would just like to take him and other honourable senators who are interested in the matter through a little of the history leading up to the decision we have now taken and to which we will adhere. When the nomination of the stage 1 area was originally made in 1980 the then Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Paul Everingham, noted that additions would be made to the park when he agreed to the World Heritage listing. So as far back as 1980 the Northern Territory government, which is now claiming there was no consultation and so forth, was aware that a future extension of the park would also be listed. That was over six years ago. The Prime Minister at the time, Malcolm Fraser, also realised that the nomination of stage 1 excluded areas which might be considered suitable for World Heritage listing. He noted in a letter of 4 June 1980 to the Director of the Australian Conservation Foundation that this was a matter which could be progressively reviewed as the Kakadu National Park was developed. In inscribing Kakadu National Park in October 1981, the World Heritage Committee itself said that it:

. . . noted that the Australian Government intended to proclaim additional areas in the Alligator Rivers Region as part of Kakadu National Park and recommended that such areas be inscribed on the World Heritage List and that in the Region the environmental protection measures specified in the relevant legislation continue to be enforced.

So again, in the actual listing in 1981, there was an indication, a statement of intent, as to the future development of the park. When a bronze plaque commemorating the inscription of Kakadu National Park on the World Heritage List was unveiled near Jabiru on 19 November 1983, the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, Mr Barry Cohen, foreshadowed a proposal to incorporate additional areas in the World Heritage listing-another very public, very clear statement of intent on behalf of our Government. Stage 2 of Kakadu National Park was proclaimed by the Governor-General in February 1984. In announcing the proclamation Mr Cohen again noted that stage 2 would be considered by the Government for nomination to the World Heritage List as an extension to Kakadu National Park as already listed.

The proposal has been raised in many forums since that time. In December 1985 stage 2 of Kakadu National Park was amalgamated with stage 1 into Kakadu National Park. There was no addition to the area of national park nor any change in the status of the areas concerned. Amalgamation allowed the whole park to be operated under the name `Kakadu National Park' and under one plan of management. It was against this very sound development background of properly considered policy development, properly publicised to all interested parties in major statements over a period, that we as the Government took our decision on 16 September to seek World Heritage listing of Kakadu stage 2. It must be realised that this proposal is not a new nomination as such, but merely an extension to an existing World Heritage listing. This status, as I said earlier, has been confirmed by UNESCO and that is the reason why it is being considered later this month rather than next year.

Of course the Northern Territory Government has protested against our decision to seek World Heritage listing. However, because of the special circumstances related to Kakadu stage 2, the Prime Minister has advised the Northern Territory Chief Minister that the Commonwealth Government will not seek to withdraw the extension of Kakadu from the agenda for the World Heritage Committee meeting in Paris later this month. Procedures for nominating Australian areas to the World Heritage List were agreed between the Federal and State governments at the 1984 meeting of the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers. The agreement called for consultation. But there is no stipulation requiring the Federal Government to seek the prior agreement of a State concerning nomination. Of course, in the case of the Northern Territory, it would be a futile exercise to do that because it is quite clear that agreement would not be forthcoming. Also, of course, the Northern Territory Government does not own Kakadu National Park; nor does it manage it. The land has been declared a national park under Commonwealth legislation-an act carried out by the previous Fraser Government-and, as such, is managed by a Commonwealth body, the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, which, I might say in passing, does an excellent job.

It must also be realised that under the World Heritage Convention the inscription of a place on the World Heritage List demands genuine protection and preservation of the area in question. In the case of many of the most significant heritage areas in Australia-for example, South West Tasmania, again rescued from destruction by our Government; the Willandra Lakes region of New South Wales; Lord Howe Island; the New South Wales rainforests-the Commonwealth can ensure this only in co-operation with the States. That is why consultation on possible World Heritage nominations is so important. In the case of Kakadu National Park, however, the Commonwealth itself has the authority to ensure Kakadu's continuing management in accordance with World Heritage principles. So, in other words, the provision for consultation is in order to ensure that proper arrangements are made for the protection and conservation of the area. In the case of Kakadu and in the case of the Northern Territory Government, the Northern Territory Government has no role in that conservation and protection procedure and, therefore, the kind of consultation stipulated is really of no particular point.

There is also no question that mining operations would be allowed to degrade the park to such a stage where its World Heritage status would be in danger. The Prime Minister has categorically ruled out the possibility of any mining operations in the existing Kakadu National Park. There has also been some suggestion that stage 2 does not currently warrant World Heritage listing. I shall say a couple of things in refutation of that, but I am sure that other speakers who are to follow me in the debate will be very well placed to speak at some length about the reasons why the Kakadu area certainly justifies this nomination. My colleague Senator Olive Zakharov has a great deal of knowledge in this area, as has Senator Sanders, too, so I shall not take up the time of the Senate by pointing out the various rare, exotic and very important aspects of the park which certainly in our view justify the nomination.

Stage 2 should not be considered in isolation but together with stage 1, which itself is discontinuous and elongated. Stages 1 and 2 are complementary, sharing some features but each enhancing the viability and integrity of the other. Although stage 2 contains outstanding features in its own right, it is now the combination of stage 1 and stage 2 which is being proposed for inclusion on the World Heritage List. Kakadu National Park is one of only eight places out of the 216 inscribed on the World Heritage List which meets the criterion of `outstanding universal value' in relation to the natural as well as the cultural heritage. Stage 2 also meets both these sets of criteria. For example, on the natural side, stage 2 includes most of the catchments of the Wildman and West Alligator Rivers, and the downstream parts of the catchments of the South Alligator River and Magela Creek-which is a major tributary of the East Alligator River. Stage 2 is drained by a vast network of creeks which in the wet season carry huge volumes of water, combining with the outflow from stage 1 to inundate the extensive floodplains and swamps.

It is quite clear from that description-I do not think that Senator Durack could argue against that description-that the two areas are properly now under consideration as one area. The interrelationship between them is very important, and of course, that is one of the major reasons for our concern to get the proper protection that will be afforded to Kakadu stage 2 by its World Heritage listing. It is not simply good enough to say, or to imply, as Senator Durack has done: `We have done Kakadu stage 1; that is enough; we will let the miners in to do whatever they want to do to Kakadu stage 2'. If that were to happen-fortunately it will not happen, because of the actions of our Government-the whole network of river systems and the whole water support system for stage 1 could be very drastically damaged.

I remind honourable senators, too, that on the cultural side this is a most extraordinary area in terms of its record of Aboriginal cultural history. Aboriginal people have occupied Kakadu for at least 25,000 years, and probably for much longer. The Aboriginal residents in the park have long-established ancestral bonds with the area. Although their traditional lifestyle has been modified, traditional customs and beliefs are still important in their everyday life. Throughout stage 2, as in stage 1, there are a large number of Aboriginal sites of significance, including sacred sites, archaeological sites and art sites. If it were only for the importance of the Kakadu area in relation to Aboriginal culture, I believe that the area would justify nomination on the World Heritage List. Anyone who has been to Kakadu stage 1 and has had the opportunity, the privilege, the experience, of seeing the Aboriginal rock art in that area, in the outstanding caves of the Nourlangie Rock or the Obiri Rock, would, I think, support the strongest possible legislative measures to ensure the protection of such a unique heritage.

I see that my time has almost expired, Mr Acting Deputy President. I simply say in conclusion that there are many other reasons why the Government has made this very important decision. They will be spelt out by subsequent speakers in the debate. As to the matter of urgency, there is no matter of urgency. As for the suggestion that our Government might retreat at this stage from the seeking of World Heritage listing for Kakadu National Park stage 2, that is entirely out of the question, as I am sure the majority of Australians think it ought to be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, wonder about the urgency. If there is any urgency, of course, it is to list this area as rapidly as possible to protect it from those who would despoil it. I wonder whether the urgency has anything to do with the fact that perhaps the Opposition feels that there is an election coming on and it wants to send firm signals to its friends in the mining industry that it is completely in favour of mining in all parts of Australia. Perhaps in such a manner it hopes to obtain election funds from the mining industry. I have no other reason to give for this peculiar urgency motion.

SPEECH.PARA: In his presentation, Senator Durack cited as his authorities for the removal of the proposed listing of stage 2 of Kakadu the Australian conservationist Mr Harry Butler and British-based conservation expert Professor Kenneth Mellanby. It just so happens that very recently in the Northern Territory News, which is a rather hysterical little publication in Darwin, the front page headline read `Kakadu ``Fraud'' '. The article stated:
Australian conservationist, Mr Harry Butler, today described the Federal Government's proposed listing of Kakadu National Park's Stage 2 as an attempted fraud.

Who is Harry Butler and why is he saying this? Harry Butler is what we in the conservationist movement call a `biostitute'-a hired mouth.
