He made himself a reputation on Australian Broadcasting Corporation television by going around and lifting up rocks and finding cuddly little animals thereunder. However, what he really made his money at was trying to justify the environmental excesses of the mining industry and the oil industry. His whole empire-he has an empire, and he is a very wealthy man because he has been running around the country trying to justify these rip-off artists-his whole ball of wool, became unravelled over the Franklin Dam issue, at which time he was hired by Harry Holgate, the Premier of Tasmania, to come in and use his so-called scientific expertise to say that South West Tasmania was not a wilderness. Where have we heard that? He is also saying that Kakadu stage 2 is not a wilderness.

When this guy from Western Australia came to Tasmania and said that south western Tasmania was not a wilderness, he even infuriated the Tasmanians who wanted to build the dam. They said, `It certainly is a wilderness. We may want to dam it, but it is a wilderness'. It came out that he had taken some $12,500, I think, and the media started questioning him very closely. He turned on the media and lost his entire credibility. I am afraid that the Northern Territory Government is simply not going to get its money's worth by paying for `conservationist' Harry Butler because he has no credibility either in Australia or overseas. Mr Butler is quoted as saying that the:
. . . stage 2 buffer areas demarcated by Canberra also should not be included in the listing because they were irrelevant to conservation and the whole of stage 2 already had national park status.

He is obviously working for the mining industry. He wants open slather, as do the NT Government and the Federal Opposition, in all parts of Australia, including Kakadu stages 1 and 2. He was further reported as saying:
Years of Ranger uranium mining within Kakadu had not provided any evidence of environmental damage.

Well, apparently this noted environmentalist, this wonderful conservationist, Harry Butler, does not consider two huge open pit mines, a whole series of tailing dams covering many hectares, tin processing sheds which extend metres into the air, and an entire township as environmental damage or environmental change. Obviously, the man has no qualifications at all.

What about British-based conservation expert Professor Kenneth Mellanby? He came in and inspected the area and is throwing his weight into the fray. I first encountered Professor Mellanby some eight years ago when I debated him on television. At that time he was being taken around the country by a group of cattlemen who wanted to get access to national parks for grazing. He is a nice man who simply does not understand the Australian conditions. He is a British person. In Britain of course all the national parks are multiple use because they always have been. Britain was the forerunner in the industrial revolution and there is very little wild land left.

To show exactly how far Professor Mellanby goes, I point out that he suggested on television as a serious proposition that we we actually open up the south-west of Tasmania to cattle grazing. Of course it is impossible. One cannot graze cattle in south-west Tasmania, it is completely unsuitable; but this environmental expert said that we should. He said that from his observations most of stage 2 was totally unsuitable for international recognition-I emphasise that this was the man who wanted to graze cattle in South West Tasmania. He further said:
I believe there are some people in Canberra who want to create the world's top national parks for the sake of doing so.

I sincerely hope that there are people in Canberra who want to create top national parks for the sake of doing so. I am glad that they are here, and I welcome them. What an extraordinary statement for him to make. These are the two environmental experts Senator Durack depends on for his pronouncements that this should not be made into a world heritage area.

This area is internationally significant. A few days ago we were talking about Tasmania woodchipping and Senator Newman felt compelled to say to me: `Go home Yank'. I took exception to that as an ethnic slur, as I believe it is. It is almost universal that those of us who do come from some place else or who have come here more recently than other migrants who may have been here for several generations appreciate Australia more than the older residents, excepting, of course, the Aboriginal people. I think that we see it with fresh eyes. We come from places around the world which do not have the wilderness area that Australia is still fortunate to have. The rest of the world does not have the open spaces or the opportunity to set these areas aside as we do here. That is why we who come from other places that are less fortunate struggle so hard to preserve what we see in Australia from development.

I believe in firm control over national park areas. I wish more areas were in national parks. I wish that the so-called national parks which are really State preserves under the control of State governments were also national parks controlled by the Federal Government The United States is a very developed country but to this very day, despite the inroads of President Reagan's Mr Watt in the Bureau of Land Management, national parks in the United States are pretty much inviolate. The government that established the first national park in the United States, Yellowstone, set it up very proudly. It had mineral and timber resources; it had a number of resources. The government there said `We are willing to set this aside in perpetuity'. For the first seven or eight years it was managed by a concessionaire who was flogging off the timber and the mining rights. When the people in Washington got word of this, Congress said `enough' and sent in the United States cavalry. The United States cavalry patrolled Yellowstone National Park for 30 years and kept out the miners and the loggers with drawn sabres. I would very much like to see that approach used in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I bet you would.
—My fellow Tasmanian says: `I bet you would'.
—Don't call me your fellow Tasmanian, for goodness sake. I can stand most things but I won't stand that.

—Apparently the good senator claims that I do not reside in Tasmania. This shows the lengths the Opposition will go to to obfuscate and distort the facts. The fact is that exploration in itself damages the environment. Already we see that Geopeko is trying to defy the Prime Minister and the Government by working in Kakadu National Park in the Northern Territory. It has confirmed that it operated a rig outside the lease areas recognised by the Government near to an area visited by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, last week. It has done this as a provocation.

SPEECH.PARA: What does exploration do? Exploration by its very nature affects the environment. Roads have to be built, drilling rigs are operated, spoiling heaps are created and it is in itself an environmentally damaging occupation. If minerals are found, the mines themselves are environmentally disastrous. What are they looking for in Kakadu? They are looking for uranium. Uranium is a mineral of death. There are no peaceful uses of uranium, only destructive uses. The so-called peaceful uses do not exist as we have seen from Chernobyl, Three Mile Island, Windscale and the nuclear arms race. So not only is it damaging to the environment; it is actually dangerous to world security and peace to dig this stuff out of the ground. But I am sure that Senator Vallentine will amplify that area. What is at stake here is the principle of whether the people of Australia can keep the mining companies out of any areas whatsoever. The mining companies do not want to mine in Kakadu at this moment. They just do not like the idea that there is some place that they can be kept out of, that they cannot get in to the area at will. They want access to all Australia's land.

In the Northern Territory the mining industry is aided and abetted by a totally subservient government. I had a discussion with the Chief Minister, Steve Hatton, when he was the Minister for the Environment. He was supposed to be the greenie of the Northern Territory Government. He could not conceive of a national park concept which would prohibit exploration. I said: `If you are going to set aside a national park, it should be for the future and it does not matter whether there are any minerals in it or not. You are not going to use them so you should not be allowed to explore'. This was inconceivable to him as the most environmentally aware member of that Government, and now of course he is Chief Minister. Unfortunately, what we see in the Northern Territory and in the mining industry is the worst side of human behaviour-the get-rich-quick syndrome. These people would happily sell their grandmothers' gold fillings for a profit. They have no thought for the future and no responsibility to the present. The Northern Territory Government is as incapable of looking to the future as is the Gray Government of Tasmania. Both governments unfortunately see their goal as making as much money in as short a time as possible and letting future generations worry about their economic, cultural and environmental well-being.

Stage 3 has not been mentioned to this point in the debate. While we are fighting very strongly to make sure that stages 1 and 2 are free from mineral exploration, the conservation movement will also be very concerned to see that no mining takes place in stage 3 and that all three stages of the Kakadu National Park are included in a park which will then have the international significance it deserves. At the moment the Federal Government must stand firm against the mining industries, the Northern Territory Government, the Opposition and any others who would want to defile what actually belongs to all Australians. This is a national heritage and it must be preserved for all Australians, not only for now but for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Senate is debating as a matter of public importance the need for the Government to withdraw its nomination for World Heritage listing of stage 2 of Kakadu National Park. I rise to support the comments of my colleague Senator Durack, who lead the reasoned and rational debate from this side of the chamber. Senator Sanders's contribution has been one of numerous slurs and it should be ignored. Indeed, he has attacked Harry Butler whom Australians recognise as one of their foremost sons. Harry Butler has been honoured by Australian and has done much for conservation for Australia and its people. I do not think that there is anything more to say about Senator Sanders's contribution. It is also a great pity that the speakers for the Government cannot address this issue rationally instead of considering it purely as a potential vote catcher. This is what they are doing and in taking that path they are ignoring their responsibility to protect Australia's national interests.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators only need to look at the Press reports of a few weeks ago. In mid- October the support of senior Government Ministers for mining within Kakadu National Park was widely reported. Those senior Ministers were said to include the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) who, it was said, strongly favoured more mining going ahead in the national interest. The Prime Minister even went so far as to write to the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, Mr Cohen, who is responsible for national parks, to express concern about the fact that the plan of management proposed for the park was deficient in its failure to include provisions for the recovery of minerals from the park. That point of view is quite correct. Less than a month ago the Prime Minister was concerned with Australia's national interest-our desperate need for export earnings and our current deficit of some $8 billion. It takes something like one-third of Australia's overseas earnings to service the interest on that debt alone.

What has happened since then? Where has the Prime Minister's concern gone? We were all exposed to the media coverage of Mr Hawke cruising around Yellow Waters and posing at Obiri Rock last week and the nation learnt that the Prime Minister is a `born again greenie'. I must say that that was a very recent rebirth. In the space of a month he has rediscovered an affinity with mother nature that is such that the national interest, with which he was concerned, is no longer relevant. At the end of his multi-media Kakadu junket last week Mr Hawke said that it would be an obscenity to mine in Kakadu. The real obscenity, of course, is the spectacle of the Prime Minister of this country jeopardising the economic future of Australia by depriving the nation of the right to develop its natural resources in return for some short term political gain and, of course, pats from the left wing of his Party. Apparently the Australian Labor Party has adopted the attitude that it must win the next election at all costs, even if that means selling out the people of the nation that it claims to represent.

If the Federal Government's decision to seek World Heritage listing for stage 2 of the Park is implemented, the Government will have succeeded in debarring development of the richest and biggest uranium province in the world. The known uranium deposits in Kakadu are large and low cost. All were found in a very short period, essentially between 1969 and 1971, and very justifiably these can be considered the tip of the iceberg. If uranium mining could proceed with market forces and appropriate environmental concern being the only constraints, Australia and Canada would virtually control the world's uranium production. In the early 1970s Australia had a large competitive edge over Canada which has now been surrendered. Access to Kakadu for exploration and mining would see Australia rapidly retrieve the lost ground and would make a vast contribution to the nation's well-being. Certainly it needs that these days. The success rate in the very short period during which Kakadu was open to explorers was staggering and probably represents the lowest cost per tonne of ore found in the history of exploration in Australia, at least in modern decades. Of course the area is highly prospective not only for uranium but also for other minerals, including silver, tin, tungsten, cobalt, lead, zinc and gold, all of which are very desirable for Australia.

Mineral exploration has been carried out for commodities other than uranium. While gold has long been known to occur with uranium in the South Alligator Valley, no systematic exploration for gold in the Kakadu region has occurred until recently with activity at Coronation Hill. This activity reflects the gold boom conditions prevailing at present in Australia. Additionally, knowledge of the gold resources in the Jabiluka ore body is incomplete. Some 11 tonnes of contained gold are indicated, but the total amount could be significantly higher. A preliminary resource estimate for gold at Coronation Hill is of the same order of magnitude as that at Jabiluka. Again, the ultimate resource could be several times greater. It is clear that this area represents a national resource of tremendous proportions and to attempt to close it off by the combination of placing it on the World Heritage List and implementing the new plan of management is not the act of a reasonable or rational government.

The argument which the Government and the Australian Democrats trot out on this issue is that mining is inconsistent with national park status and that the environmental impact of mining would be to destroy the area. It must be remembered that we are talking about an area of more than 13,000 square kilometres in relation to stages 1 and 2. When the proposed stage 3 is added in, the area of Kakadu National Park will be more than 22,000 square kilometres. The area of the existing Ranger mine is only 0.02 per cent of the proposed total area of Kakadu. That is about one part in 5,000. It is quite realistic to state that less than one per cent in toto would ever be affected by mining. Additionally, in circumstances of carefully controlled exploration and with market forces prevailing, all ore bodies would never be found simultaneously and hence would never be mined simultaneously. Also, rehabilitation could proceed in concert with orderly mining. We have certainly seen orderly mining carried out in the Northern Territory, such as at Nhulunbuy and Groote Eylandt. Indeed we have seen the reclamation of the old uranium mine at Rum Jungle and with the modern techniques of reclamation this has done enormous good for that particular area. As I said, mining would be aggregated in small discrete areas within the belts of favourable rocks. Thus a minute area would be affected by mining and indeed rehabilitation would take place after it had been fully developed. It has been shown that mineral exploration activities can be carried out with minimal disturbance of the environment.

The Federal Government is clearly ignoring the legitimate option of multiple land use within Kakadu. In doing so, as I have said, it is depriving the nation of valuable natural resources. At the same time it is depriving the Northern Territory of access to its natural resources. Honourable senators should be aware that development in the Northern Territory has proceeded at an impressive rate in recent years, particularly since the Territory obtained self-government in 1978. The progress which has been made has been made within the confines of a restricted resource base largely dependent on the pastoral, tourism and mining industries. There are of course other industries operating in the Territory, but these three are of very great significance in terms of the Northern Territory's economic development. The World Heritage listing of stage 2 will rob the Northern Territory of the right to develop a vast quantity of its natural resources. When the cry constantly goes out from Canberra that the Northern Territory is too heavily dependent upon the Commonwealth for funding, it is ironic that the Commonwealth Government is bent upon a course of making it even more difficult for the Territory to improve on its level of economic self sufficiency.

The other industry which the Northern Territory has done so much to build up over recent years and which is threatened by the Federal Government's approach to Kakadu, is tourism. It is not so much threatened by the World Heritage listing of the area as it is by the plan of management, which looks set to prevent any large scale tourism accommodation being developed within the park. The assault on the Northern Territory which has been launched by this Federal Government over Kakadu is a disgraceful display of the Labor Party's attitude that if it cannot win votes in the Northern Territory it is not interested in protecting the interests of this part of the country. Surely this is borne out by the actions and comments of the Prime Minister in the last few weeks. This attitude has been made perfectly plain by the way in which the Federal Government has gone about seeking World Heritage listing.

As a starting point it must be noted that the Federal Government is required to consult with the Northern Territory Government in relation to this matter in accordance with an understanding reached at the 1984 meeting of the Council of Conservation Ministers. That meeting reached an agreement that the Commonwealth Government would fully consult with State and Territory governments in relation to seeking World Heritage listing for national parks. In a letter to the Honourable Barry Coulter, the Territory Minister for Mines and Energy, the Federal Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, Mr Cohen, specifically wrote:

Should the Commonwealth decide to pursue World Heritage listing on the former stage two area, your Government will be consulted in accordance with the CONCOM agreement prior to any approach being made to Paris.

No such consultation has taken place, and of course the Federal Government has set in train the procedure to have the area heritage listed. As a result of this lack of consultation, the Northern Territory Government has now decided that, in order to see that its views on the matter are heard, it will attempt to make representations to the World Heritage Committee in Paris this month. The Prime Minister has been informed of this planned action and has advised the Northern Territory Government of his view that under Article 34 of the World Heritage Convention the Committee can deal only with national governments. Clearly he does not want the full story to be put. In the light of that interpretation the Prime Minister has given a qualified and restricted indication that the Northern Territory Government may, in some indirect way, be able to present its case to the Committee. The Prime Minister said:

I would be prepared to consider submitting to the Committee supplementary documentation to reflect the view of the Northern Territory Government on the cultural and natural heritage values of the stage II area.

This contrasts starkly with the Commonwealth's invitation to the Tasmanian Government in 1983 to participate in its own right in relation to the Franklin Dam. It is by no means clear that the Prime Minister's offer would enable the Northern Territory Government to present its case in a compelling and unfettered way, and in view of this the Northern Territory Government has approached the World Heritage Committee directly requesting that it be invited by the committee, as a public organisation, to present its case and address particular problems surrounding stage 2 listing. This invitation would be in accord with Article 10(2) of the World Heritage Convention which enables the committee to invite interested parties to participate in its meetings.

In response to the Northern Territory Government's approach the World Heritage Committee has replied that the Northern Territory Government's telex has been brought to the attention of the Australian permanent delegation to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation for appropriate action. The inference which can be drawn from this response is that the World Heritage Committee will prove reluctant to initiate an invitation to the Northern Territory Government to participate in its own right. It seems to me that the intention expressed in the articles is that interested parties are able to present their own views on matters which are the subject of the Committee's deliberations. The problem here is that the Committee does not want to get involved in a dispute between the Australian Commonwealth and the Northern Territory.

Personally, I believe that regardless of the politics of the situation the Committee is obliged to hear the views of the Territory as an interested party. But assuming that it is not prepared to put its neck out and upset the Federal Government, the responsibility reverts to the Federal Government to support openly and unequivocally the Northern Territory Government's right to put its views independently to the Committee. The Federal Government should communicate that to the Committee without delay. One wonders why it has not already done so. Perhaps the Federal Government is just a bit concerned that the fraud which it is proposing to perpetrate on the World Heritage Committee will be disclosed. It may be worried that the committee will learn that while there are certainly areas of great beauty and cultural significance within stage 2, the vast majority of the of the area proposed to be listed is not worthy of the status proposed for it. Indeed, only this week two very eminent conservationists have indicated that to the Australian media.

In closing, I note that Senator Ryan has said that the Government will not retreat, that that is out of the question. The Northern Territory and those on this side of the Senate are asking that the World Heritage Committee and indeed the Australian Government give this whole question an open go, a fair go, because there is good reason why they should not rush into the listing of this area. The area should be open to multi-use, and I believe that can be carried out without any damage occurring. I repeat that it is the experience of the Northern Territory that there would be no damage to this beautiful spot within this part of the Kakadu National Park.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The World Heritage listing of all stages of Kakadu National Park is highly desirable and I hope that the Federal Government will stand firm in its long-standing intention to have it so listed. As far back as the Fox report of the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry in 1975 it was recommended that the whole of the area-that is, stages 1, 2 and 3-be nominated for World Heritage listing. This particular area meets all of the eight criteria laid down by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation to qualify for World Heritage listing, and there are very few places in the world that qualify for such listing under each of the eight categories. It is acknowledged as the biggest and most important tropical wetlands area in the southern hemisphere. By not protecting stage 2 from the ravages of mining we would allow that to be damaged for all time. As well as its biological importance, it contains rare and important examples of Aboriginal culture which have not been mentioned a greater deal in the debate yet, but those examples of wonderful age-old art forms are well acknowledged.

SPEECH.PARA: The rivers which flow through stage 2 are in their final stages, having come from stage 1. They are all part of the whole. It is most important that the whole area be considered as one system. It is ridiculous to try to remove stage 2 from the whole listing because the waters that flow from stage 1 will have a great impact on stage 2. The whole nation should value this beautiful area and should be very concerned that we passed on this heritage to future generations.

The whole debate is really about mining and the question that needs to be asked is what is the point of declaring an area a national park or indeed having it World Heritage listed if mining is to be allowed. That is the crux of the whole argument, and of course that concerns the Opposition, the National and Liberal parties, backed up by the mining lobbies. They are trying to grab back the opportunity to explore for minerals in stage 2, and the mineral they are most concerned about finding there, of course, is uranium. That is a very dangerous sort of mining to get into and it is one that we should look at very carefully indeed. The Northern Territory Government is very short-sightedly looking for dollars from mining rather than looking, as it should, to provide more jobs, and socially useful jobs, by encouraging carefully planned and monitored tourism which will allow more Australians as well as people from other countries to appreciate the magnificence of this region.

Mining is capital intensive and it is environmentally hazardous, particularly if we consider uranium mining which I believe is the major interest being pushed by the mining lobby. The present foray of Peko-Wallsend Limited to test its mining exploration lease is the real test for the Federal Government to prove its commitment, even through the courts of this country. Exploration leases which were put in place before the area was declared a national park should not be acted upon now because there will be a great temptation for future governments to allow leases to be given in those areas. That is why it is most important that this area be protected from the ravages of mining by its inclusion on the World Heritage List.

There are already several important uranium deposits, two of which are being mined in that area, but I am concentrating my comments mainly on the Ranger mine which is just outside the area excised from the park so that mining could continue. We need to look at the environmental impact of uranium mining, which would be the great threat to this whole area if the mining lobby, backed up as it is by development-oriented politicians, had its way and managed to exclude stage 2 from World Heritage listing. I think it is intent on doing this as quickly as possible before the bottom falls out of the uranium market. Even the so-called peaceful uses of uranium have been largely discredited, in the last year in particular, since there have been several very serious accidents, the one at Chernobyl being the better known of these accidents, but there have been many other accidents at nuclear power plants, which is descrediting even the so-called peaceful purposes of the use of this ore. The environmental and social costs of uranium mining are extremely high.

In the case of the Ranger uranium mine operated by Energy Resources of Australia Ltd there have been enormous problems in controlling the tailings. The problem at every stage of the nuclear industry is what to do with the radioactive leftovers. In this case the tailings dams have persistently overflowed their boundaries. The report just recently brought down from the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation on Ranger uranium and its water management system stated:
. . . 24 occurrences involving the water management system which have given rise to regulatory concern-
the word `occurrences' is the euphemism for an accidental release-
of which 16 related to failures in the tailings pipeline or tailings dam seepage collector lines.
Both the NLC and the Environment Centre considered that frequent spillages were in part due to Company attitudes and the lack of supervision and penalties.
Further on, it is stated:

The Committee believes that there are many areas of the Company's operations which warrant criticism. The Committee agrees with the Northern Land Council and the Northern Territory Environment Centre and others that the number of failures relating to the operation of the water management system is alarming. The Committee cannot accept that a Company which is located within an area of significant environmental value, claims to be as efficient as any operation in the world and claims to be one of the most regulated in the world, should have allowed the number of incidents to have occurred as have been reported . . .

The Committee further calls for a temporary cessation of operations until such time as the system is rectified. The particular system that is being referred to is the piping system to get rid of the radioactive contaminants. Many efforts have been made by Ranger to deal with this. It is always looking for the cheapest way out. The 1975 Fox inquiry recommended that the accumulation of excess water could be avoided by building additional retention ponds around the mine to allow the water to evaporate slowly. This would have the drawback of concentrating radioactive wastes. The Ranger management opposed this recommendation because it was expensive. It argued for the direct release of the water into the nearby Magela Creek. This creek runs into the East Alligator River, which in turn courses through the Kakadu National Park. So this does have a very relevant bearing on the argument that stage 2 should be nominated for World Heritage listing.

The latest plan the ERA has concocted to deal with these radioactive tailings-it has had constant problems ever since it started operating there-is to introduce a new dry method of dealing with contaminated tailings in an effort to relieve the controversy over the dam used to store the mine's wastes. It has just completed a 12-month trial of beaching, which means that it actually allows the contamination to dry out on the surface of the soil without having water covering it. This is even more alarming to conservationists as the dry tailings are known to emit high levels of radon. The problem has not been solved to any degree of satisfaction to either the Aboriginal people in the area who do not want the threat of the Magela Creek being contaminated, or to the satisfaction of environmentalists who are concerned about every stage of the Ranger uranium mine's operation and the consequences that actually has at the moment for contamination of stage 2 in Kakadu National Park. We should look at the uses to which the extracted uranium could be put.

I have already mentioned briefly the so-called peaceful purposes of the use of this ore which has come under a lot of criticism in very recent months. I am firmly opposed to the use of the nuclear fuel cycle except for medical purposes at the moment, which would be the only exclusion. I think we should be pouring our research dollars into finding ways of producing the radioisotopes which are necessary so that we do not have to rely on the nuclear fuel cycle. I am sure that if the research dollars were there, a way would have been found around that problem. That is a requirement which needs a very small amount of uranium and it is a very concentrated and very highly regulated aspect of the uranium industry. Apart from that, at every stage of the nuclear fuel cycle-from mining, through every stage of milling and transportation, right through to the production of nuclear power-there are enormous problems for the workers involved and for the environment. The main problem is that there has been no solution to the disposal of wastes. That is despite 30 years of intensive research on the part of the nuclear lobby which desperately wants to keep its industry going and to make it credible to the world's people, who are becoming increasingly concerned with the enormous amounts of nuclear waste we are piling up all around the world.

Apart from that so-called peaceful use to which this uranium could be put, we also have to allow for the possibility that Australian uranium will end up in nuclear weapons systems. This is despite all the safeguards that are written on paper. I do not care how many times the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) or the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) try to tell the people of Australia that our uranium does not end up in nuclear weapons. Most countries in the world say the same thing, yet there is an enormous amount of nuclear weapons proliferation. We have to allow for the fact that once Australian uranium enters the nuclear fuel cycle it is not separated out from other countries' uranium. There is no magic tag on it which says `for peaceful purposes only'. I think the confusion stems from the fact that safeguards are written on paper, but there is no way that we can prove that Australian uranium is clear, that it is pure and that radioactive leftovers the come from Australian uranium have not been involved in nuclear weapons production. We cannot prove that at all.

Nuclear weapons proliferation is one of the main problems facing the world at the moment. There is no way that the Australian Government or the Australian people should in any way be involved in helping towards that proliferation, unwitting though it may be. There are enough people around now who do understand the connections between the nuclear fuel cycle and the proliferation of nuclear weapons. The two things cannot be separated; they are all part of the same package. Indeed, the original Atoms for Peace program in the United States of America was a cover for the weapons producing industry in the first place. The nuclear energy which was promoted then was meant to be too cheap to meter and environmentally clean. Both of those advertising slogans have been proven to be absolutely unfounded. It is a very expensive form of energy and it is certainly not a clean form of energy. I think that the danger is that when there is a leak of radioactive contamination it cannot be smelt and it cannot be seen. People tend to think that it is clean, but of course its consequences are absolutely devastating, as the people of eastern and western Europe are finding out now to their horror and as they will continue to find out for the next 10 years in the wake of the disaster of the melt-down at the Chernobyl reactor in the Ukraine earlier this year.

There is no way that an Australian government of any political colour should allow mining to go on from any mine, particularly if it allows that to continue in a national park. It cannot go on if this is declared a World Heritage area, which is why it is most important that stage 2 is included on the World Heritage listing. I also think that it is most important that a basic statement is made as clearly as it can be that uranium mining in any part of Australia whatsoever is morally indefensible.

To conclude, I would like to say that the Northern Territory Government seems to be making a last ditch stand and concocting a sense of urgency about this debate when it has known that this was coming up. In fact, since 1975, if it cared to go back to the records of the Fox report, and certainly since 1981, it has had plenty of time to make its objections known. I think the Australian people wholly support the Government, except for some very highly development-oriented people in the Northern Territory who, as I said, should be looking into tourism rather than into mining. Apart from those few people with vested interests in the very influential and wealthy mining lobby most Australians would highly support the Government's proposal for stage 2 of the Kakadu National Park to be incorporated in the World Heritage List. I hope that that will be done without this ridiculous notion from the Northern Territory getting any further credibility.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —After listening to Senator Kilgariff and Senator Durack, I wonder what our political opponents would not sell to help their mining industry supporters. The Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) has outlined the history of the developments which led to the proposed listing. I would like to add one point to that history. The Government made a 1984 election commitment that this would be done. The Opposition is often putting up matters of public importance claiming supposed broken promises by this Government. Clearly, it does not want to know about those promises which are quickly fulfilled, and this is one of them.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ryan also pointed out that the Northern Territory Government neither owns nor manages Kakadu National Park. Indeed, I am very thankful for that because the Northern Territory Government seems to have a very strange understanding or knowledge of national parks in other parts of Australia or the world. This became very obvious on many occasions during the Senate National Resources Committee inquiry into the Kakadu region. National parks seem to be seen by many representatives of the Northern Territory Government as places where there should be little restriction on any land use, including agriculture, mining and other commercial enterprises, as long as what they see as beauty spots-very small areas-are preserved. Senator Ryan also alluded to the danger to the present World Heritage listing of stage 1 if the rest of the park were to be degraded by mining or some of these other activities. I point out that, if the World Heritage stages of the park were endangered, it would also be very detrimental to Australia's image as a nation which cares about its environmental and cultural heritage and carries out in those areas its responsibilities to the rest of the world. People elsewhere do notice. I was in Europe for Christmas 1983 and I was quite amazed by the number of people who were aware of what had happened in south-west Tasmania and what this Government had done to save the wilderness area of south-west Tasmania.

I come now to the allegations that stage 2 does not warrant World Heritage listing. I will be dealing with that in some detail but at this point I will again refer briefly to Mr Harry Butler, who reportedly called the proposed listing an attempted fraud-that is, if the Northern Territory News accurately reported what he said. Mr Harry Butler is well known to the general public as the producer and the central figure of a high quality series of programs about Australian wildlife. It is less generally known that he makes his living as a consultant to mining companies including, I understand, a permanent consultancy to West Australian Petroleum Pty Ltd. Some of us will remember his support of the Tasmanian Government during the Franklin Dam dispute. My memory is that the Tasmanian Government also retained him as a consultant. He supported the decision to build the Franklin Dam and destroy an area which now was World Heritage status. According to the Northern Territory News he is now a consultant to the Northern Territory Government on Kakadu. If he is a consultant to the Northern Territory and has been for any length of time either the Northern Territory does not listen to him or he has done a poor teaching job-I understand that he was originally trained as a teacher-because the Northern Territory Government's understanding of conservation principles is abysmal. Mr Butler's statement about attempted fraud appeared in Monday's Northern Territory News. He is also reported as saying:
Another problem with the Stage 2 listing bid was it would set a standard for `second-rate conservation material' and could affect Australia's future attempts to gain a listing for first-class sites.

It is hard to imagine what sites he would have had in mind, but it is interesting to note that he seems to have moderated those views. I understand that, in a video made for the Northern Territory, he concedes that the eastern part of stage 2 is valuable and that the western part has considerable importance as a buffer zone. Nevertheless, I believe that he might be better occupied going back to teaching.

What are the factors which justify World Heritage listing? Senator Ryan referred to the network of creeks which feed the wetlands of stage 1. I point out that these are the wetlands which were included in 1980 in the list of the Convention of Wetlands of International Importance especially as Waterfowl Habitat. The wetlands of stage 2 are of at least equal value and are an interconnected system with those of stage 1.

In terms of natural heritage, Kakadu National Park stage 2 is of outstanding, universal value for a large number of reasons. It improves the integrity of the currently listed stage 1 because it is biologically complementary to it. It contains representative samples of a wide range of ecosystems, particularly those with coastal swamps, tidal flats, flood plains and lowlands. It is a very large area and that ensures that the integrity of most of the ecosystem is maintained. This is why the notion of the Northern Territory Government that only beauty spots need to be conserved is such a nonsense. The vegetation is rich in variety and visually beautiful in many cases and includes species which are not found elsewhere. Indeed, botanists believe that there are still many undiscovered species in the area, some of which may have food or medicinal value as the Aboriginals found.

The bird life is very rich and varied in that area and comprises an estimated one-third of Australia's bird species. There is a wide diversity of mammals, reptiles, amphibians and invertebrates. I am no Harry Butler but when I was there two weeks ago I was delighted to find in a damp area, although it was the end of the dry season, large varieties of different sorts of frogs, geckos and other sorts of reptiles which could be easily seen and approached by people without fear. The area also provides a suitable habitat for some of Australia's endangered species, the most notable, of course, being the estuarine crocodile-I will not attempt to say its Latin name. In short, it provides a habitat for a wide range of rare or regionally endemic species of flora and fauna. The wetlands constitute one of Australia's major wetland regions and are frequented by very large numbers of a wide variety of water birds. Some of these water birds are migratory and come from other parts of Australia at different times of the year and also from other parts of the world, particularly Asia. They are an important wintering habitat for some of the Asiatic wading birds and they also act as dry season refuges for many of the local species.

One of the important aspects of the area is the availability of both wet and dry areas within stages 1 and 2 of the park so that wildlife, in extremes of climatic conditions, can move fairly easily from an area which perhaps has been inundated to an area where they can survive until the next season. Conversely, those that need the wet can migrate there. The flora and fauna in the park have interesting and scientifically important affinities with those of South-East Asia and New Guinea. This is important in the study of pre-history. As most honourable senators will be aware, there was once a land link there and this gives some clue as to the age of the separation of those two continents and what has happened in the meantime. In addition to scientific research and educational opportunities this natural heritage also provides an outstanding mecca for a wide range of active and passive visitor use and it is one of the main reasons for the tourist attraction of Kakadu National Park. In economic terms, I would say that in the long term that offers far more to the Northern Territory economy, particularly in terms of jobs, than any possible other use of the area, particularly mining.

Senator Ryan referred to tens of thousands of years of Aboriginal occupation. I point out that the Aboriginals who live in the area still carry out traditional practices, observe their religious ceremonies and pass on their knowledge to the younger generation. Similarly, the younger generation is being taught how to look after the environment and how to conserve the rock art. There are many Aboriginal sites of significance, including sacred sites. The archaeological sites of stage 2 represent one of the world's major cultural heritage assets. Many people go to see the ancient art sites in France. There is something to see here at Kakadu which is possibly far more important. It is expected that several thousand archaeological sites will be recorded in Kakadu. One of the pieces of work being carried out at the moment by officers of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service is in seeking out those sites, classifying them and drawing them to the attention of people so that those sites can be conserved. Similarly, there are many old camp sites that provide some knowledge of the way the Aboriginal people lived in times past, their development of artefacts, their food gathering methods, their cooking methods and so on. Most of these sites are relatively intact. In particular, one of the sites excavated in stage 2 has provided some of the world's oldest evidence of the technology of edge-ground axes and the preparation of pigments 18,000 years ago. I find that quite mind-boggling.

My time is running out and I just want finally to read a quotation from what the World Heritage Committee, a United Nations body, noted at the time of the inscription of stage 1 on the World Heritage List:

. . . the World Heritage Committee noted Australia's intention to proclaim additional areas in the Alligator Rivers Region as part of the National Park. The Committee recommended that such additional areas should also be included in the World Heritage Listing.
Finally, I would like to say that I and the Government will certainly be pressing ahead with this listing.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Durack's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Copies of the Industries Assistance Commission annual report were not available until it was tabled, and I have not had a chance to examine it in any detail. However, it is of considerable importance to us, given the agreed importance of the strengthening of manufacturing industry in Australia. The Industries Assistance Commission is a fairly contentious body, and elements of manufacturing industry describe it in very unflattering terms as an industries destruction commission. I think that is very severe judgment on a body which, after all, does no more than report to government within the terms of reference that are given to it.
In a very brief contribution this afternoon I will simply refer to a number of the comments which are made in the report and which I think are of importance. On page 3 the report states:

What is clear is that, in a world of pervasive and unpredictable change, no particular economic structure can remain competitive for long; and no blueprint for an appropriate future structure can be designed with any confidence. Recent events have demonstrated the overriding importance of achieving a flexible and innovative economy.

I think that is a very important statement to be made in Australia, for the sorts of reasons that were indicated in the statement that was made today by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, when he reported on his visit to Japan. One of the points made by him was that the Japanese economy is being forced to restructure in quite significant ways. Some industries are having to move out of Japan; new industries are having to be established; the economy is having to be directed in new courses to meet the Japanese situation, which, of course, is quite different from ours-its exports are an embarrassment, but it has economic problems, nonetheless, because its industries are no longer appropriate in all cases to its economy.

If the strongest economy in the world has to face problems of restructuring, it needs to be acknowledged that the Australian economy, which is in such a parlous state, as evidenced by the extraordinary continuing high deficit in our balance of payments, has to face the need for change. To the extent that the Government is trying to promote that change, it will have the Opposition's support. The unfortunate fact, as I tried to indicate in a debate earlier this afternoon, is that, whilst acknowledging the need for change, the Government is tending not to acknowledge the need for rapid change. In further cementing some of the traditional arrangements and making, for example, the removal of work practices in the heavy engineering industry dependent upon quite complex negotiations, drawing up sets of rules and having union participation as against the participation of the work force directly in a particular plant it is leaving in place structures which are not in the interests of manufacturing recovery in this country.

We require the maximum co-operation between employer and employee, not least in manufacturing establishments. It is only when we have a high degree of trust, co-operation and interaction between employer and employee that we will get the flexible and innovative economy to which the IAC is referring. I welcome the fact that the Industries Assistance Commission draws attention to `the overriding importance of achieving a flexible and innovative economy'. Those words have to be accepted as putting upon us an imperative to accept and promote change and be prepared to adapt at both the management and work force levels.
Later in the report, in discussing the contribution of the Commission to a more competitive industry structure, it proposes:
. . . a separate stream of broad inquiries which would focus on removing impediments to industry competitiveness.

The Commission suggests inquiries in such areas as the effects on the economy of regulations, the various taxation measures, and controls and administrative arrangements applying to transport and handling of goods. Those sorts of inquiries are important. What is perhaps even more important is to accept that in all those areas change is needed, perhaps more quickly than lengthy inquiries would permit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Senate would be aware, some time ago I moved a notice of motion suggesting that it might be more appropriate for the Industries Assistance Commission rather than a royal commission to conduct an investigation into the important issue of grain handling in Australia. I did this for a number of reasons but principally because of the speed with which the IAC could get on with an inquiry and bring forward a report. As we all know, Australia is a major producer of grains, such as wheat, barley and sorghum, and is responsible for about 20 per cent of sales on world markets. Over 90 per cent of this domestic production is exported. In 1985-86 wheat alone was responsible for exports worth around $3,600m, or 11 per cent of Australia's export revenue. This export performance was achieved virtually without any government support.

SPEECH.PARA: I believed at the time that there were a number of reasons for a royal commission not being the appropriate body to carry out such an important investigation. The first and foremost reason was that the time involved in setting up a commission and the time taken for it to report would be too long, given the urgency of this issue. Already more than half a year has elapsed since the Government proposed this inquiry, and only now is the commission starting to move. It is interesting to note that the Government has not budgeted for a royal commission inquiry into grain transport and handling for 1986-87. Had the IAC been asked to report on grain handling, I believe the Government could well have had an interim report at this stage, with a final report early in the new year. The Government is not really interested in getting a quick decision.

As all honourable senators would know, I have been a critic of the IAC, but I think it is about time the Government asked it to get off the backs of manufacturing in this country and to look at some of the other important issues. I refer to grain handling, the problems on the wharves, the transport problems and the dislocations that they cause and problems arising from work practices.

I cannot lose this opportunity to comment on the future of the textile, clothing and footwear industries. Few commentators seem to realise that these industries are in the process of being, and will continue to be, restructured. I will give a few examples. Since the announcement of the current sectoral plan in mid-1980, the industries have invested millions of dollars in upgrading their plant and equipment; they have introduced high technology plant, increased productivity quite significantly-above the general industry average-provided employment, particularly for females, and maintained an industry base in many country and regional areas. It is very important because it is decentralised and it has an ability to meet the challenge of increased exposure to import competition, provided that a degree of predictability is accorded by current quota arrangements.

To discard such a balanced approach in favour of an IAC preferred option will have a devastating effect on these industries. While it is important that the TCF industries become more efficient and more exposed to international competition, it is also extremely important that the Government recognise the social and regional significance of these industries and the implications for employment. Employment in the industries is approximately 120,000, or 10 per cent of the total work force. About 70,000 women are employed. Is it right that the prosperity of whole communities, whole towns, should now be threatened by the potential demise of these very important industries?

When the present arrangements cease in 1988 we must have developed a set of assistance programs which accommodates three features: It must be predictable and gradual, but there must be meaningful adjustment; positive measures must be taken to encourage modernisation and plant consolidation and efficiency; and measures must be designed to ease the hardships of those people who are made redundant by technological change and rationalisation. Unfortunately, my time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to this paper I want to say that aviation certainly plays a very important part in Australia, and indeed throughout the world. Because of the vast distances that we have to cover in this country, people have to use aeroplanes to save time. As politicians, of course, we all use them regularly and we are certainly given very good service by the airlines in this country. I think their safety record is something that we should commend and something for which we should all be very grateful indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: While speaking to this report, I do want to make some comments about the Brisbane Airport, which is of great importance to the aviation industry in my State. I must say that the Government is building an excellent domestic airlines terminal in Brisbane at a cost of $350m, and I know that that will be of very great use to Queensland. I emphasise, though, that there is a great need for a general aviation terminal.

On the matter of the international terminal in Brisbane, I asked a question of Senator Gietzelt on 15 October and, although the Minister was going to seek a reply from the Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris), I have not had one. I asked that day whether it was correct that the Government had decided not the proceed with the building of a new terminal as part of a hotel complex at Brisbane. I asked whether the Minister could give the reasons why this decision was made and whether it was a fact that the Government claims that it does not have the money to build a new international terminal in Brisbane, despite the growth of tourism in the State and despite the fact that Expo 88 is to be held there. I asked the question: If that was the case, should not the Government be encouraging the private sector to build the international air terminal for it at no cost at all to the taxpayers so that it will be ready for Expo 88? I believe-and I am sure the people of Queensland also believe-that it is really a shame that private enterprise is not being allowed to construct a first class terminal in conjunction with the building of a hotel. I think perhaps the Government might be scared that that might be privatising airports.

I say that Brisbane needs a first class air terminal of the same standard as its new domestic terminal. The current terminal in Brisbane really is just a temporary facility, and I am sure that those honourable senators who have been there will realise this. On 9 November the Minister for Aviation, the Hon. Peter Morris, announced that the Federal Government would spend $1 1/2m to improve Brisbane's international terminal. I wonder whether that might be just throwing good money after bad. With Expo 88 coming up and with Queensland having 45 per cent of all new tourist projects and continuing growth and development because of the good, strong Government in Queensland, I believe it is vital that Queensland get a good international airport.

Also a few other problems arise from retaining the present international terminal and not building a new one. Actually, the Australian Federation of Air Pilots say that there will be long delays on the ground before jets can take off, as aircraft wheel assemblies would overheat while they are taxiing out. It also maintains that the distance from the current international terminal to the runway is too long. Also the air traffic controllers said that it was full of World War II style technology and appeared designed not to handle traffic. These are problems that I think we ought to be worried about and, as the air traffic controllers very correctly refuse to compromise passenger safety, there will no doubt be further delays for aircraft landing and taking off. We know that there will be, indeed, congestion at the airport when the Expo comes around. At present it allows for only 1,700 passengers to be processed every hour but we know that there will be many more passengers than that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 November I was given leave to continue my remarks later. I was discussing the excessive costs imposed by the cost recovery scheme on aircraft, particularly in the outback. To continue, the bureaucrats in Canberra who thought up the cost recovery scheme failed to realise that for many private aircraft owners in the outback their aircraft are a means of communication. For those in the pastoral industry who use aircraft for aerial mustering, those in the mining industry and many others, the aircraft is much like a car is for Australians in the cities and towns. It is not a luxury; it is a necessity. Small aircraft are part of a vital communications link in the outback and many of the services they provide are to remote Aboriginal settlements and communities, bringing goods and supplies and providing contact between these communities. Of course, with the considerable number of light aircraft that are used in the outback there has to be a means by which people learn to fly. We have flying schools, particularly in Darwin, Batchelor and Alice Springs, but the number is beginning to diminish as costs are becoming too high to train people to fly. This is a pity because, as I have said, aircraft in the outback are a necessity.

SPEECH.PARA: The overall impact of this cost recovery scheme is bound to impose greater financial burdens on aircraft owners and operators. The larger operators may be able to absorb the costs by passing them on, and the smaller operators could try to do the same thing. In both cases it means increases in air fares for travellers, and when people in Darwin are already paying close to $1,000 for a return fare to an eastern State destination further increases would be the final straw. It means that commercial charter viability is cut back by a downturn in demand with less use of aircraft overall. On the small private operators who rely on aircraft as a link with regional towns or other stations or properties, or a necessary piece of machinery for the operation of their business, the cost will fall on the operator. In view of the facilities available, particularly in the outback, it is plain that the levy is heavy and is, to quite a degree, unwarranted.

Whilst the aircraft industry, charter and private, is under seige, at least there is one bright spot on the horizon in the north and the outback and remote areas. I refer to the staff of the meteorological services and the flight service staff, whose assistance and courtesy are a byword to the people of the outback. It gives me some pleasure at least to recognise them in this brief speech.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: THE HUMAN RIGHTS OF AUSTRALIAN-BORN CHILDREN WHOSE PARENTS ARE DEPORTED

That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This paper on Australia's population trends and prospects has been prepared by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. It is a very interesting publication and it is well worth reading, as it contains some enlightening facts and figures on what is happening in Australian society today. I should like to single out just some of the trends which are shown up by the paper.

SPEECH.PARA: The first of these trends is that Australia's population growth rate has been declining for most of the post-war period. I think that that is a fact of which most of us are aware. It is a result of a lower natural increase and low migration rates. It is interesting to see that the reasons for the low natural growth are put down to a number of factors, including the tendency towards smaller families, from an average of six children in the middle of the nineteenth century to 2.5 children in recent years. The period between marriage and the birth of the first child is also increasing, with, as the report states, couples waiting to develop a better economic base before having children. There is also the increase in the tendency towards voluntary childlessness to take into account.

We must ask ourselves why people are having fewer children. We may find that in many cases the answer is that having more children costs too much. Many couples have to think very hard about having children. Can they afford children? This reflects very poorly on the way in which the family has been treated. Its needs have been ignored in very many ways, and the time has come for Governments to pay attention to the needs of the basic unit of our society.

I turn now to another aspect of the reduction in our growth rate-the low immigration rate. Immigration is a very important element in Australia's population growth strategy, and the report states that in the absence of immigration, natural increase is projected to reach zero growth rate by about 2010. Australia has become a truly multicultural nation, with one in five Australians being born outside Australia. In the last decade, with the problems which have developed in Indo-China we have, as a nation, accepted responsibility for providing homes to some of those fleeing the conflicts in that area. However, I am concerned by the recent indications coming from the office of the Minister that there is a change of attitude to the plight of these people in the Federal Government's approach to refugees. I understand that the Government is concerned to stem the flow of what it terms economic refugees, as opposed to political refugees. By this I understand that it is the Minister's concern that those fleeing, from Kampuchea, say, are fleeing only because Australia offers the prospect of a better social and economic future. But that appraisal fails to take account of the ongoing hostilities in that part of the world, the poor conditions in the refugee camps, and the perilous situation in which many of these people live. Australia has an ongoing responsibility to these people, as have other nations, and we should meet that responsibility.

What needs to be stressed is that it is not a responsibility which imposes burdens and brings no benefits-quite the contrary. Australia has benefited enormously from immigration-from the European post-war immigration to the more recent immigration of Indo-Chinese refugees and others. They have all added to the depth of Australian society with their social, cultural, educational and economic contributions to the nation. For example, in the Northern Territory, which I represent in this place, we have a multicultural society that is probably unequalled in any other State. Our population is new and young, and it presents an example that many other areas would do well to follow. In fact, over 90 nations are represented in the Northern Territory. It is a tremendous thing to see the development that is taking place. I often say that looking at the Northern Territory now, with all its multicultural people, one can see a view of what Australia will probably be by the year 2000.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of the Committee of Review of Migrant and Multicultural Programs and Services

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 November, on motion by Senator Reid:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recommend to the Senate the Jupp Review of Migrant and Multicultural Programs and Services. It is a very well thought out report. It puts forward a number of proposals which I support thoroughly. The main report supports the strengthening of Commonwealth control and development of the English as a second language program. However, it seems that the Cabinet has not read this report or taken much notice of it, because at the same time as we are considering this report, the Government is cutting down that program. It is also important to note that the Jupp report recommends the keeping of an independent institute of multicultural affairs. It waxes lyrical about the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs-it says that it is needed to continue its research and education functions-as well as the creation of a new Office of Ethnic Affairs within the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to monitor and co-ordinate progress towards access and equity by departments, authorities and State and local governments and other agencies, and the establishment of a new Parliamentary Standing Committee on Multicultural and Ethnic Affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems that the Government was intent on pre-empting the report, although I believe that it new of its contents. This seems to be part of a general program by the Hawke Government to dismantle completely multiculturalism and its recognition within the Public Service. I am very disappointed at this trend, but I am fairly heartened at the support that apparently will be forthcoming from the Liberal and National parties to save one of the aspects of multiculturalism which I believe to be extremely important-that is, the Special Broadcasting Service-by not supporting the merger of the SBS with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.

As well as totally ignoring the contents of the contents of the report, which is called `Don't settle for less', the Government is going about closing down at least three of the regional offices of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. This was extremely disappointing to me. The Albury-Wodonga, Rockhampton and Launceston regional offices were closed on 30 September this year. I managed to obtain some answers in the Estimates Committee on this matter. At that stage the Government believed that it would also close down the Newcastle, Wollongong and Geelong offices. However, I believe that representations from the more multiculturally minded members of Caucus have succeeded in stopping that operation. It is a pity that the Government having commissioned such an important report, is going in the opposite direction. I commend the report to the Senate as an important milestone in moving forward towards a sensible handling of our multicultural population, and I would point out that some 45 per cent of Australians are of non-Anglo Celtic descent. I recommend that the Government read the report throughly and recognise that its electoral future depends on that 45 per cent of the community. This Government will find it difficult to get back into power if it continues to kick in the guts migrants and people it thinks will not kick back, as has happened just recently.
