SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly on the Aussat annual report tabled in the Senate on 11 November. It is a most interesting report on Australia's communications system. People in the cities, the country towns and in the outback are entering a very exciting period. The advent of the Aussat satellite operating above Australia will bring communication in so many ways to the people-and, of course, I am particularly interested in the people in the outback. The Chairman of Directors of Aussat, in his letter introducing the report, says:

SPEECH.PARA: Potential customers have responded to the technical and commercial opportunities created by the satellite system. The challenge now lies with the further development of telecommunications policy and regulatory issues to ensure that Australian gains the full range of potential benefits from the Aussat satellite system.

It is good to see that close association is being developed between Aussat and the Australian Telecommunications Commission. Both authorities which are responsible for communications in Australia can bring immense value to Australia. It is interesting to note from the report:
Separate contracts have been executed with the Queensland Government and a number of its agencies to establish a state based communications network in Queensland for Government services.
Perhaps the report is referring to an interesting experiment that is now taking place at the Mount Isa School of the Air by way of satellite. The leaflet on it says:

In a major breakthrough for distance education, eight students from outback north west Queensland are taking part in a high-tech trial using satellites and computers. The year 6 students, all veterans of the School of the Air, are linked to Aussat and can talk to each other and their teachers instantly-a far cry from the days of hand-held radio and horse and buggy travel.

The specially chosen year 6 class of 8 children from various parts of outback Queensland have this voice and data satellite network. They also view a regular television program transmitted from the Brisbane studios of the Department of Education at Ashgrove and talk with the studio presenters via the satellite. It is pointed out that there has been a very noticeable change in the children who use this high-tech equipment. Instead of the noise and static of their familiar high frequency radio lessons, they now have a voice link of telephone quality with classmates and teachers. This is extremely good.

I wonder what will happen when this experiment ends in December this year. Children of the outback-I do not put this forward as a criticism-are still not getting from Aussat what it was thought they would get when the idea was first put forward; namely, a voice frequency as well as television operation. I do not think Aussat has been able to extend itself to the role that was originally envisaged. One finds in many places a resistance to purchasing the necessary equipment because voice facilities are not included. I hope that to meet the future needs of outback children Aussat will be able to bring in the full range of facilities. That will mean that the purchase of dishes will increase. At the same time I hope that children will have the advantage of high-tech voice production which will be so essential for the School of the Air of the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I, too, commend the Aussat annual report. It is well presented and issues from an organisation which has been very professionally run. I was interested to read the highlights of the year for Aussat. At this stage the first two satellites have been successfully launched and the third has been built and is ready for launching; it will serve the Pacific region. The commercial services started in October 1985 and the second set of services on 1 January 1986. In fact, the organisation has now marketed the majority capacity of the first two satellites and this work is either contracted or committed. The process that is now going on relates to the planning of the second generation satellites, the lifetime of which is around seven years. We should be thinking about the new types of technology that can be carried through this type of communication media. Australia has been first in developing the remote area HACBSS system-the Homestead and Community Broadcasting Satellite Service-which is making inland Australia accessible to effective media communication.

SPEECH.PARA: I join Senator Kilgariff in commending the distance education program and hope that that will develop further. It is to be hoped that more material will be developed for that program so that joint systems using modern technology such as compact discs, cassette tapes and computers in conjunction with satellite communication, will give children from the outback a much better chance of getting the same type and quality of education that Australian students have come to expect in our cities.

The second generation system's planning is well advanced, with the first launch of this generation scheduled in 1991-92. I hope that by then the various satellite launching programs in the United States will be back on line after the disasters which struck the space shuttle project.

TALK.START.PARA: —I bet you we end up using the Chinese launcher.

—As Senator Puplick just suggested, we may in fact end up using the Chinese launching program. In fact, it may be worthwhile considering the type of program I heard about when I was up in northern Queensland. I believe that the Government should think about satellite launching from our soil and offering rocket launching on a sub-contract basis. We need to move into the space era because it is here to stay. Whether space technology will be used in the way in which satellites in this current generation are being used, it will still be part of our civilisation-if we still have a civilisation and have not been destroyed by nuclear bombs or various other hazards-whatever happens in the forthcoming years. This is something that Australia must recognise. We must be part of any developments in space, even if it is just in the development of ground stations, for which we have some potential. We should be encouraging Aussat a lot more to use the facilities of our Australian industry in the same way as I have urged the Government to encourage the Overseas Telecommunications Commission and Telecom Australia to do exactly that. I believe that Aussat is to be commended. This is a well-presented annual report and I recommend it as light reading for honourable senators.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 November, on motion by Senator Sheil:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to the statement that was tabled by the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) on the new subsidiary company to be known as Telecom Australia (International) Ltd. This is a very interesting statement because it indicates the developments of Telecom Australia and its activities, not only in Australia but now also in various countries overseas. This new development reaching into other countries will be very beneficial for Australia and will bring interaction between those countries and Australia. Already we have Radio Australia, which has been extremely beneficial to continued liaison with and development and knowledge of the countries it reaches. Indeed, when one travels through Indo-China and various parts of South East Asia, one sees just what Radio Australia has gained for this country. I believe that, in reaching out, Telecom will also be able to bring about continued closer developments and associations with those countries.

SPEECH.PARA: It is good to see that there is an appreciation of Australian technology in those countries of South East Asia. Indeed, this technology will bring about an increase in throughput. By throughput I mean the construction of equipment in Australia. This will mean that turnover will increase and the technology will be more efficient in the years to come. I believe also that when this new company comes into being not only will it provide better communications with these countries, particularly to our north, but it will also mean that the new technology which can be developed in the next few years will have an immense effect on the people of the outback. As I indicated earlier, this is beginning to occur already with the Aussat satellite. I believe that Telecom's improved techniques in communications in the outback are extremely beneficial. About two weeks ago I was on the border of Western Australia and the Northern Territory, not far from Kununurra, and there was a ceremony there for the linking of telephones around Australia. Not only are we seeing an improvement in communications in towns and cities but we are also beginning to see, through the widespread development of Telecom in the outback, the people of the bush being brought into much closer contact with those in the towns and cities of Australia. Not so long ago one had to wait for hours on radio telephones and it was a competition to see who could get the line when so many other people wanted to make calls. One would have to sit alongside the radio telephone for hours. While this is continuing now, there is a planned development which will mean that in the next few years, practically everyone in the outback will be able to have telephone communication which brings them immediately in touch with their cousins in the cities and in other States.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 May 1985, on motion by Senator Chaney:
That the Senate take note of the speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 May 1985 Senator Graham Richardson rose in this place to make a personal explanation regarding allegations which had once again surfaced in regard to the so-called Enmore conspiracy case. On that occasion I have absolutely no doubt that Senator Richardson told the truth, but as we now know, following the publication of the Domican tapes, it may not have been the whole truth. Today is an opportunity for Senator Richardson and other members of the Australian Labor Party, particularly those from New South Wales, to address the Senate once again in regard to the Enmore scandal and this time to give us the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth.

SPEECH.PARA: On 31 October 1986 Senator Chaney put out a Press statement in response to the publication of certain allegations regarding the affairs of the Enmore branch of the Australian Labor Party. Senator Chaney drew attention to the fact that these allegations involved the reputation of a very senior member of the ALP and a very significant member of the Senate, Senator Richardson. Senator Chaney said in his Press statement:
That is particularly the case, given the fact that Senator Richardson obviously would like to join the Federal Ministry when Senator Grimes steps down.

With the very real prospect that Senator Richardson may become a Minister in the Hawke Government, it is even more important there be no lingering doubt about the propriety of his actions in the Enmore case.

That is the matter before the Senate for discussion at the moment. On 2 April 1985 the Enmore conspiracy case was the principal topic of discussion on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio program AM. It related to a program previously screened in the United Kingdom which has been made by the British Broadcasting Corporation's Mr Tom Mangold. The ABC reporter said:
All of the accused-
that is, the people accused of offences arising from the various activities of the Enmore branch-

were associated in one way or another with the Party's right wing machine. One of them was a self-confessed political thug, Tommy Domican. Recently the BBC's Tom Mangold was in Australia to produce a television documentary on organised crime and political corruption in this country, and in an interview yet to be shown in Australia, Tommy Domican explained why the prosecution case against him and the others collapsed.
Tom Mangold: How many witnesses did the prosecution have?
Tommy Domican: About 80, 85, something like that.
Tom Mangold: What happened when the case was heard?
Tommy Domican: The witnesses had a lapse in memory.
Tom Mangold: What happened in between?
Tommy Domican: We were able to get transcripts of most of their accusations they levelled at us. We were able to get a copy of them and, which helped us to win the case.
Tom Mangold: How did it help you win the case?
Tommy Domican: It's good if you go into court and you know what the person said against you.
Tom Mangold: Were some of these witnesses visited?
Tommy Domican: Yes.
The transcript proceeds along that general line. At one stage Domican, in relation to how the material came into his hands and how the case was eventually resolved, said this:

It can only be done really and truly by the powers to be, and the powers to be was the Labor Party in the State. We could not have got found guilty. Had we have got found guilty, very high-up officials of the Labor Party would've fell, who were also involved in the rigging of that.
Tom Mangold then said:
Did you let this be known?
Domican replied:
Oh yeah, my word.

That is a very serious set of allegations. As honourable senators will see in a few moments, I want to deal with the way in which the legal side of the Enmore case was handled. But that last part of Mr Domican's comments, implying that he had let it be known that there were potential problems for members of the Australian Labor Party had he and his colleagues been found guilty, simply passed, as it were, at that stage until on 9 November 1986, almost a year and a half later, the National Times on Sunday produced what it purports to be transcripts of discussions which it is alleged involved Mr Domican and Senator Richardson. The printed transcript, which appeared in the National Times on Sunday, has a number of sections, one of which indicates that Mr Domican referred to a conversation with a person who is simply identified in the transcript published as `R'. Mr Domican said, basically: `I hope you are not going to sell me down the river'. The transcript then reads:
R: I'm not selling you down the drain.
Domican: Well mate, that's my go, I don't
R: Look Domican . . .
Domican: Well, I'm telling you straight. If he's going to f-ing sell us down the drain he might f-ing join us.
R: Ah . . .
Domican: I've some time for Harrison, right?
R: Righto.
Domican then warns the person alleged to be Richardson:
Don't f- around.
R: No way, Tommy.
Domican: Righto.

We see elsewhere in that publication an allegation that Senator Richardson had given an undertaking to intervene with the then Premier of New South Wales to obtain legal aid for Mr Domican in the pursuit of cases which were pending, and in particular the Enmore conspiracy case. This new publication by the National Times of the alleged tapes raises once again the whole question of the conduct of the Enmore case. On 15 May 1985 Senator Richardson read into Hansard the text of a letter which he had addressed to all members of the then New South Wales Government, basically saying to them that the Labor Party in New South Wales wished them to be aware of the fact that it was the Labor Party's view that the Cabinet of the day should intervene to ensure that the police did not pursue their inquiries into the Enmore conspiracy case. Senator Richardson's letter says, in part:

We therefore call upon the responsible Ministers of the N.S.W. Government, the Attorney-General, Frank Walker, QC, MP, and the Minister for Police, Peter Anderson, MP, to withdraw those charges which have been laid against ALP members in respect of internal ALP affairs.

That was a clear attempt to put pressure on Ministers of the Crown, including the first law officer of the State of New South Wales, to intervene in the judicial processes in New South Wales to ensure that prosecutions not continue against members of the Labor Party for offences which were regarded as internal ALP matters. As we know, the case in fact did proceed to hearing, and it was heard before Magistrate Mr Bruce Brown. As I have previously indicated, the 80 of 85 witnesses previously scheduled to appear and give evidence all had, individually and collectively, a lapse of memory. They suddenly could not remember what it was that they were going to tell the court.

TALK.START.PARA: —All 85?

—All 85 suddenly had this collective amnesia. Some of them, as Mr Domican admits, presumably had been visited on this occasion, not to help jog their memory but in order to help suppress their memory. As a result the case was dismissed. It was dismissed by Mr Brown on the basis that no evidence was put before him because of this collective amnesia on the part of the witnesses. The magistrate, speaking from the bench, indicated that he regarded the matter as so serious that there ought to be further investigations.

SPEECH.PARA: In May 1985 a number of articles appeared in the Press in which Mr Brown's decision was attacked as being wrong in law. It was suggested that the magistrate should not have dismissed the charges and that it should have been his decision that the matter be pursued. Various legal authorities, including the decision of the New South Wales Court of Appeal in Wentworth v. Rodgers, were subsequently analysed. There is no doubt in my mind that the magistrate was wrong in law. A letter dated 10 November 1986 over the signature of the New South Wales Police Commissioner, J. K. Avery, addressed to Mr Paciullo, the Minister for Police and Emergency Services in New South Wales, further confirms this. The Police Commissioner in his letter to the Police Minister stated in reference to the Solicitor-General, Ms Mary Gaudron:

Subsequently, the Solicitor-General on 23 July, 1985 and 31 July, 1985 addressed the Enmore case and a number of peripheral matters. In respect of the charges relating to the books of the Enmore Branch, she said, `In my view the Magistrate erred in dismissing the charges on the ground which he did.'

I put it to the Senate that there remains the residual problem as a result of this Enmore business that the matter has never satisfactorily been dealt with. The Sydney Morning Herald in its editorial on 4 April 1985 called for a full investigation of the extraordinary features of the Enmore case. I believe that the publication of the alleged tapes in the National Times last weekend revives very clearly the legitimate concern that people have about the Enmore case and the need for some form of inquiry into the allegations of which, once again, have surfaced from a case which clearly will not go away until it has been given satisfactory explanation and satisfactory analysis.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you doubting the accuracy of the tapes?

—Senator Tate asks me a question about the accuracy of the tapes. Let me remind Senator Tate that that was the tired, tawdry line that his front bench served up in this Senate month after month about the Age tapes, was it not? It was the same tawdry line that was served up on every occasion: `Can you verify, can you justify, can you prove?' The tapes were dismissed, were they not, by Senator Gareth Evans, by Mr Lionel Bowen and by the whole of the Australian Labor Party's front bench as worthless, not worth pursuing and not worth investigating. I said on that occasion as I will say on this occasion that, once again, that is not going to be a good enough excuse to cover up what are serious allegations if people have nothing to hide. Here is the Labor Party rabbiting over the country about the Australia Card, `the only people with anything to fear are people who have something to hide'. The only people with anything to fear in the Enmore business are the people with something to hide. So let them apply their own principles on this particular matter, let them have an investigation and let the truth be discovered. Let it be discovered by proper inquiry, with proper powers conducted by proper persons.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of other matters arise on this issue. They require us to seek some answers for instance as to the relationship between Senator Richardson and Mr Domican. On 17 February 1984 Mr Domican swore a statutory declaration. He stated:

I Thomas Christopher Domican of Croydon Park, in the State of NSW do solemnly and sincerely declare as follows: on 17 February 1984 that I have known Warren Anderson for approximately three years and am currently an unfinancial member of the NSW branch of the ALP.

An agreement was reached between myself and Graham Richardson, General Secretary of the NSW branch and Warren Anderson whereby Anderson paid me $20,000 a year to work for Graham Richardson in return for preferential treatment for Mr Anderson within the Labor Party. I understood this to mean that Mr Anderson would be given access and favours by Labor Party controlled local government councils in the areas in which he wished to develop.
Although I was being paid by Anderson, I was actually employed by Richardson to do what he requested which involved, generally, recruiting members to join the Labor Party.

At one lunch in 1982 in a Dixon Street restaurant, Anderson said to Richardson that he wanted to buy land adjoining his place to build a heliport and Richardson replied: ``I will see what I can do and get back to you.'' He added he would have to discuss the matter with the Minister for Planning and Environment, who I'm fairly sure was Mr Bedford at the time.

I was paid directly by Anderson in his office by cheque from Owsten Nominees (No 2) Pty Ltd or Coles New World. At that time he and Richardson frequently saw each other at lunches discussing Anderson's business.

On one occasion I was waiting for Richardson in his Sussex Street offices. He had returned after 4.30 p.m. and remarked, referring to large sums of money, ``Anderson's kicked in some dough. Hang on a minute''. I asked him how much and he replied the sum was $40,000.
And I make this solemn declaration conscientiously believing the same to be true and by virtue of the provisions of the ``Oaths Act of 1900-1953''.

It is signed by Mr Domican. One is entitled to know whether, in fact, that is a fabrication by a man who is a rogue, a fraud and a liar or whether it constitutes a serious question which goes to the relationship between a member of this place and a person who has been described in very adverse terms by royal commissioners and by commissions of inquiry.

A number of matters arise which go back to the days of the Balmain area of the Australian Labor Party, to the affairs of the East Rozelle branch of the Labor Party, to the bashing of Mr Peter Baldwin, then a member of the State upper House and now a member of the House of Representatives. They go to the question of the relationship between senior members of the Labor Party, including Senator Richardson, with people such as Danny Casey. There has never been any denial of the relationship between Senator Richardson and Danny Casey; there has never been any denial that Casey lent Senator Richardson money which was repaid; and there has never been any denial that Senator Richardson's wife was employed by a company in which Casey had a particular involvement-the Balmain Welding Company, a company well known for its activities in illegal drug trafficking and which was an employer of a notorious criminal by the name of Stan `the man' Smith. All of these matters are discussed at length in the report of the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking in New South Wales conducted by the Hon. Mr Justice Woodward. They are matters of public record. We know from parts of Mr Justice Woodward's inquiry that people, including quite notorious criminals, were involved with meetings and with this particular company and they met in particular hotels such as the Sackville Hotel. There were a number of occasions on which people of a most unsavoury nature, many of whom had notorious criminal records, who were met at that hotel by Senator Richardson. There is no denial of that and indeed I am prepared, if Senator Richardson says so, to accept that that was a perfectly ordinary, perfectly legitimate meeting taking place with nothing more to be imputed to it.

For instance, we know that on 18 February 1977 in its meeting the New South Wales administrative committee of the Labor Party named Edward Paul Delaney as the initiator of an incident in which people had been beaten up at a Labor Party meeting. Before Mr Woodward's inquiry in 1980, Casey described Delaney as a fairly close friend of his, one whom he knew had been charged with attempted murder arising out of a stabbing at the Sackville Hotel. We know that Senator Richardson said that he had met this same Delaney at a meeting of the Balmain branch of the Labor Party and on one occasion in the Sackville Hotel when Senator Richardson was there. That is in the transcript of evidence given before Mr Justice Woodward. We know that there is still a series of allegations about the conduct of members of the Australian Labor Party arising out of iterim report No. 2 of the Royal Commission of Inquiry into the Activities of the Nugan Hand Group conducted by His Honour Mr Justice Stewart, involving allegations about members of both houses of this Parliament in effect acting as touts for the Nugan Hand Bank with Labor-dominated councils, people who were prepared to attend luncheons, to facilitate meetings and to facilitate introductions around the place. Mark you, in evidence before Mr Justice Stewart, members of the Labor Party were only too anxious to drop each other in as far as this was concerned. I quote from paragraph 8.16 of Mr Justice Stewart's report:

Senator Sibraa told the Commission that he selected Mr McLeay as the person to whom Mr Pittard should speak because at that time Mr McLeay was `the person in the Labor Party office who handled local government matters' or was an alderman of the Marrickville Council . . . Mr McLeay, however, subsequently gave evidence to the Commission that he had nothing to do with local government affairs especially in his capacity as organiser.

I referred to this matter in a speech which I made in this chamber on 21 August 1980 about relationships and meetings between people trying to fix various things in local government with officers of the New South Wales Branch of the Australian Labor Party at the time when Senator Richardson was the General Secretary of that Branch.

It seems to me that a large number of matters require some explanation following the publication of these comments in the National Times over the weekend. Among these are the following: One, what is the exact relationship that Senator Richardson has, or had, with Mr Domican? Two, did Mr Domican work for Senator Richardson-then Mr Richardson-paid for by Warren Anderson? Three, did Anderson obtain favours from the Australian Labor Party via any officers of the Australian Labor Party in return? Four, why are there questions which remain unanswered by Senator Richardson in relation to the work done at his home by Anderson's company, Multiplex Constructions Pty Ltd? Five, does Senator Richardson still defend putting pressure on the first law officer of New South Wales to drop any attempt to reopen the Enmore case? Six, given the reputation of persons involved-the Domicans, the Meissners and others, did Senator Richardson attempt to get legal aid for these people and to use his influence with the Labor Party and the Labor Government in New South Wales?

Seven, why has Senator Richardson continued to frustrate any comprehensive inquiry into the Enmore allegations? Eight, why has the Labor Party in New South Wales failed to pursue the details of the Baldwin bashing? Nine, why has there been no response to the serious charges made in the report of the Stewart Royal Commission? Ten, what are the responses from the Labor Party to Mr Meissner's offer of a package of documents, tapes and photographs for sale? Eleven, why has there consistently been a cover up and why did Senator Richardson consistently defend the role of Mr Casey until it was too late, and too hot, after the Baldwin bashing? Twelve, were these tapes which were reproduced in the National Times at the weekend, in fact in the possession of left wing members of the ALP in New South Wales prior to the 1983 general election and how were they persuaded not to make them public at that stage?

Thirteen, what was the role that Senator Richardson and others played in instructing and helping Mr Domican to fix up the Lowe pre- selection to deny the second round preselection to Miss Burnswood? Fourteen, is it true that senior officers of the Labor Party, at the time Senator Richardson was the General Secretary, issued people with instructions as to how to forge branch records? Fifteen, is it true that Senator Richardson, as General Secretary, was involved in transferring dead members from branch to branch, something to which he adverted, at least in passing, in his statement of May 1985? Sixteen, what is the relationship, if any, between Senator Richardson, Mr Delaney and the other crew who hang around Sackville Hotel? Seventeen, who is Barry McCann? Is he a member of the Lilyfield branch of the Australian Labor Party and what is his role in the recent events which are currently unfolding?

Allegations made against public figures are very often those which are made by people motivated to destroy individuals. In terms of the Enmore events, what is of most interest is that the attempts to have this matter brought forward, discussed and shown the light of day have come from within the Australian Labor Party. These attempts have come from those people in the Australian Labor Party in New South Wales who do not believe that it is proper that members of a political party should be subject to intimidation by a gang of thugs of the likes of Tommy Domican and who are distressed that the elected officers and senior members of the ruling clique in the New South Wales Labor Party will not help them clean out their own Augean stables. They have not come from this side of the chamber; they have come exclusively from within the ranks of people in the Labor Party in New South Wales who believe that they have been subject to a conspiracy, going back now to the 1970s, of harassment, of threat, of intimidation and of thuggery which, when Senator Richardson had the responsibility, as the General Secretary of the New South Wales Branch of the Labor Party, he consistently failed and consistently refused to assist in having cleaned up and he was precipitated into action on one of the matters, that of Mr Casey, only after Peter Baldwin had been viciously bashed.

Mr President, I put it to you that the true face of the Labor Party in New South Wales during the period of the administration of Senator Richardson as General Secretary is the face that you will see of Peter Baldwin sitting up in his hospital bed showing the way in which Labor politics is really conducted.
Sitting suspended from 6.27 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I have been subjected to a smear by Senator Puplick. Let it be said by me at the start in the clearest and starkest terms that not only have I committed no wrong, no offence, but also, after six years of regurgitated accusations, no one has brought forward any instance of possible wrongdoing by me, including tonight. All we have is smear and innuendo-a blatant attempt to try me in the media. I am sick of it. I will now destroy the accusations and the accusers once and for all.

SPEECH.PARA: Amid great flurry, I was asked 17 questions by Senator Puplick. There may as well have been 50 or 1,700. However many there are, they will all be answered. In the hurried way that I had to write down the accusations as they came, I am not exactly certain that I got them all. But let me say that I am stunned that, with all of the build-up and all of the drama of the last few weeks, particularly in the State Parliament, not one new fact could be produced tonight. Not only did the State Liberal Party suffer so badly in the State Parliament on Tuesday, with the Premier, Mr Unsworth, and the Minister for Police and Emergency Services, George Paciullo, destroying their accusations; but also tonight Senator Puplick puts his credibility on the line. I can say for certain that, by the time this saga is over, Nick Greiner will regret it; John Dowd already regrets it, and Senator Puplick will also.

Let us take the 17 questions. The first was: What is the exact relationship that Senator Richardson has or had with Mr Domican? As to `has', the answer is none. It is a pretty simple answer. All honourable senators will have watched the television, read the papers and will have seen him attack me over the last four years. As to `had', as I have stated publicly before, because of my actions Meissner was put out of the Australian Labor Party before the Baldwin bashing. The Enmore branch's charter was withdrawn before the Baldwin bashing. As far as Domican was concerned, I, and I alone, withdrew him from a preselection ballot by telling him that there was no way that we would endorse him to stand. Through my actions, he finished up being kicked out of the Party.

If we are to look at the relationship with Tom Domican, let us go back six years. It is all wonderful in hindsight, but let us look at what happened then. He was not the multi-media personality of today. There had been no well-publicised court appearances. There had not been any court appearances. He was not under any form of investigation. He was a garbo, an ordinary Party member. He never held any office in the ALP either at Federal electorate council, State electorate council or local level. No one knew of his criminal record until the time of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking in 1984; that is, the criminal record that existed many years earlier in England. He was a friend of John Harrison, who was the Mayor of Marrickville, who was a friend of mine. I was the Secretary of the Party of which they were both members.

The second question was: Did Mr Domican work for Senator Richardson, then Mr Richardson, and was he paid by Warren Anderson? Senator Puplick did not reach back just a few years. He reached back 10 years in going back to find every allegation that has ever been made against me. But apparently he forgot that in the Senate on 28 February 1984 I denied those accusations. Domican was employed by Anderson for a period of a year as a security guard. That had nothing to do with me. That accusation alone cost Rosemary Foot a lot of money, her job and her career. If Senator Puplick persists, it will cost him the same.

The third question was: Did Anderson obtain favours from the ALP via any officers of the ALP in return? I presume that means from myself or from anybody else. The answer quite clearly is no. If one looks at Warren Anderson's record in New South Wales, one can see time and again where State Government action frustrated his developments.

The fourth question was: Why are there questions that remain unanswered by Senator Richardson in relation to work done at his home by Anderson's company, Multiplex Constructions Pty Ltd? I previously ignored this. I was asked questions on it by Brian Toohey of the National Times on Sunday. Quite frankly, I would not tell Brian Toohey the time, let alone answer questions about my house. But, on a more serious note, I do not consider my family and my home to be the business of the Senate. However, since I have to destroy these accusations and those who seek to raise them, let me say this: Warren Anderson paid nothing for my home. I did not pay $45,000, as reported. I paid over $100,000. I borrowed money to do it. I am still in debt because of it. Furthermore, just for the record, Multiplex is not Warren Anderson's company. Senator Puplick got that wrong too.

The fifth question was: Does Senator Richardson still defend putting pressure on the first law officer of New South Wales to drop any attempt to reopen the Enmore case? I must ask: Why did not Senator Puplick or anybody else in the Liberal Party raise this at the time? It appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald. It was not kept secret. I did it openly. Not only did I do it openly; at a State conference we had a unanimous decision calling on the police to stay out of internal affairs. The decision, which I conveyed to every Minister-not just Mr Walker; Senator Puplick should remember that; I told every Minister-was a unanimous decision of the administrative committee also. At the time everybody in the Party, from the right, the left and the centre, agreed with what we were doing. I was the Secretary of the Party. I conveyed the decisions of the 1981 State conference and of the administrative committee. That was my job. Furthermore, in the 90 years of the Labor Party's existence, falsification of records in the Labor Party never attracted the attention of the police, and they have not since Enmore, even though there have been a number of well-publicised instances. They should never have attracted attention then. I said in the letter that the Solomon affair in the Liberal Party, the joke of the North Sydney preselection, should not be the subject of a police investigation and neither should the stacking of a branch's fascists into the Liberal Party.

The sixth question was: Given the reputation of persons involved, the Domicans, the Meissners and others, did Senator Richardson attempt to get legal aid for these people and use his influence? Presumably, that means influence to get legal aid. I would certainly have made inquiries about legal aid; let me say that. But let us also face the fact that when we are talking of Domican and Meissner in the Enmore case the word `others' is pretty important. Also charged was Allan Johnson, a friend of mine since I was 10 years old, an executive officer of my father's union, a great Australian, a mail sorter at the Sydney Mail Exchange who carried shrapnel around in his body from World War II and who was having to go to Royal Prince Alfred Hospital during that hearing to get treatment just to keep himself alive. Of course I wanted to help him and I am proud of that. No influence was exercised. I made inquiries. They did not get legal aid. They were not entitled to it because legal aid did not apply to committal proceedings.

The seventh question was: Why has Senator Richardson continued to frustrate any comprehensive inquiry into the Enmore allegations? Obviously, Senator Puplick and honourable senators opposite did not know what happened in the State Parliament on Tuesday. If I get the time later, I will make sure that they do. The Police Commissioner gave an answer to the Police Minister. In it he said that the principal investigators involved in the Enmore case-Detective Inspector, now Senior Detective Inspector, Kelly and Detective Chief Superintendent Newall, now retired-had been interviewed. They had advised that there were no instances of Labor Party officials having refused to co-operate at any time. He also went back to the previous Commissioner, Mr Abbott, and the previous Assistant Commissioner, Mr Whitelaw. They all said that there was complete co-operation from the Labor Party at all times.

The eighth question was: Why has the Labor Party in New South Wales failed to pursue the details-I think that was the word used-of the Baldwin bashing? When one looks at the details one sees that there were two assailants; they attacked in the dark; they were masked; apparently they did not speak; and Peter Baldwin could not help in identifying them. It is not all that surprising that the police found it a bit difficult to identify them. Nevertheless, their inquiries continue. That is a file that will never be closed; nor should it be.

The ninth question was: Why has there been no response to the serious charges made in the report of the Stewart Royal Commission? We had a royal commission and Mr Justice Stewart reported. When he reported he said that Domican was a witness who was prepared to, and did, lie upon oath to suit his own purposes. He said that Domican prevaricated and lied repeatedly. He also said that I was a truthful witness. I came out of that inquiry with my head held high. I still hold it in the same direction.

The tenth question was: What are the responses from the Labor Party to Mr Meissner's offer of a package of documents, tapes and photographs for sale? I will have more to say about that a little later, but at this stage all I can say is that I wish someone would buy it. If someone is foolish enough to pay the $550,000 that John Dowd was asking News Ltd to pay or the $400,000 for which everybody else tells me it has been offered, I wish he would. I would love to have it examined. At least Nick Greiner did us one favour. By producing a list of documents that are supposed to be in it he showed me just how silly it all is. Neither I nor anybody else in the Labor Party has anything to fear from that package.

The eleventh question was: Why has there been consistently a cover-up, and why had Senator Richardson consistently defended the role of Mr Casey until it was too late and too hot? I knew Casey; that is no secret. I gave evidence about it before the Woodward Royal Commission into Drug Trafficking. Contrary to Senator Puplick's claim that Balmain Welding Company was involved in drug trafficking, after seven years of investigating Casey's personal and company life Mr Justice Woodward could make no adverse finding against him. Casey's branch's charter was withdrawn, and he resigned from the Party.

The twelfth question was: Were the tapes reproduced in the National Times at the weekend in fact in the possession of left wing members of the Australian Labor Party prior to the 1983 general election? I think the other part of the question was: How were they persuaded not to make them public at that stage? I would say to Senator Childs that he knows the record pretty well. If there were tapes in the possession of the Left that could do me damage prior to the 1983 election, the 1980 election, the 1977 election, or any event as far back as the Reichstag fire, honourable senators would have heard all about them; they would have heard plenty about them. The Left has never been backward in criticising me. That is its right. I suspect that at least one left wing member of the Party had the tapes, namely, David Halpin. I do not know whether he gave them to anyone else, but why would it matter? The Left did not need to produce those tapes. John Dowd produced them for it in the State Parliament way back in February 1983. John Dowd had been meeting Tom Domican; he had them. He made the allegations about legal aid; they led nowhere; they were nothing.

The thirteenth question was: What was the role that Senator Richardson and others played in instructing and helping Mr Domican to fix the Lowe preselection to deny the second round of preselection to Miss Burnswood? I am stunned by that. It beggars the imagination. I do not know how to reply to it, except to say that I doubt very much whether Tom Domican had the capacity to influence one voter in the Lowe preselection. If he knew anyone, it was in the Marrickville end of Grayndler, miles away from Lowe. I cannot remember the figures-it is too long ago-but Michael Maher won very comfortably because he had an easy majority of support amongst the rank and file. He bolted in. He did not get help from Domican; he did not need it.

The fourteenth question was: Is it true that senior officers of the Labor Party at the time Senator Richardson was the General Secretary issued people with instructions as to how to forge branch records? The answer to that is no. Again, I only wish someone would produce the documents. The difficulty with this is that it is very easy to smear. A person just repeats the allegations. The Press is gullible enough; it will give him a front page every time. I hope we are now getting to the stage where those in the Press Gallery realise that this is very old material. Senator Puplick went back 10 years in dredging up allegations against me. I have appeared before two royal commissions. I have given my responses to questions. I have been questioned for hours. I came out of both of them with absolutely nothing to worry about; I do not worry now.

The fifteenth question was: Is it true that Senator Richardson, as General Secretary, was involved in transferring dead members from branch to branch, something to which he adverted, at least in passing, in his statement of May 1985? I do not know to what I adverted in May 1985, but I answered the question in the AM program last Friday week. I said then that the procedure involved for clearances in the Labor Party at the time-I think it is still the same-was that branch secretaries sent in clearances; they gave details of members' tickets. If the members' tickets checked out in relation to the files, I signed a clearance. Wow! There are 21,000 members of the Labor Party in New South Wales. I do not know them all. I wish I did, but I do not. If one member had died and a secretary sent me in a form suggesting that the member was alive, I would not have known; I may have signed the clearance. I doubt very much, however, whether there are as many dead-uns as has been suggested. It is the same old package. It is talked about, but we never see it.

The sixteenth question was: What is the relationship, if any, between Senator Richardson, Mr Delaney and the other crew who hang around the Sackville Hotel? I have not been in the hotel for seven or eight years; I do not really know them. I have to say, though, that the time I have spent with Delaney is so short that I doubt that I would recognise him if he walked in the door.

The seventeenth question was: Who is Barry McCann? Is he a member of the Lilyfield branch of the Australian Labor Party and what is his role in recent events which are currently unfolding? I would not know who the hell he is. The name Barry McCann means absolutely nothing to me. He is not someone I can recall ever meeting or knowing. I do not know whether he is a member of the Lilyfield branch. I do not think it is worthwhile my finding out. Given that I have never heard of him and I do not know him, whatever he has done is of no concern and no interest to me.

On 14 May last year I spoke in relation to this matter. I did not need to speak; I chose to speak. My speech was effective enough to put paid to the Enmore story and to see the story lie dormant for 18 months. I put to rest some of the myths, but not all; I did not have time. There are even more now, and there will be more at a later time. At the end of my speech Senator Chaney moved that the Senate take note and sought leave to continue his remarks. We have all had to wait breathlessly for 18 months to hear another word about it in this place.

These are not the first Liberals with problems of waiting. Nick Greiner and John Dowd had problems, too. They have been sitting on information on the Enmore case, albeit useless and irrelevant, for almost four years. In February 1983, after the meeting with Domican, of which we have photographs, Dowd produced the tape about legal aid. Because some members of the media are so forgetful, they printed it as a brand new story two weeks ago. It was not; it was old news. I did not bother to comment at the time on the allegation. It went by, and was never again raised. It has been ignored for that period. It meant nothing, and it led nowhere. It did not and could not amount to an illegality on my part. Even Greiner, on national television, said he did not allege any illegality on my part. Three years after he came into possession of that tape-in February 1986-John Dowd was again acting in collusion with those people whom he, Greiner, and those opposite now smear me for having known. This time he rang senior executives of News Ltd and offered them the package for $550,000. At the same time he apparently received copies of a few more tapes. Again, Dowd and Greiner waited. It happens a lot in the Liberal Party. They did not rush into the Parliament with the material. They did not rush to the Police Commissioner with the material. They shoved it in a cupboard. They kept it in a bottom drawer. By the time this saga has ended they will wish to God they had left it there. Senator Puplick declared that these matters are so important that they must be debated in the national Parliament. Yet his State colleagues sat on the information-some of it for four years and some of it for nine months. This stuff is so old it has whiskers on it.

Let us have a look at what Greiner did with the material he had and, more importantly, with the material he gave the impression he had, but failed to produce to the Commissioner of Police-and which he was forced to admit later on television that he did not have anyway. He listed the documents supposed to be in the package. But he conveniently omitted the first item of the package. Senator Puplick totally omitted the incident that that first item referred to-the Love Boat. All honourable senators will remember the Love Boat. I remember it. The first item of this package at the time was supposed to be photos of six Labor members of parliament and one prospective Liberal leader cavorting naked on the boat. Why did Greiner fail to mention that that was the first item? Why did Senator Puplick fail to mention the Love Boat in this half-hour bucket on me, this half-hour collection of allegations made over the last decade? They omitted it because they know, as the whole world knows, that no photograph of that kind ever existed. The package, and what was in it, was shonky, like the rest of the package which Dowd tried to sell.

Anyone who heard my interview, by the way, on AM last Friday week, 31 October, knows that I gave that interview on the basis that Greiner had the package. I assumed he must have been mug enough to buy it from his friend Dowd. I was prepared to assume that because the Australian newspaper, among others, had been told so by Greiner that he did have the package. But, as has always happened on the Enmore affair, when someone blackening my name has had the opportunity to put up or shut up, that person has shut up again. For two long weeks in that State Parliament since then not a word came from these people-not a word from Greiner, except for an audible groan from him when Premier Unsworth revealed that John Dowd was involved in trying to sell the fake package.

I want to take the opportunity to answer some of Greiner's claims, because that is where all this new run of old material springs from. He said I `did not co-operate with the police'. The day after the Baldwin bashing I sought an interview with the Police Commissioner. I went to see him and the senior officer he had assigned the task of investigating the bashing, Barney Ross, who is now, I think, Deputy Commissioner, or in some very senior position. I offered full co-operation. I went with John Johnson, the President of the Legislative Council. All documents asked for by the police investigators were produced. I never refused any request; I never delayed any response. Just to bear that out, in a letter dated 10 November 1986 the current Police Commissioner said:
The principal investigators involved in the Enmore case were Detective Inspector D. W. Kelly and Detective Chief Inspector D. Newell.

These officers have been interviewed and have advised that there have been no instances of Labor Party officials having at any time refused to co-operate with police in the investigation of the Enmore conspiracy.

Similar statements were obtained from former Commissioner Abbott and former Senior Assistant Commissioner Whitelaw. It was just a stupid allegation, totally wrong like all of them. Greiner also claimed:
First among the reasons why the Government is deserving of censure on this matter is its failure after four and a half years to take up the police recommendation of an ex-officio indictment.
He repeated this claim the following day on the John Laws program-wrong again. This is the response of the Police Commissioner, Mr Avery, to that allegation:
There has never been an application by this Department for an ex-officio indictment.

But despite the lies and the deceit inherent in the attacks on myself, Greiner was almost Goebbels-like in his next act. In a masterstroke of propaganda, folders full of documents were produced for the cameras. This was the material to be handed over to the police-so we were told. But what happened by the time these folders reached the Police Commissioner's office? They had shrunk. All that was produced was a few tapes and a transcript. A Greiner staffer, in handing over the material, informed the police that the tapes were practically inaudible. Yet there was no claim on the Liberals' part that the transcript necessarily matched the tapes.

Senator Puplick referred to the tired, tawdry line of Australian Labor Party senators and members of the House of Representatives disputing the accuracy of the Age tapes. Whatever the Age tapes were in terms of illegal productions, they were produced by police on, we will say, sophisticated equipment. These tapes were not. Whoever produced these did a pretty awful job. The National Times on Sunday has now kindly printed the transcripts. In view of the headline to the accompanying article, its lawyers had better be at the top of their form, because those tapes are crook and the National Times on Sunday will pay dearly and so will Nick Greiner. His career will be in tatters. But I will say this for Greiner: Given the phenomenal run that that effort got-the one full page and one front page in the newspapers-I will give him six out of ten for politics, nought out of ten for morals and minus ten for integrity. Barrie Unsworth said in State Parliament on Tuesday:

The Police Minister has asked the Commissioner to investigate all the tapes and documents. If there is any suggestion of illegality or an ounce of sustainable evidence, then there will be a full investigation. I will pursue any question of wrongdoing relentlessly.

Anyone who knows Barrie Unsworth and knows the sort of fellow he is knows that he will be true to his word. But we had all better wait, before we get carried away in this chamber or anywhere else, until the police get a chance to report on those tapes. I would like to get the opportunity myself to hear and listen to what these tapes say. I want to know how good they are. More importantly, though, let us examine why the matter was raised in State Parliament two weeks ago and why we are hearing about it tonight. The matters were raised because Tom Domican has made several well publicised court appearances. This gave the Opposition in New South Wales the chance to spread its slander and be guaranteed good coverage.

Domican has spent several years attacking me. I do not want to do any more tonight in terms of responding to him, because the fact is that when one is before the court one has to come up for trial, and I want to make sure that he gets a fair trial, as every citizen is entitled to. But I repeat tonight that, as far as I am concerned, at the time of these allegations he was a garbo, an ordinary member of the Party. Sure he flexed his muscles at Party meetings. Sure he made a pest of himself with a lot of people. But there was no suggestion at that time of criminal activity on his part. What standard of behaviour is set for me? I do not ask everyone I meet about his record. I am not expected to. If someone has no record, has never been charged and is under no investigation, what am I supposed to do? The Labor Party is not equipped to investigate criminal accusations. The weakness of the Labor Party in that 12-month period was that when assaults occurred it was pretty hard for Party committees to get involved. We had disputes committees asking us for legal opinions as to how they could be sued if they were prepared to hear evidence. We had a lot of problems in grappling with it.

I do not claim that every response I made and every action I took was perfect. No one can ever claim that. But I will say this: At the end of the day-too late according to some; in my view it could not have been done earlier-all the troublesome elements went. They went because all of us were prepared to take action-and in the end I did. I got rid of those people who have been talked about tonight. Delaney was got rid of 10 years ago. That was nothing new. But it was done, because when we had proof we always acted. On the Baldwin bashing, the Labor Party could not have been expected to solve the question. The police, hopefully, one day may. I, and every member of the Labor Party, will give them co-operation in doing so. But I have to say this: I am tired of Enmore. I have had to answer this time and again. All that happens is that the same allegations are raised and I have to repeat the same responses. It is old and it is tired. It does not have much life left in it now, and by the time investigations into the tapes and the transcripts are completed, no one will raise the question of Enmore in this chamber or anywhere else again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —An American musical on the life of Fiorello La Guardia included in it a song relating to Tammany Hall, in which La Guardia, in his success over the Democrat machine in his campaign, asked an election rally, `What does T.A.M.M.A.N.Y. spell?' The response was, `Tyranny'. His reply was, ` ``Tammany'' spells ``Tyranny'' like R.A.T. spells ``rat'' '. In this case, we should change it to, ` ``Tammany'' spells ``Tyranny'' like ``A.L.P.'' spells ``Pal'', in a slightly muddled way', because this relates to the old pals act.
—You have got yourself all mixed up.

—Yes, it is a very mixed up `pal' in the Australian Labor Party, and it is the old pals act that really should be concerning us tonight. It is what happens when people seek to protect their own rather than allow the reality of the judicial system to do the right thing.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend Senator Richardson for the sections of his speech where he has quite directly taken on reality, both tonight and on 15 May 1985, in particular in the section in his May 1985 speech where he said:
The reason that some unscrupulous people in the Labor Party have tried to manipulate and falsify branch records over the years is to ensure extra votes in preselections.

Really, I would think that that is the crux of the matter. I commend Senator Richardson on his taking the view that if information is fully revealed, he will be pleased. I notice that on 10 November the Sydney Morning Herald reports him as having said that he welcomed the production of any evidence. That means that we are all on the same track; we are all going down the same path. But before I proceed down that path, let me just note a couple of observations that concern me about Senator Richardson's speech tonight. In the first place, he said, as I understood it, that he had got Domican out of the Party by the time of the Baldwin bashing, and certainly had got him out of the Enmore branch. I must say that that confuses me. I should like to know-and I think that everyone has a right to know-what date Domican was got rid of, because Ms Burnswood gives the clear impression that he was still in the Labor Party and still representing the head office when in a television program she gave an inference that he was there at meetings to terrorise her supporters to ensure that she did not get pre-selection for the seat of Lowe. In support of that suggestion, I quote from the transcript of the Panorama report in which Ms Burnswood-the Senate will recall that she was the candidate who stood against Sir William McMahon in Lowe and came fairly close to beating him in 1980, and then stood once again for pre-selection in January 1982 against Mr Michael Maher, who eventually became the candidate-is recorded as quite proudly stating that she is a member of the left wing. In the transcript she is reported as follows:
The machine-
that means the head office machine of the Labor Party-
was worried that I was going to win-
that is, win pre-selection-
and when I was not supposed to win, and therefore it was necessary to remove that candidate-
herself-
and bring in someone who could be seen as a far more acceptable candidate.

This is not Tom Domican talking. This is not some crook or someone that Senator Richardson has got out of the ALP. This is a left wing candidate who got rolled for pre-selection because, she says, `I wasn't supposed to win by head office'.

TALK.START.PARA: —She had stood for them before.
—She had stood before, as the honourable senator says, and had performed very well before. The commentator on the Pannorama program then interposed this:

SPEECH.PARA: In order to help some of her constituents make up their minds, a familiar figure suddenly turned up-Domican. There are a few left wingers giving them a bit of trouble.
Then Ms Burnswood went on:
I don't remember him making any sign-just this frightening, very still, very fixed sort of presence in the room.
Then she went on:
He had two habits. One was to sit on the side of the hall and stare fixedly for a long time, with what I can only describe as a glittering eye, and I found that quite frightening.

The left wing Labor candidate for Lowe, who then failed to get re-endorsed after having performed so well, because head office did not want her, found him frightening. That is what he was there for-to frighten her and to frighten her supporters. She continued:
He had another habit of sitting either alongside someone or behind someone and cracking his knuckles just behind their neck.

That is the suave and sophisticated way in which, apparently, the right wing machine operates to ensure that the wrong candidate, who happens to be a left winger, does not get pre-selection in a seat which its members consider they are going to win.

It seems to me vital that if Senator Richardson wishes to convey to us a genuine impression that there were no relations between him or the head office of the ALP and Mr Domican by the time that this happened, or by the time of the Baldwin bashing, or shortly after Enmore or the Rozelle East branch arrangements, we must know the dates. What are the dates? It is all very well responding to Senator Puplick's questions by just dismissing them. The reality is that if there is to be a convincing response to Senator Puplick's questions, simple things like the dates of such matters must be provided as those happen to be absolutely vital. Until we can see when there was no further relationship of any kind between the Labor Party and Mr Domican, I am afraid that it is very difficult to accept that there was no continuing relationship. It is very difficult to accept that Ms Burnswood is not a credible witness. It is very difficult to accept that Mr Domican was not continuing his activities for head office-at least as recognised not only by Ms Burnswood but by other members of the left wing. I will go into what they have been saying later because it is well documented. That is important: It has been well documented.

Another point of difficulty that I have with what Senator Richardson had to say tonight was when he said `I knew Casey'. Senator Puplick dealt at some length with the Rozelle East branch and Mr Casey. Senator Richardson then said: `Woodward made no adverse finding against him'. Let me quote from another newspaper report which gives a totally different suggestion altogether from the impression conveyed by Senator Richardson tonight. The Sydney Morning Herald reports:
Justice Woodward, in his NSW drugs royal commission, refused to make a positive finding that Mr Casey . . . was not involved in drugs, partly because-
and here I quote Mr Justice Woodward:
I regard Casey's explanations of relevant matters as unreliable or unacceptable.

Yet Senator Richardson says here tonight: `Woodward made no adverse finding against him'. What on earth is Senator Richardson trying to do here tonight when it is so simple to check evident facts such as that? How can the Senate take on board and accept at face value statements he has made about information which is not readily available to us-for example, the proposition that Domican had nothing more to do with the ALP at the time these evident things were being spoken of and were currency?

We certainly are aware of the relationship of Senator Richardson before he was a senator-and none of the matters I seek to raise tonight have anything to do with Senator Richardson's role as a senator, and I have no intention of pursuing anything of that kind, as my concern is with the management of the State Branch of the Labor Party-but I acknowledge Senator Richardson's comment that he did know Casey well, if only because the senator's wife was employed by Balmain Welding Company in May 1977 at approximately $130 a week but she did not have to attend the office. The typing was reportedly sent home so that she could do it at home. I raise the question of Mr Casey because it is alleged by left wing members of the Labor Party in NSW that the Rozelle East situation was far more disgraceful than that at the Enmore branch. Once again I quote from a report in the Sydney Morning Herald about Mr Baldwin, who at the time of the bashing was the key left wing investigator into rigging of inner city ALP branches and the infiltration of criminal elements, lodging a report to the ALP alleging almost total fabrication of records at the Rozelle East branch. He and another left winger regarded the alleged fraud in Rozelle East as bigger than at the Enmore ALP Branch. The report continues:
Police began investigating Rozelle East and Enmore branches after the bashing on July 19 1980-and Mr Baldwin told them that a possible motive for the bashing lay in his inquiries into both branches.

But while police mounted a conspiracy case against six former members of Enmore ALP Branch-they were all later acquitted under the most curious circumstances, as outlined by Senator Puplick-the police investigations into Rozelle East stopped without explanation. I suppose it is reasonable for the Senate to wonder why. In the new forthcoming answering of questions approach that Senator Richardson is adopting perhaps he could add that to the list and tell us.

No action has been taken against any former official of Rozelle East, by either the police or the ALP. I wonder what the left wing members of the ALP in NSW think about that. Mr Baldwin's complaints about Rozelle East dated back to December 1976, when he and another left winger, Mr Rodney Cavalier, wrote to the State ALP alleging that the attendance book was a fraud and calling for the branch's charter to be withdrawn. That was in 1976. Is it not remarkable that that branch lasted until July 1980, about four years later, before magically, three days after the Baldwin bashing, it lost its charter? One wonders how these things magically happen. There is no doubt about the reports that left wingers were angry, not only at this course of events but also at the fact the former officers of both Enmore and Rozelle escaped any party discipline whatsoever, and that charges laid against them up to four years previously by other ALP members have not been allowed by party chiefs to proceed. We all know that the Rozelle East branch was the power base of former Deputy Mayor of Leichhardt Alderman Daniel Patrick Casey, the person we have discussed as Senator Richardson's friend-`I knew Casey', as he told us tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you know Askin?

—Neither I nor any member of my family received any emoluments of any kind from the late Mr Askin. The most intriguing issue that seems to me to emerge from this is that what Senator Richardson seemed to be doing was making a sort of de facto admission that the tapes do exist and are real, even if a little hard to hear. I am also concerned about another point that he made, and that is an allegation that the State Opposition in New South Wales made no remarks, did not raise this issue, for four years. That is absolute nonsense. The Enmore conspiracy case was raised in the State House on 29 October last year; it was raised again on 19 March this year. In each case the Opposition was asking: `What has happened to police inquiries?'. That other point made by Senator Richardson was simply untrue. There has been action. It is untrue to say that there has been no word on this from the Opposition. On the question of the Baldwin bashing, I think that there have been 14 questions in the Upper House in New South Wales over this matter since it took place, and since nothing has proceeded.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand the matter, the Government has failed after four and a half years to take up the police recommendation of an ex officio indictment in the Enmore matter. The police, I understand, have been seeking an ex officio indictment on the Enmore case since 1982, shortly after the charges were dismissed by magistrate Bruce Brown on a basis, as Senator Puplick said tonight, that did not seem appropriate at the time and was bad in law. Two more reports in April and May last year were made on this question, supported by a legal assessment by the police prosecutions branch, to the effect that the magistrate's findings were wrong in law. As I said, the Opposition raised these matters. In March of this year the Minister for Police and Emergency Services told the State Opposition that `further police inquiries were almost complete'. Well, nothing has happened. We have all heard the quotes from Mr Domican on the Panorama program relating to this matter where, as Senator Puplick said, Domican told the people of Britain:
We could not have got found guilty. Had we have got found guilty, very high-up officials of the Labor Party would have fell, who were also involved in the rigging and that.
One wonders, is that the reason for this magical failure to proceed, despite continuous requests from the State Opposition in New South Wales.

We have heard about the package of documents concerning the Enmore case that was on offer to the media and the Labor Party has been trying to make some capital out of allegations that it was for sale and as to the persons involved. It was as if somehow that will diminish the reality of what that package was all about. Can they explain away from that package what is alleged to be a handwritten note by Mr Leo McLeay on how to forge records in the Enmore Branch and an alleged directive by Mr Graham Richardson to transfer seven members from other branches to Enmore, at a time when those members were deceased. As Senator Richardson quite properly said, as General Secretary he would not have known whether those members were alive or dead. There is no doubt that he has a sound point to make.

There is in this package original records from the Enmore branch, statements by crown witnesses in the Enmore case-about 60 of them-which, as Senator Puplick said, helped the defence considerably. There is an alleged note in Steven Loosley's handwriting signed `Steve' on the selection of legal representatives in the Enmore case; instructions allegedly in Loosley's handwriting regarding the Labor party meeting legal expenses for the case and paying for a holiday for Joe Meissner, who was heavily involved in this, as well as receipts relating to that holiday; and handwritten instructions from head office on how to remove Owen Wright from the Enmore Branch, as well as originals of a large number of taped conversations. All this is true, and the point was made in the State Parliament. All this might have had an air of fantasy if it were not for two of these tapes, which Tom Domican released and which it is understood, as Senator Puplick mentioned, Senator Childs, for example, may have had access to before the 1983 election. We know that the left wing has been very cross indeed about the whole question of what went on. One of the tapes is a record of a discussion between Joe Meissner and Keith Challenger, an organiser for the Electrical Trades Union of Australia and then a mainstay of the machine. In it Meissner warns Challenger:
You don't probably know this . . . I don't think I ever told you that Leo McLeay wrote out a document telling me and John and the other people how to rig the books.

That is not direct evidence, it is only third hand, but nonetheless all these tapes and this information surely are material which reflects very badly indeed on the conduct of the Australian Labor Party in New South Wales. Challenger's reaction to these tapes was not to reject that suggestion as highly improbable and a fraud but to nervously ask: Where is the document?' All this seems to support very throughly the allegations that the left wing of the Labor Party in New South Wales has been maintaining for many years about the Enmore conspiracy case. I quote these allegations, which include:
The New South Wales Right's recent protestations of concern about the type of people joining the party is nothing more than an obscene joke . . .
That Harrison and Domican were welcome visitors in the office of Graham Richardson and Steven Loosely . . .
In the words of Peter Baldwin, when interviewed by the New South Wales police:

One of my main objections to Richardson is that he has a strong association with these what I regard as nasty machines in the area. I think it's a bad thing when a senior party official allows himself to become enmeshed with the sort of people he's become enmeshed in.

If Senator Richardson really feels that he has the capacity to reject these things for all time-and I must say that it would give me no pleasure if he did not do so-then for heaven's sake he should do so in a more effective manner than he has done tonight. It seems to me that what has happened cannot be brushed away by a statement like the one that Senator Richardson made tonight when it is clear that what is needed is a proper inquiry. A proper inquiry has not taken place during the six years since this whole range of activities occurred. I am not referring simply to Enmore. I am referring also to the rigging, to the threats, to the evidence of fraud, which, I must say, goes on at some lengths in the New South Wales machine.

It seems to me that the whole question, apart from the question of allegations by Domican that he visited witnesses who had sudden lapses of memory, is far more serious than that. Why has there not been a proper judicial inquiry or something held into the assault on Peter Baldwin? Why has nothing happened? I presume that it is because of the iron law of the Labor Party which prevents its members from allowing these things to go outside the Party, not because of what is right and wrong or because of issues of morality, but simply because the ALP likes to keep things within its structure. In fact, the motion put forward by Senator Richardson, to which he adverted tonight, was a resolution preventing members of the Party from publicly airing internal party grievances. `Internal party grievances' meant fraud, forgery, the theft of branch records, assault and alleged assault and the takeover of several inner city branches by organised crime. This resolution was effectively telling the Left to abide by the code of silence, no matter how significant that might be in terms of its impact on society as a whole.

We must recognise that these days political machines and political parties are being funded publicly. Where there is fraud and corruption within the structure of a party, it is no longer an internal party matter and can no longer be excused on the basis of the lengthy justification that Senator Richardson gave in the Senate in his last long statement here when he outlined the letter he had written pleading with the New South Wales Government not to allow the police inquiry into the Enmore branch because it should be an internal matter.

The reality is of course that the ALP in New South Wales has a long history of refusing to co-operate with police investigations in that State. In 1972 there was bribery and forgery in the Shortland preselection. The fraud squad reported then that, because of the refusal of the ALP to make available key documentation, it was unable to carry its inquiries to completion. The following year the fraud squad was investigating allegations of bribes demanded by ALP alderman in Marrickville and again the State Secretary of the Party refused to co-operate and again police investigations were terminated as a result. The same law of silence prevailed in the Botany Council case in 1974-75 and that case involved the present Minister for Public Works and the former Chief Magistrate of New South Wales who subsequently resided for some time at Her Majesty's pleasure. When the former Premier of New South Wales, who was then the Leader of Opposition, was asked about this matter and whether he would speak to investigating police, he said: `I feel that I should not be subjected to a lengthy interrogation'. That was that. That seems to be the pattern of this matter.

The Government's inaction on the Enmore case and the Baldwin bashing is now a matter of international notoriety and it is a scandal even in New South Wales. It is incredible that the State Government of New South Wales has taken more than six years to tell us that the police investigations into the brutal bashing of a member of the State Parliament, as he was at the time, perhaps even the attempted murder of that member, have elicited no additional evidence and that absolutely nothing has happened. I remind the Senate that absolutely nothing has happened in New South Wales to pursue the murderer of Donald Mackay. It was only the Victorian police force which managed to arrange a prosecution on the basis of conspiracy because the conspiracy to murder took place in Victoria, and that is where the criminal charge was laid. The murder itself took place in New South Wales but we have had no prosecution there. I do not want to try to draw any long bow between the drugs matter in that case and activities at Balmain Welding, but it is unfortunate that drugs seem to be dominant in these matters.

Unless the Party machine in New South Wales acts more effectively than Senator Richardson has acted tonight to clear its name from these very serious charges and this very serious proposition that has been put up that it has influenced preselections-and Senator Richardson effectively says that that is the whole point of this matter-it will remain under a cloud. I was intrigued to note that Senator Richardson said tonight that Domican would not have had any influence in the area of Ms Burnswood because his influence was down the other end in Grayndler. I wonder whether he was telling us that we should perhaps have a look at Mr McLeay's preselection and the role that Mr Domican played in that because Senator Richardson admitted that that was an area in which Mr Domican really has some significant influence. On 15 May Senator Richardson ended up saying that he was more than confident that the police could get to the bottom of the matters that have been raised. They have not done so yet.
