We remember the curious links that existed between some members of the New South Wales police force and some senior Labor politicians. We know that the disgraced Mr Bill Allen was a close friend of one senior Labor politician. In the Waterhouse program the other night it was alleged that Mr Allen was on the receiving end of bribes from a casino which went via him to an unnamed senior Labor politician. What has happened in New South Wales? All we want is a proper answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In approaching this matter we have to understand that tonight the two most skilled honourable senators on the other side have put forward a case. I am not sure who the case is against-whether it is against Senator Richardson or the Australian Labor Party in New South Wales or elsewhere. They really have not defined their mark, which makes their case very difficult to answer. Nonetheless, the fact is that two of the most skilled honourable senators opposite have put forward such a case. Mr Hodgman, an eminent Queen's Counsel from Tasmania is in the gallery. He would have to say, if it were put to him, that no case has been made out. Perhaps the only person who could have put a better case, Senator Withers, did not move in his seat because he knows there is really nothing beyond allegations. Senator Michael Baume asked why did we not answer the allegations put. One does not answer allegations for the simple reason-this seems to have been forgotten in this chamber over the last few years-that allegations are simply statements unsupported by evidence. Allegations, it has been forgotten, have never comprised evidence. If one is to make accusations against anybody, one must produce the evidence. If that evidence is to be produced, it must be produced in the right circles. The right circles as far as criminal allegations are concerned are not in this chamber. The proper place is in the criminal courts or before the police. That should be remembered.

SPEECH.PARA: I see Senator Georges in the chamber. He would agree that through this chamber and its committees over the last few years quite striking injustices have been done to all sorts of people, for what ends I will not now speculate. Let us begin by looking at what is said in the eighth edition of Gatley on Libel and Slander:

The law recognises in every man a right to have the estimation in which he stands in the opinion of others unaffected by false statements to his discredit. This right is protected in English law by the existence of the torts of libel and slander and the criminal offence of libel.

That right is protected except in chambers such as this. When people seek to circumvent the law, to use privilege to get round the law, which stands to protect every citizen of this country, one might ask why. If these allegations are so serious, why are they made in here and not outside? Will they continue to be made for ever and ever? Will there ever be a time when people are satisfied? On tonight's performance obviously not.

Senator Richardson spoke tonight, although he need not have, and answered in detail the various accusations made against him by Senator Puplick. He was then pilloried again by Senator Baume, even though he conceded that Senator Richardson did the right thing in standing up and pronouncing his innocence. He should not have had to do that for a start; this is not the place for him to pronounce his innocence. Even though he has done that there is still the snide innuendo made that, nevertheless, he has further questions to answer. This sort of business, not only in reference to Senator Richardson but in reference to anybody in this chamber, anybody who is a member of parliament, indeed anybody who is a member of our society, has to stop. If we are to go ahead and simply pillory people on the basis of allegations made year after year and time after time, it is time we looked at ourselves as a chamber. Whether these allegations come from this side of the chamber or the other side, this whole process has to stop. People have to go back to the traditional way of doing things, which is simply this: If there is evidence of criminal activity, that evidence should be put before the police. The police force is the proper institution in this society to lay charges, and the proper place to hear them is before the courts of this land. If we go back to the days when the Parliament was making use of impeachment and of Bills of attainder, we will have reached a very sorry state indeed.

I suppose these allegations are made easily enough in chambers such as this, and in a certain sense they are made as part of the general political play, the political give and take of the place. I suppose that to a certain extent Senator Richardson has to cop that as a member of this chamber. But certainly his wife does not have to cop it. When people through their statements make an innuendo against somebody who is not a member of this chamber-the only relationship with the chamber in this case is that this woman is married to a member of it-and that person is pilloried without an opportunity to defend herself, again we as a chamber must ask ourselves whether we want to continue down that line. There has been strong innuendo made that while she worked for the Balmain Welding Co. she did so in a surreptitious, if not dishonest, manner. Getting at her husband by taking that sort of stance is a reprehensible approach indeed.

This forum has been chosen to put Senator Richardson on trial, as it were. The allegation against him is that while he was the Secretary of the Australian Labor Party in New South Wales the Government hindered the police investigations into the Enmore conspiracy case, that the Government of New South Wales stopped the police from proceeding on an ex officio indictment, whatever that means. Certainly as I remember it, it was a structure which operated in England in respect of quite serious crime and was abolished in that country in the 1930s. I accept that it still exists in New South Wales. Be that as it may, one good thing that has come out of the activities that have taken place in recent days is that evidence has been obtained which, in my view, exculpates Senator Richardson and anybody associated with his administration of the New South Wales Branch from the accusations that have been made here tonight. That evidence is contained in a letter from the New South Wales Commissioner of Police dated 10 November 1986. It makes reference to the three allegations that have been made. It is worth while at this point stating those allegations, which are listed in question form. They are:
1. Has the Government at any time hindered Police investigations into the Enmore conspiracy case?
2. Have Police at any time sought of the Government the preferment of ex officio indictments in respect of the Enmore conspiracy case?
3. Have any Labor Party officials at any time refused to co-operate with Police in relation to the Enmore conspiracy case? If so, who were they and what was the nature of their refusal?

I now turn to the answers to those questions. First, as to whether the New South Wales Government had at any time hindered police investigations into the Enmore conspiracy case, the answer is as follows:
At no time during the currency of the Enmore investigations has there been any evidence-
I emphasise `any evidence', although the Opposition does not rely on evidence; all it relies on is allegations-
of Government hindrance to police investigations.
The answer to the second question involving the Government seeking to frustrate the preferment of ex officio indictments states:
The May letter contains no recommendation for an ex officio indictment. In its subject the question of `Consideration to the question of a possible application for an ex officio indictment' is posed.
Just to make it clear that I am not quoting out of context, the letter says:
In the April document Kelly-
that is the policeman on whom those opposite have relied-
recommended that all depositions, exhibits and the prosecution brief be examined by the State Crown Solicitor or a senior Queen's Counsel for an opinion as to whether this case should be reopened.

That was in answer to the question asked, and I stress that passage. The letter then refers to the May letter, which contained no recommendation for an ex officio indictment although the question of a possible application for an ex officio indictment is posed. The letter continues:

It will be seen from the foregoing that unwarranted emphasis is being given to an informal advice obtained by the investigator, from a Police Prosecutor acting with the assistance of the judgement of Mr Brown, S.M. and without the assistance of the full transcript of evidence. Subsequent to the submission of Inspector Kelly in May, 1985, and in a submission dated 17 June, 1985 I recommended-
that is the Chief Commissioner of Police, as I understand it-

that it may `now be appropriate for the Crown to examine the transcript of evidence in the light of the issues raised' `and to provide a legal interpretation.' Subsequently, the Solicitor General on 23 July, 1985 and 31 July 1985 addressed the Enmore case and a number of peripheral matters. In respect of the charges relating to the books of the Enmore Branch, she said `In my view, the Magistrate erred in dismissing the charges on the ground which he did'.

That is the part that was read by Senator Puplick. That is quite clear. The Solicitor-General said: `Look, you were wrong in dismissing charges on that ground'. That supports the case put by Senator Puplick. He quoted that in this chamber. If it stood at that I would have thought it provided substantial evidence to prove his case. The letter continues:
However, later she said-
this was not quoted; one might well ask why-
`notwithstanding that view, the evidence would not support the charges laid' and `the evidence does not support either the substantive charges or the charge of conspiracy to commit forgery'.

He used the wrong law, in dismissing the case. She concedes that. Notwithstanding the view that the wrong law was applied, the evidence would not support the charges laid and the evidence does not support either the substantive charges or the charge of conspiracy to commit forgery. The letter continues:
Because of the evidentiary deficiencies-
as distinct from the wrong law that was applied by the stipendiary magistrate-
it would be wrong to seek to have these matters further litigated.

Members of the Opposition must support the Solicitor-General's statement because they quoted part of it to support their case. They quoted part of her opinion with approval, and, even if they left out the rest, they must, having approved of the first part, approve of what she then goes on to say. She goes on to say that it would be wrong to seek to have these matters further litigated. If that is correct why do honourable members opposite come into this chamber and say, in spite of the Solicitor-General's opinion, which they accept, that the matter should be pursued?

TALK.START.PARA: —Evidentiary provisions-because Domican had shut them up.

—Senator Michael Baume says that it is all a problem of evidence. Honourable senators opposite do not produce evidence. They continue to make accusations. They keep repeating this misdemeanor. I say that with kindness but perhaps I should call it a felony. If a society is run on allegations, on a totalitarian system, whispers in the night, knocks on the door, spying on itself, of course we should act on accusations unsupported by evidence. That is the sort of society which honourable senators opposite are creating. It is certainly not the sort of society I want to live in. I am a traditionalist. I am a person who believes in the law and in the institution of this society. One of the fundamental propositions in our society is that if a person makes an allegation against somebody he should come up with the evidence to support it.

SPEECH.PARA: Those opposite have made allegations tonight about a mysterious package. Why was that not tabled in the Senate? Why did they not get up and say: `This shoots Senator Richardson out of the water. There is the evidence. Look, it is on the table'. What happened? Senator Richardson got up and made what I thought was a fairly restrained answer to the charges, given their nature, and that still does not satisfy those opposite. What evidence has been produced to contradict the denials that are made by Senator Richardson tonight? What is there to balance against his statements as a senator of this nation, a person who is obliged to tell the truth in this public forum, in this chamber? What evidence have those opposite got to put against his statements that he is not guilty or has not in any way offended in the way they have said?

He was accused in relation to what Anderson did about his home. If somebody asked me who built my home and what I was charged, he would have to ask my wife. I would naturally say: `Why is that the business of anybody?' What it comes down to-no doubt I will get a reaction from the other side-is this: What those opposite are really asking for is that we declare our interests. Is the Opposition prepared to do that? Do we all now sit down solemnly and faithfully cite who built what, what we own and what terrible sins we may have committed in our past for everybody else to see? If those opposite are not willing to do that, why do they want Senator Richardson to do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did do it.

—Senator McIntosh is absolutely correct. He has done it not only tonight but also on several other occasions. Yet the accusations still come. Credence for the case is sought from the statement in the National Times on the alleged tapped phone conversations. Presuming just for a minute that what is put out is correct, what is wrong with giving somebody legal aid? That is another thing I am concerned about. There seems to be a suggestion abroad that a person should not get legal aid if he is a criminal, is charged with a serious offence and has prior convictions. In the situation that has been spoken about here, Domican did not have any of those things attached to his name but let us say he did. Is the proposition being put from the other side that such a person should never get legal aid, a person who is threatened with years in gaol? It is my belief, and I think it is absolutely correct, that if the only people that society is going to help are the beautiful, the people for whom we feel sympathy, the people for whom we feel a love and with whom we can easily sympathise and if we reject the ugly, those who are downtrodden, and those for whom we feel no sympathy, we are not much of a society. This society can be judged by what it does for the lowest member in it. If Senator Richardson is to be condemned for trying to get legal aid for someone, where do we get to? We are getting into a very sad state of affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter I want to talk about is the bashing of Peter Baldwin. A horrible, horrific and disgusting exhibition of brutality was committed on that man. That ought to be punished. Sometimes, the less choice prosecutors in the land try to invite a jury to convict whoever might be around when a horrific crime has been committed. If that is the way honourable senators opposite are trying to get at people tonight, again, that borders on the reprehensible. The seriousness of a crime alone should never be used to point the finger at anybody. That is the very reason why in murder trials often times the judge will not allow photos of the victim to be shown to members of the jury. There is a danger that their judgment will be overborne by the horror depicted there and do an injustice to the person charged. That is the very thing that those opposite are doing now. They are saying that this horrific horrible, terrible crime has been committed; let us get someone who is nearby and, with the factional distribution of power in New South Wales, we might stir up a bit of hatred against him.

Senator Richardson is accused in terms of a Ms Burnswood, who apparently proposed to stand for the seat of Lowe in the State of New South Wales but was beaten for preselection by Mr Michael Maher. I heard these accusations being made. I have been provided with some details on that matter. As I understand it, Ms Burnswood did in fact stand on two occasions for the seat of Lowe and lost. I do not know Ms Burnswood. I suspect that she is a decent, honourable member of this great Party which people on this side of the House belong to. Apparently she missed out on preselection, and did not stand for the seat. It was won by Mr Michael Maher. I hope that no accusation is made against his integrity or his decency because he is a man who has decency, honour and ability written all over him. Is this a prelude to lining him up next for some sort of campaign where he will be denigrated before the country and before his family, where perhaps his wife will be introduced into public life to be denigrated and put in a position where she cannot defend herself? Is that the situation that we will face?

If accusations are going to be made in the manner in which they have been tonight, where will they stop? Senator Puplick quite properly referred to one of his speeches in August 1980. When I looked at that I saw he was in as good form then as he is now. He was talking about the Woodward Royal Commission into Drug Trafficking, about what the Melbourne Age said and what the Sunday Telegraph said and he was trying, as he does now, to draw some sort of inference from editorials and reports in the papers in respect of certain people-although not Senator Richardson, as I understand it from a quick look at his speech at that time. Are we going to have people convicted on the basis of editorials and on the basis of suggestions in the papers on the basis that the papers and radio broadcasters state: `We think so and so ought to be looked at'? Are we then going to set up royal commissions? Let me quote what Senator Puplick said in those days:
Here is a royal commissioner, who asks for greater powers-
that would not be unusual, just as the police ask for greater powers-

from the Government that established his position, in order to pursue his investigations into drug offences. The Government says that it is not able to give him that power. Clearly we need a national body that does have the power to undertake that sort of investigation.

Senator Puplick is asking for more powers. When the debate on the Australia Card comes along I will be interested to see whether he will be saying: `Give greater powers to certain institutions to investigate'. Where does all this stop? We have cards and we have an extension of powers to the police. Why do we not go right to the 1984 situation, with television screens everywhere, even in the bedroom, so that everybody knows what everybody else is doing? Then we will not have to rely on allegations because it will all be before us. Senator Puplick will go along with that because one of the great statements he made-I will quote this to him again and again over the years because I have it all highlighted in yellow-is: `Only people who have anything to worry about have anything to hide'. What he is really saying is that if people do not have anything to hide they should not worry about their civil liberties. That is real O'Brien stuff. That is what Winston Smith found out when he trusted O'Brien. I see that the time allotted to this debate is about to expire. As Senator Puplick is not denying me the right to continue speaking I will not call him O'Brien any more; I will call him the son of O'Brien, which reforms him a bit.

The other thing I wish to refer to is the Age tapes. I have been wanting to talk about the Age tapes for a long while. I have only five minutes left. The Age tapes represent the real problem. Having been brought up as a Christian boy, I believe that what Opposition senators really want society to do is deny any room for a redemption. They want everybody to be absolutely perfect: Anybody who does anything wrong or nods his head adversely should be rooted out and investigated. Tapes and investigative machinery should be put into operation so that, in the end, we become fearful of our neighbours, even the children in our house, those with whom we are acquainted, our friends, because we do not know whether they are wired with listening devices or whether they are paid informers who are willing to swear life and liberty away.

The old traditional values that we had-the right to silence, the right to make an unsworn statement, the right not to give one's name and address to the police, the right as citizens to enjoy as best we can the sorts of rights that our forefathers used to have are under challenge. I am speaking of the sorts of things that people fought and died for over the years to provide protection against the intrusive and, at times, malignant state-I am not saying that that is what this Government is. Institutions like the committee of public safety during the French Revolution have to be avoided; one just had to be named to have one's head lopped.

If I may be somewhat critical of honourable senators on my own side of the chamber, we have reneged, I think, too often on our obligation to protect people from the sorts of things that have been attempted here tonight. We have reneged too often on standing up and saying: `Yes, there are traditional values. There are the sorts of values that protect individuals and families'. I think that, as a result of having failed to stand up, we have suffered very drastically.

The reality is that not only honourable senators on this side of the chamber but also, deep down, Opposition senators, including Senator Puplick and Senator Michael Baume, really believe in the values that I have talked about. I think their speeches tonight were aimed at a political victory, at political pointscoring. I suppose that that is the sort of thing we have to put up with in this Senate. But when honourable senators opposite think about the ramifications of the sorts of things they do, the consequences that it might lead to and the destruction of the sort of culture that this society has developed, they will put an end to this. There are plenty of things to go on with. They have the Australia Card to talk about, they have their beloved fringe benefits tax and they have all sorts of other things.

TALK.START.PARA: —They can be redeemed.

—I think they can be redeemed. I am always hopeful. I am sure that everybody on the other side, properly counselled by Senator Withers, can be redeemed. But they have to start fairly smartly and they have to get on to real issues. They are not to pursue matters in this revolutionary and radical fashion, leaving aside those traditional values we have fought so hard to build up. They cannot cast them aside. Now is the time to stop. They have picked on poor old Senator Richardson. I think they have thrown enough darts at him. Let us leave him alone and get down to the real issues that confront this society. Let us preserve that magnificent culture and tradition which we have built up but which, unfortunately, are under very strong attack at the moment. Unfortunately, the debate tonight has contributed to the destruction of those values and that culture. It may be overtaken unless we are very careful.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1986-87[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 1) 1986-87APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 2) 1986-87]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When my speech was interrupted by the suspension of the sitting earlier I had made the point that the world needed, as a matter of urgency, a new major industry for the Third World that would permit it to earn income of a massive kind needed to permit development. I am talking not of the affairs of one person or a few people but of a matter of life and death for millions of people. Without that attention by the developed world, we have a bad time ahead of us, and soon. I was very touched and taken recently to read in the Sydney Morning Herald an excellent article by Robin Williams of the Science Show dealing with Professor Peter Mason of Macquarie University and the view that he had taken and put forward, which I think can be substantiated, that, apart from a bit of computer science and things of that kind, science has not done much for the world since 1950, that is, for nearly 30 years. Of course, that is a fact.

SPEECH.PARA: We are now a rapidly declining society in world terms, a society in which malaria is once again becoming a major killer disease of millions of people, in which child mortality is increasing and in which, in almost every possible respect, for the majority of human beings life is becoming worse to the stage of desperation-short, nasty and brutal, as it was in previous centuries, for everybody. Australia and Western countries must bear the direct responsibility for allowing that to continue because we are the only people who have the potential and power to do anything about it.

I further made the point that, although the Third World had vast areas of desert land with high and very hot sunshine records and so is ideally suited for solar energy development, in the past that had not seemed a viable option because energy is needed in the industrialised cooler areas of the earth and solar energy cannot be stored or transported. I will resume with the assertion that technology is now under rapid development which ensures that solar energy can be stored and transported. I was referring especially to the research being carried out in many parts of the world, particularly in the Weizmann Institute in Israel, into the dissociation of substances which include water, methane or ammonia into their constituent gases which can then be used by recombination to create energy at some remote point or which can be used directly, one of the key points being that in most of these areas of dissociation one of the constituent gases, the almost universal one, is hydrogen. Hydrogen is a word which in the future will mean a great deal to the world. It is of interest that, as some honourable senators will recall, for many years patents have been held by the Australian National University in Canberra for the research headed by Professor Stephen Kaneff into the dissociation of ammonia into nitrogen and hydrogen. That research seems to me to be research that could be proceeded with. It is good enough for the United States of America's energy department to put $5m into this kind of research. It would seem good enough for us to put $1m to enable this process, which was very highly lauded at its beginning, to be continued. If it can work-it is worth while trying to find out whether it can-Australia naturally has the potential for a huge energy industry that could provide for our energy needs indefinitely into the future. With our resources of natural liquid fuel running down rapidly and not much evidence of another major oilfield off-shore, and with the certain prospect of huge oil prices, even by today's standards, by the time our fuel supplies run down, it might be worth our while looking at any reasonable option that might provide this country with energy in the future, even if the costs seem now to be prohibitive. A time may well come when we will look back on petrol and fuel prices now as very cheap by the standards of the future.

It is interesting that the base product in these processes is hydrogen. In support of Professor Kaneff I will add that the scientists at the Weizmann Institute, who I understand are of world standard and with whom I discussed this matter-they after all are spending $10m on a solar furnace to work mainly on dissociation of materials into their constituent gases-said that this was a very viable option for the future. They regard it as such in their country. They regard the prospect of their exporting pipeline hydrogen to the metropolitan powers of Europe in the future as very likely. That is why they are going ahead with it. They have no doubt whatsoever that that technology can be perfected. It is not for nothing that hydrogen has been described as the fuel of the future. It is that because of another technological breakthrough, which I must yet again concede could be lower in cost but in which promising cost reduction areas are being achieved; that is, the development of the fuel cell. A fuel cell works by stripping hydrogen, methane or methanol of electrons at one electrode and giving them back at another. The fuel is oxidised just as if it had been burned but the energy output is dramatically higher than when crude burning is carried out. While fuel cells are at present expensive, they have such a promising future that many countries are working on major fuel cell programs. The fuel cells are quiet; they are non-pollutant and compact and, as I have said, they can use hydrogen as a fuel with maximum efficiency.

When one considers this kind of alternative, one runs at once into the fact that most methods of turning fuel into electricity give a conversion efficiency of about 35 per cent; that is, some 35 per cent of the energy in the fuel actually emerges as electric power. However, the fuel cell has an efficiency conversion rate hopefully as high as 85 per cent. Japan has built one such generator of four-and-a-half megawatts as a model, but it has plans for 35,000 megawatts from this technology by the year 2005.

It has been fashionable in this country to regard all these things as sort of way-up, off-beat stuff of the future. But as one moves around the world it is intriguing to find that we are the only group of scientists who look at it in that way. When we go to Israel, to the Common Market countries or to Japan we find that they do not see it in that way at all. They are quite prepared to stake millions and millions of dollars into research of that kind. They are hard-headed companies; private enterprise is involved in every case.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have nuclear power too. What about their nuclear plants?

—There are not many tougher organisations than those of Japanese private enterprise; Senator Withers might agree with that. Some of the biggest electrical companies in the world are putting literally millions of dollars into photovoltaics. Does Senator Withers know better than they do? With all respect to Senator Withers, I would doubt it. I would think that the scientific expertise in the big companies in Japan is considerably more than that which Senator Withers could convince us with. As I said earlier, on this basis it is reassuring-as the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) is here I will repeat what I said, because it is to his credit-to see that at least this year the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council are doing some work into these alternative energy sources. A start has been made, at least on some solar pond research. That technology ought to work well here. While I was in Israel I went down towards the Dead Sea to look at the little station operating there. It works extremely well. It is completely renewable energy. It does not have any staff. It works perfectly economically. It just sits there and produces power without any necessity for any fuel or any staff.
—We have nitro.

—Senator Archer is now in business. He now knows more than the experts in the Weizmann Institute in Israel and those in Japan, Holland or the United States. I think he is now saying that, like Senator Withers, he knows best. It is a great pity that these things happen because they have been a positive deterrent to possible research into scientific developments in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Wind energy is becoming of increasing significance in suitable areas. It will interest honour- able senators on my left who are again interjecting to know that such people as the Director of Energy in Israel, one of the world's leading scientists in this field to whom I could give Senator Withers an introduction if he wished, takes this technology extremely seriously. Israel is to put a great deal of time and money into it. He regards it as one of the most promising future developments that hard money can be put into, and that is being done. In California now there are more than 9,000 wind turbines generating more than 500 megawatts. This is increasing rapidly, with a target of 21,000 megawatts envisaged in that one State of California by the late 1990s. It is ridiculous for us just to hide in Rip Van Winkle land and ignore the fact that in California there is a target of 21,000 megawatts from wind energy alone, and most of it is being built by private enterprise. A good deal of it is working now and competing favourably in economic terms with fossil and nuclear power houses, and competing much more competitively than nuclear power houses if one takes into account the cost of decommissioning a nuclear power house. If that cost is thrown into the equation, the cost of nuclear power becomes roughly 50 per cent higher than the cost of wind energy, as is now being demonstrated and used in the United States of America. But Senator Withers knows better than all of those people in California! The 21,000 megawatts of power there mean nothing to him. This is cloud cuckooland. Even though these things are actually working, he has not seen them with his own eyes and, therefore, to him they do not exist. I note also with some interest a report in the Sydney Morning Herald of 25 September that the Austrian Government has ordered the dismantling of the nation's only nuclear power plant.

The movement from nuclear power to renewable resources has gained significant impetus, and this will be increasingly so in the next two or three decades. As my colleague Senator Macklin noted in a notice of motion on 11 November, renewable power sources, such as biomass, hydro, solar, wind and geothermal, already provide twice as much energy as nuclear power and in the last five years orders for 60,000 megawatts of nuclear power have been cancelled in the United States of America while, in the same period, 18,600 megawatts of cogeneration and renewable energy capacity has been ordered.

According to the Guardian of 10 July, the British Energy Secretary, Peter Walker, told the House of Commons that the Government would be putting big money into studies relating to two huge tidal power projects in Britain. He described this as `one of our most promising renewable energy resources'. The Severn Tidal Power Group, again a private enterprise group, expects the project, the Severn barrier, to start construction in 1992 at a cost of $5 1/2 billion. The Government will also put money into investigating a similar project on the Mersey River.

One welcome spin-off from the Severn pro- ject-I think this is of considerable interest to us in Australia-is that it will create 44,000 jobs. Surely it is evident to us and to the Government that in such a situation as we are in now, with so many unemployed people, that sort of construction, labour intensive as it is, will not cost what it appears to cost on paper if, indeed, it can provide work for significant numbers of people. I think that is one of the answers to our problem. It is better for us to spend that money on projects of this kind. Any project which has reasonable prospects or any research which has any sort of reasonable hope or promise for the future is better than to allow our young people to sit in a world in which they believe there is no initiative, no future and nothing ever happens. Nothing really big or significant has happened in this country in the developmental sense since we built the Snowy scheme, has it? Let us be honest with ourselves. We have sat and rotted since then. We have not even got the Burdekin scheme in Queensland going, which Townsville needs so badly. We sit here and claim that we are making progress. We do not make any kind of progress, but it is time we did.

In conclusion, it is necessary to note that many of these new technologies are now hampered because of their costs. That is a point which has to be conceded. It is true that, even though, for instance, solar systems are now operating more and more efficiently with every new development that is built, and wind systems are narrowing the gap and are now comparable certainly with nuclear costs, when the costs of decommissioning nuclear reactors are taken into account, the basic imperative is not an economic one; the basic imperative is strategic. From a defence point of view these are dangers to the world, in the event of war, of having nuclear power stations and of having any kind of nuclear fuel cycle. There are the dangers of horizontal proliferation of nuclear weapons based on U235. If we allow technologies such as the laser enrichment to go ahead, those are the imperatives.

The other imperative is our view of the future, our responsibilities to future generations. They will look back on us and make their judgment of this generation on what we do now and whether we showed ourselves to be a generation of human beings who had the vision to look forward and try to get things sorted out for the future so that some hydrocarbons were left for future generations. To burn them up is, I think, one of the most decisive and important decisions any government can make now. On that basis, I commend to this Government that it courageously go forward and develop and research, where it seems prudent and wise, even if it does not seem economic, and wherever it might be viable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1986-87 and Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1986-87 I will take the opportunity to draw some comparisons between the economic performance of Queensland and that of the national economy. Earlier this evening Senator Michael Baume tried very hard to talk down the economy and to validate his claims by mentioning an American financier, who claimed that investment in Australia in the future would not return the amount that it should. It is only reasonable that we should compare in some way the performance of the conservative Government in Queensland with that of the national economy to show how that Government is performing under the present economic circumstances. I think it will show clearly the type of performance that one could expect from a Howard-led government in the national economy. It is quite obvious that Queensland is a supporter of the New Right or, should I say, the old Right, or could we say it is one and the same. The recent economic performance of the National Party Government in Queensland leaves a lot to be desired. Its very bad performance in a number of areas is continuing to pull down the national economy.

SPEECH.PARA: For many months Queensland has had the worst economic record of all States. A close analysis of 18 economic indicators to the beginning of this month, compiled by senior economist Jason Reynolds from figures supplied by such reliable sources as the Australian Bureau of Statistics and Federal Government departments shows that it is still the case that the performance of the Queensland Government is the worst of all State governments. Of the 18 areas surveyed, Queensland had the worst result in five, the second worst result in eight, and below the national average in 14. The areas in which Queensland had the poorest results to 1 November included the following: The lowest average weekly earnings for May-$396, which is 6 per cent below the Australian average; again Queensland had the greatest fall in the number of new dwelling units approved for the September quarter 1986, with approval down 34.2 per cent compared with the same period last year; for the three months ended September 1986 Queensland had the greatest fall in the number of new telephone connections, which are tied very closely to the investment that is made in that State by business. Compared with the same period a year earlier they were down some 14.5 per cent. This is a highly significant and most underestimated indicator, as it proves that new business is not moving into Queensland to any great extent, contrary to the assertions of the Government of that State.

In the June quarter 1986 Queensland had the greatest fall in the number of new residential buildings completed. It declined by 20.8 per cent compared with the same period in 1985. Queensland also has the second worst result in the following: The unemployment rate for Queensland for October 1986 was 9.1 per cent; the national average over the same period was 7.8 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you read the telephone book?

—I suppose in Brisbane one could read the telephone directory. Because a number of allocations of new phone numbers has not been included, it is a very thin book and it would be very easy for the honourable senator to read it. For the past two years Queensland has had either the highest or the second highest unemployment rate and the second lowest average weekly earnings for women-$252.80 at May this year. That is 10 per cent below the national average. It had the second worst figure in the number of overtime hours worked, at 6.5 per worker in August this year. The household income per capita in Queensland for 1984-85 was $10,410, which was 9.8 per cent below the national average. The number of new residential buildings completed in the June quarter declined, as I said before, by 20.8 per cent compared with the same period in 1985. Queensland has the second highest increase in the number of bankruptcies for the year ended 1985-86. No doubt my colleague Senator Sheil will be able to take down some of the figures and probably he will try to make some comparisons at a later stage. I am sure that the honourable senator will find that these figures are very true. They come from the Australian Bureau of Statistics and from the various departments. So it is very difficult for the National Party in Queensland to deny the sorts of problems that exist within the economy of Queensland.
—Don't you represent Queensland?

—Yes, I do represent Queensland, and it is very difficult to do so with the decline in the economy that is being caused by the National Party Government that has just been re-elected under a very large gerrymander in that State-61 per cent of the people in Queensland voted against having a National Party government, and the National Party is able to govern on 37 per cent of the vote. Queensland-let me repeat this for Senator Sheil's benefit-had the second highest increase in the number of bankruptcies for the 1985-86 financial year. It was up 23.7 per cent over the previous financial year. That was an increase of 23 per cent in 12 months. Queensland had the second largest decrease in new motor vehicle registrations. For the September quarter of 1986 there was a drop of something like 26.5 per cent over the same period in 1985. We could go a little bit further. Queensland had the second highest proportion of industrial disputes for the year ending July 1986, with 295 days lost per thousand employees-the second highest number of days lost per thousand employees of any State in Australia. It was 13.5 per cent higher than the national average.

SPEECH.PARA: Further, Queensland had the second lowest growth for new fixed private capital expenditure for the March quarter this year. Again, looking back at the number of phone connections one sees a relationship between the fixed private capital expenditure or investment in the State and the number of connections made in the State of Queensland. Queensland was also below the national growth rate for the number of new residential buildings under construction at the end of June 1986-down 8.2 per cent on the same quarter a year earlier. Figures produced this week by the Australian Bureau of Statistics show that the building industry in Queensland is at a point of collapse, or even beyond it. I think that what has happened in Queensland in relation to the building industry provides a very clear example of this. There has been a downturn in the supply of building materials to that industry. In the three months to August 1986 the production in Queensland of concrete blocks was down 23.1 per cent on the figure for the same period in 1985. Roofing tiles, terra cotta and concrete were down by 20.8 per cent. Ready-mixed concrete-that is the supply of ready-mixed concrete to new building sites and sites where renovations were being carried out-was down by 13.1 per cent. Structural clay bricks were down by 4.7 per cent. This gives an indication of what is happening in the building industry in Queensland. Sales of paint, which is used in the construction of dwellings in the finishing off process, are down in the State of Queensland by 4.1 per cent. This is entirely due to the decline in the domestic building industry outlined earlier. I believe that one of the problems we face in Queensland is the fact that the Government is cutting back on expenditure and also is not encouraging investment in the State of Queensland, which would allow for the development and construction of office blocks, home units and other buildings on building sites throughout the State of Queensland.

One of the things we must look at when comparing what happens at the national level with what happens at the State level is what the Federal Government and the trade union movement have done in relation to prices and in relation to the accord. First of all, let us look at prices. The Federal Government does not have the constitutional power to govern prices in the State of Queensland. While such a power is available to the State Government in Queensland, we find continual increases in the prices being paid for consumer goods by the families and people who live within Queensland. The State Government continues to allow the increases in prices and takes no steps to try to contain prices so that there is a reasonable standard of living and so that the low wages being received by the workers in the State of Queensland can at least purchase consumer goods at a reasonable price. But, as I said, the Federal Government does not have the constitutional power to control prices.

However, in March 1984, the Federal Government did establish the Prices Surveillance Authority. In recent times this Authority has held inquiries into principal charges of Australia Post-one of the Federal Government's own facilities-fruit juice prices, cigarette prices, the table chicken industry and retail food and grocery prices. Following consultation with the Australian Council of Trade Unions last year the Treasurer, Mr Keating, in line with the Government's policy, instructed the Prices Surveillance Authority not to support price increases in excess of movements in unit costs. In August 1985 the Prices Surveillance Authority issued a set of voluntary guidelines and it now publishes a bulletin each quarter called Price News, which provides information on movements. This is in line with the promise of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to the nation in June when he stated:
There will be an extension of the list of products under review and increased communication with the public.
This statement was made in relation to inflation and increases in prices which provide excessive profits to those companies selling at retail prices to the consumer.

One of the things that the Federal Government has done during its period of office has been to introduce a centralised wage fixing system. By September 1983 there had been five national wage decisions involving applications from the trade union movement for wage and salary increases based on consumer price index movements. I suppose, looking at the result of those increases, one would have to say that the trade union movement has been very positive in the way in which it has approached these applications for wage increases. A lot of credit is due to the trade union movement for sticking to increases that are based on CPI movements. The results were: A 4.3 per cent rise in October 1983; 4.1 per cent in April 1984; 2.6 per cent in April 1985; 3.8 per cent in November 1985; and 2.3 per cent in July 1986. The trade union movement and the ACTU have shown a very responsible attitude in accepting discounting and in accepting the fact that only a 2.3 per cent increase was received in July 1986.

One would have to say that this reflects great credit on the trade union movement, because it has done something to try to assist the economy in Australia. It has provided a reasonable increase for its members but it continues to keep these increases to a level which covers the CPI movements. More recently, the ACTU, employer groups and the Government have given consideration to changes in the system. I believe that the Government sees merit in certain changes providing wage restraint continues and the current Budget forecasts for aggregate wage growth are not exceeded. I believe that all members of the Government appreciate the way the trade union movement has acted with great restraint in recent difficult economic times. I think the Government also appreciates the co-operation of the vast majority of employers in relation to the economic difficulties that we have been facing.

I suppose that, comparing what is happening at the Federal level with what is happening at the State level, one can see that the State Government can only build confrontation and fight with the trade union movement to try to encourage the trade union movement towards a more militant point of view. It tries to force it into unrewarding strikes at which point the State Government moves in and sacks the striking workers. One has only to look at the South East Queensland Electricity Board strike in which power workers employed by SEQEB were sacked by the State Government and have not been reinstated now that that particular issue has been resolved.

It is obvious that the way to economic recovery and progress in Australia is through the spirit of mutual co-operation and understanding created by the incomes accord, which has given a benefit to all, and I believe that it is something that will be maintained by a reasonable and constructive trade union movement in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following the speakers list on the Appropriation Bills is something of a challenge, Madam Acting Deputy President. I notice that it has been suddenly rearranged. In speaking this evening on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1986-87 and cognate Bills, I want to pick up on some more specific areas of interest and concern of mine under the appropriations rather than talk in more general and wider terms of the broad economic thrust of the Budget. Those areas have been very well covered, for example, by Senator Cook in his contribution this afternoon. The Appropriation Bills give me an opportunity to speak of a couple of areas that I find of very great importance and which I think are well worthy of the Senate's attention under this legislation, being, as they are, part of the Budget program. In particular, I drawn the Senate's attention to the document that is produced at the same time as the Budget documents, the Women's Budget Program. It is an extraordinarily useful document, describing, as it does, how all the ministries affect women in terms of the staff and behaviour of people within the departments and the implementation of policies and legislation covered by the portfolios.

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, I want to look at a sub-set of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations headed `National Occupational Health and Safety Commission'-now known as Worksafe Australia. That Commission, Worksafe Australia, has been in existence for over a year now and is well on the way to being solidly estab- lished. The initial period of establishment is past, and we are now beginning to see the benefits of that Commission and its more comprehensive work. Worksafe Australia, the shorthand name for the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission, is responsible for policies and strategies to improve occupational health and safety. Its activities include the development of national standards and codes of practice, the review of laws and awards relating to occupational health and safety, the collection and dissemination of information relating to occupational health and safety matters, providing and encouraging training and skills relevant to occupational health and safety, and conducting educational and promotional programs.

Worksafe Australia enshrines, I suppose, the principle, and is in the process of putting into practice, the expectation and the general principle of equity that everyone has the right to a healthy and safe working environment. This is of particular relevance and pertinence, in the document from which I am reading, to women. In the Women's Budget Program the relevance is spelt out under the heading of Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. The Commission has been asked by the Government to conduct research into occupational health and safety problems in the working environment particularly relevant and pertinent to women. In particular, it is recommending suitable legislation and regulations to cover working environments where women predominate and which are not covered by existing legislative provisions. It has also been asked to review regulations that are designed to protect women workers but which may in practice be discriminatory, and to identify and control factors that would affect reproduction for both men and women.

Also, the Commission, in its specific regard for women, will look at legislation and awards that seem to provide protection but in fact not only discriminate against women but also prohibit them from having an opportunity to work. I am thinking in particular of the requirements as to what is a safe amount to be lifted. Those standards, for example, are currently under review because they are tied to old standards setting procedures and are not necessarily pertinent or relevant in the current situation.

Worksafe has also specifically asked its Manufacturing Industry Committee to examine the extent of the occupational health and safety effects of piece-work and out-work practices employed in manufacturing industry, particularly as they affect workers of non-English speaking backgrounds and women, and to make appropriate recommendations. That is a particularly important area. I am sure that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, would be concerned about that, too, particularly in the current very comprehensive examination of the textiles, clothing and footware industry, where many of the questions to be asked have to address not only the number of workers but also where those workers are and what are the conditions affecting their health and safety. I think it can be said that this Government has a very well established history of being comprehensive in the way that it examines such questions, and I think the health and safety dimension of those workers is a very important facet. I am very pleased that Worksafe Australia is seriously addressing them.

Of course, it is not only confined to textiles, clothing and footwear. Any sub-set of the manufacturing sector that uses out-workers or piece-workers will be included in that examination. It is important to know that many of those piece-workers and out-workers are women. Very often they are not English-speaking women or they are struggling to learn English as a second language, so they are a group of workers particularly at risk. They are at risk of being underpaid and exploited; but they are also at risk of suffering less than sufficient health and safety standards in the way that they are being asked to work, and perhaps, too, from pressure or encouragement to increase their rate of work.

The other area that is very important in the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission is the comprehensive examination of the condition-I suppose it is a grab bag of conditions-known as RSI, the repetitive strain injury group of conditions. We have had a long debate in the community about whether RSI exists at all and to what extent it should be taken seriously. Fortunately, I think that that piece of history is behind us, and that RSI is known to be a real condition. If it is treated seriously-that is, if it is judged to be a serious and real condition-appropriately different behaviour follows. I am pleased to see that the Government has, through the RSI national strategy recently released by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Ralph Willis, acknowledged the seriousness with which it regards this condition and the degree to which it is pleased to have a strategy to address the difficulties of RSI.

Some very outrageous and false claims have been made about this group of conditions: First, as I said earlier, that it does not exist as a real condition; secondly, that it is mainly in the mind and not in the aching arms, elbows, shoulders, necks, and so on, of the people complaining of it; and, thirdly, that it is a condition that affects only white-collar middle-class workers. Anyone who has examined the documented medical history of the RSI condition will know that that is nonsense. Even in 1985, the latest figures would suggest that about 75 per cent of claims come from other than white-collar work places.

This is well acknowledged in the national strategy. The strategy has six components, and under one of those components, called `Standards', the strategy proposes to develop an industry-specific code of practice for the manufacturing industry and keyboard occupations, acknowledging in those words the understanding that it is not only a keyboard condition. It has been long understood that RSI conditions occur in the manufacturing industry, particularly in repetitive work done on assembly lines of all sorts. It is also a condition that is known among shearers and musicians, particularly stringed instrument players but also piano players-although I suppose strictly that is a stringed instrument, but getting at the strings is less direct.

Repetition strain injury is not a new condition. It is often claimed that it exists only in Australia. Any examination of medical literature from America or England will give conclusive evidence that it has been around for a long time. It has been called any number of things, but it is not a condition that is new; it is not a condition that is confined to white collar workers on keyboards in the public sector in Australia. I am pleased that that section of the debate has passed. I am pleased that we now have a national strategy acknowledging the seriousness of the condition, and also its realness, and are taking significant steps to reduce the incidence and, if possible, to prevent it. It has been discovered that, among other things, RSI is an eminently preventable condition. If acknowledged early and properly managed, it is a short term discomfort for people rather than, as is sometimes the case, a permanent disability that is not reversible if it is left untreated. So the strategy to address the difficulties of RSI is to be greatly welcomed. Since the RSI proposals have been taken seriously and steps have been taken to address the difficulty, and particularly to introduce preventive measures, the incidence of RSI appears to be declining.

The Public Service Board announced a drop of 4.3 per cent in RSI affected staff in the Australian Public Service in the March quarter of this year as compared to the December quarter of 1985. Some States have also reported early encouraging signs of a fall and numerous organisations with RSI prevention programs have significantly reduced incident rates. Those of us who attended an Estimates Committee hearing earlier this Budget session have the hard data, in answer to questions put to various departments, that the incidence of RSI is falling in most departments in the Public Service. I do not believe that is inadvertent or accidental. I think that it is in response to an acknowledgment of the seriousness of the condition to take steps to provide early treatment, and in particular to put into place preventive measures. I am very pleased to acknowledge the step that has been taken within Worksafe Australia and under the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. Anyone who is interested will find more reference to that in the `Women's Budget Program' document, which documents this very well along with any number of other government policies that have particular relevance for women.

The RSI condition is also very important in terms of an economic consideration. A number of people have failed to understand exactly what are the cost implications of a condition such as RSI, or for that matter any condition that permanently disables a worker. Apart from the considerable cost of human suffering, difficulties and misery that can be created in the family of any worker who is disabled out of the work force, there is the inordinate economic or hard dollar costs. Figures for accident and death caused in the work place in 1982 were assessed by the then Minister, Mr Ian Macphee, to cost this community some $4.5 billion a year. Any efforts we can make to reduce the costs of illness and injury in the work place have to be welcomed, not only for human consideration but because of the hard economic calculation. I am pleased to see that already, because of those steps taken by Worksafe Australia, there has been a decline in the incidence of RSI.

That is of some relevance because in recent times the incidence of RSI has been claimed as a very large contributing factor to the dramatic increase in compensation premium costs happening around the country. I am staggered to discover how compensation premiums have increased in the last four or five years. Although I have asked questions about it and am still seeking information, I do not believe that we yet have a full understanding of why compensation premiums went through the roof in the last few years. I can appreciate why the compensation payouts may have increased, because there may have been larger settlements and more people claiming, but to understand why that caused such a massive cost in premiums is still problematical. I remember drawing to Minister Button's attention the dramatic increase that G. J. Coles and Co. Ltd had to pay for compensation premiums-something like $4m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have never forgotten your mentioning it.

—I am delighted the Minister has not forgotten it. I hope one of these days he will be able to give me a full and comprehensive answer as to why those premiums increased. A figure that rose from some $4m near enough to $20m in four years is a matter of considerable importance. Certainly Coles took the matter seriously, and rightly so. In fact, when I inquired further, I discovered that the number of people claiming for accident or injury over that period fell slightly. Although we can say that some of the premium costs have to be attributed to increased payments on settlement, it is still difficult to understand why there would have been such a dramatic increase in premium costs over that time.

SPEECH.PARA: I also understand that the figures at the universities in my State of South Australia reflect exactly the same increase. I believe that Flinders University in 1979-80 had a payment for compensation premium of about $45,000 and in 1985-86 its premium costs had risen to $400,000. I am not very good at percentage increases, but I think that is approaching a 1,000 per cent increase in seven years. It is fairly dramatic, especially when I discovered from that university that the number of accidents and injuries claimed for have fallen slightly. I appreciate that it depends on the nature of the claim and the payment on settlement. But even so, with the falling number of complaints one would think that there may have been a fall, or at least only a small increase, to do with the consumer price index and so on, over that time in compensation premiums. That is not the case, and I understand that kind of picture is reflected in any number of areas around the country. Around the years 1983-84 there was a dramatic increase in compensation premiums. I hope that any steps the Government can take to reduce those inordinate costs will be put in place as soon as possible. If they are not already in place, I acknowledge the value of Worksafe Australia, and in particular its strategy for RSI, but as more of the occupational health and safety programs are implemented, I hope that we will see a fall in the number of accidents and injuries at work. I also hope that we shall see reflected a corresponding reduction in the massive costs through both compensation premiums and pay-outs.

Finally, I would mention one other area under this very useful document, `Women's Budget Program', and I refer to the Department of Sport. Those honourable senators who have been in this place for a year or so will know that not too long ago, in May 1985, I reported to the Senate on an inquiry into women in sport that I had been asked to chair for the Government. We tabled the report in the Senate and in the House of Representatives, which was entitled `Women, Sport and the Media'. That inquiry found that women in sport throughout the country were very much disadvantaged compared to men in sport-in media coverage, opportunities for sponsorship, financial assistance, facilities, access to training and so on. In just about every area of sport affecting women as players of sport, there was insufficient assistance and inequitable distribution of finances towards women in sport. Our principal recommendation from that inquiry was that there should be established a permanent unit, which we preferred would be called the women's sports promotion unit, established within the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism to become a focus for all the improvements that we had hoped to see for women and sport in this country.

I am very pleased to announce again-it was first announced on 2 November-that the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, Mr John Brown, and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women, Senator Ryan, have jointly announced the establishment of a task force on women in sport under the Australian Sports Commission. That is the first step to the establishment-I hope-of a permanent unit to be a focus for all those things that women in sport need in this country. The establishment of that task force is very much in accord with the initiatives taken by Minister Brown in the area of sport. His encouragement for broad participation by people of both sexes and all ages is to be thoroughly endorsed, and I certainly do that. The recently released Aussie Sports with the modified rules to encourage more and more youngsters to take part in sport in primary school and to maintain that participation in secondary school by girls is to be very much encouraged and acknowledged.

The establishment of the task force on women in sport fits very well with the other steps taken by the Minister to promote the participation by women in sporting activities of all sorts and at all sorts of levels-from the level of recreation through to the level of excellence. Women in sport in this country have some extraordinary achievements. Many of these achievements are forgotten, not sufficiently acknowledged or unsung. The achievements of women in sport in this country are quite remarkable. Our Olympic gold medal list shows that women feature in higher numbers than men in winning individual gold medals. I will not spell out the achievements of great women in the history of sport in this country but I recommend that interested honourable senators look at the `Women, Sport and the Media' report and see some of the achievements documented there.

I am delighted that we have a task force for women in sport within the Sports Commission. That task force will be headed by Margaret Pewtress who is a member of the Sports Commission and who has had very long experience as a world-class netball player. She has also had long experience in administration in that sport. She will be assisted by Vicki Cardwell, Australian and world-class squash champion, and Wendy Ey, who was both an athletic performer and an Olympic athletic administrator. For encouragement for women in sport and for developing and implementing the recommendations from our `Women, Sport and the Media' report, the task force is something that I am delighted to see established, and I congratulate the Government on doing so. This has been done at a time of considerable budgetary constraints, as other speakers have no doubt spelt out in this debate on the Appropriation Bills. These two areas of women and sport are of particular interest to me-that is not to say that I do not have interests in other areas-and I wish to focus on them.

Even though we have enormously difficult budgetary constraints, which have been spelt out by any number of Government senators, the Government has still done an enormous amount in this Budget. I commend the Government for the Budget and for its priorities for the most needy-a focus which it has always had and which it is implementing in this Budget. I also commend the `Women's Budget Program' as an excellent document for discovering in more detail how the various items in the Budget particularly affect women.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This year's Budget is a statement of despair from a dull and unimaginative administration for whom the long term is probably anything after the next session of the money market. It can probably be called the `Budget of a thousand cuts' and, as Senator Richardson has so honestly pointed out, some of the deepest cuts have been at the Government's own throat. Besides the financial cuts there has been a general tendency to cut down on the information available to the Parliament and to the public. That has been achieved by putting freedom of information beyond the reach of many Australians and by turning the program budgeting reporting to the Senate into a charade. It has also been achieved by closing avenues of independent analysis, in areas such as multiculturalism, by closing down the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs, and in areas of consultation with local government by closing down the Advisory Council for Inter-Government Relations.
—Don't talk bunkum. What do you think that did for anybody?

—There has been a failure to recognise what these bodies do and that has just been echoed by Senator Button who has obviously swallowed totally the line put forward by his colleagues in the Treasury and in the Department of Finance. I believe that the Government has also swallowed the line put forward by the large foreign corporate organisations which have forced it into condoning such corporate rorts as inter-company negative gearing, transfer pricing and all those types of activities. Instead of raising funds from those groups of people, who can afford to pay, the Government is raising revenue from ordinary Australians and the poor who cannot afford to pay. Indeed, the Government has been afraid to upset the apple cart of the currency speculators. It has also shown a remarkable leniency towards the tobacco interests despite their unparalleled contribution to illness in Australia. The dominant minority faction in the Australian Labor Party seems to be devoid of ideas and totally in the thrall of the Treasury. Thus we are missing a large number of opportunities for national recovery.

SPEECH.PARA: We really cannot continue with the failed policies of the Stone clones in the Treasury with their fundamentalist American monetarist views and their particularly poor approach to the economy. We must learn to stand up for a strong, independent Australia and not just stand up for foreign economic interests, as the Government has been doing, which interests basically the cuts in this Budget have been organised to placate. It is a tragedy for Australia that the Opposition threatens to augment the role of the Treasury when it gets back into government. I believe that that would be absolutely disastrous. Instead, we should get some common sense back into the Treasury and make certain that some people with business experience in the Australian community and an understanding of the needs of Australians are actually let into those areas.

For example, in our current trendy deregulation mode, the Treasury and the Department of Finance want to examine the corporate plans of statutory authorities and to set a variety of performance targets. Clearly these two departments have too many staff and I being this to the notice of the Minister. These staff are not specialists in the specific functions of the authorities and the only explanation for this interference can be that they regard the Minister responsible for each authority as somehow derelict in his duties. No other rational explanation could be given for this particular type of measure. I would like to illustrate this and I will do so when I continue my remarks tomorrow. At that time I will refer to Telecom Australia and the fact that the Government has ripped $98m from Telecom which it could have used for the development of proper technology within the Australian community. I really believe that a Minister such as Senator Button would see the advantages of leaving that money in there to be spent on development of an effective telecommunications industry within Australia. It is this type of strangling of industry and of opportunities which has resulted in the problems that I will outline in the rest of my speech tomorrow. Right now Australia is in the world forefront of fibre optics research. There are billion dollar markets available if we only want to chase them, yet the problem is that Telecom is not being allowed to develop them with our local industry.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the lead-up to any election it is common to see politicians bandying around outrageous accusations under privilege in an attempt to blacken the name of their opponents. One Australian Labor Party politician from Queensland distinguished himself in that regard during the last sittings of Parliament. I refer to the honourable member for Capricornia, Mr Keith Wright, who is in the melancholy position of being a failed Queensland Labor Party leader, rejected first by the sensible voters of Queensland and then by the members of his own Party. Among the more minor of his unsubstantiated and false allegations was a disgraceful smear of a very worthwhile community organisation-the Leisha Harvey Community Link.

SPEECH.PARA: The members of this organisation, not having the facilities of the honourable member for Capricornia, have asked me to respond on their behalf. First, the Link was not created by Mrs Leisha Harvey, the successful National Party of Australia member for Greenslopes in the State Parliament; it was initiated and formed by a committee of five ladies who sought Mrs Harvey's co-operation and permission to use her name. The basic aim of the Link is to provide a social grouping and joining of people and groups of similar interests in the Greenslopes community and through this to give support to local charities. There is nothing political about the group's activities. Some members, not all, freely admit they are members of the National Party. Due to the fine work the Link has done in the community, its membership has grown to 16 women. The committee totally refutes Mr Wright's accusation that it in any way funded any political advertisements or donated any money raised by social functions to any politician.

The advertisement the honourable member for Capricornia referred to was in fact paid for by the member for Greenslopes personally and is a reflection of her good relationship with her constituents-a relationship proved by her easy win on 1 November. Mr Wright referred to a Melbourne Cup party last year. Revenue raised amounted to $1,800, but after paying for the hire of the hall, the kitchen and other sundry expenses, profits came to $492, which was donated in full to the local Red Cross. The committee chairman, Mrs Maureen Hunter, is quite prepared to offer to anyone who is interested full access to the financial dealings of the Link. She has taken professional advice to ensure that all is in order.

What the Link does is get people together, particularly aged people, and create a more caring society. While the money it raises might be a modest amount, it has always gone and will continue to go to the needy, worthwhile charities in the area. All the ladies of the Leisha Harvey Community Link are unpaid volunteer workers and are to be admired for their fine community spirit and genuine contribution towards building a better society. They certainly do not deserve to be denigrated by some desperate failed politician under parliamentary privilege for the most base political motives.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.34 p.m.
